reviews.title: Tribute Arch That Offers a Great View of the City
reviews.text: We appreciated the tasteful tribute to the military coup July 1994 that offers views of Banjul.  This is the tallest structure in The Gambia and worth a visit.

reviews.title: Panoramic View of Banjul
reviews.text:
Located on the Banjul-Serrekunda highway into Banjul, is the commemorative arch built in 1996 Provisional Ruling Council overthrew the democratically elected Gambian government of President Sir Dawda Jawara.  A statue of the "unknown soldier" is set near the base of the arch:
Construction

At about 90 feet, the arch is one of the tallest structures in The Gambia. The building has three floors. Access to the upper floors can be made through a series of several marble spiral stairs.  Although there is an elevator it was not working.

Each floor provides a panorama of the city, with the top floor providing a view extending to the sea port of Banjul and the mangrove forests of Tanbi Wetland Complex. In the third level is a series of photos of  President Jawara.  Worth a climb if you are in reasonably good shape.

reviews.title: Important to put this museum in perspective
reviews.text:
By today's European standards this little museum is a museum piece in itself. The displays in the natural history and agriculture sections are poor by any standards, consisting of poorly framed and fading photographs and a few skins.
The reconstructed settlement of the 19th century is much better and was made more interesting by the guide who accompanied me. 
However you would be hard put to spend more than an hour here. I was soon in the central bar/entertainment area where a drum band was playing (for me). All a bit uncomfortable and although I would like to have helped by spending some money there was no 'shop' or even any craft souvenirs available. A lack of funding is clearly a problem and such efforts to promote Gambian culture can only be commended and supported- just don't expect much. But in time things should change.

reviews.title: Nice outing!
reviews.text: This place should be better known! The museum here is just as good as the main national one in Banjul, and because there are so few visitors, you get your own guided tour from the very knowledgeable curator who works there. There's some interesting history here, and the museum also displays some cultural artefacts from the nearby areas in the north bank. The views from the fortress are nice too. I am based in Fajara, and it was easy to catch a couple of bush taxis, get the ferry and the walk to the fort from the ferry terminal in Barra. The entrance fee is 100 dalasi.

reviews.title: Historie van Gambia, dit moet je wel gezien hebben.
reviews.text:
We bezochten dit met onze locale  chauffeur en gids Muhammed Camara (ook wel bekend Big Mo)
Op de afgesproken tijd was Mo bij ons hotel, we reden naar de ferry en Mo regelde  de kaartjes voor de ferry.
Ook heeft hij steeds koude drankjes voor je bij ( water- frisdrank)erg fijn gezien de temperaturen.

Aangekomen stond er een auto klaar met chauffeur en beozchten we eerst het dorpje 
historische dorpje Juffurey, beroemd om zijn connectie met de slavenhandel.
Hier had Mo een gids geregeld die ons alles kon vertellen tijdens het bezoek aan het museum.
Daarna Had Mo een bootje geregeld incl de gids om de oversteek te maken naar Kunta Kinthe Island.
Bizar als je erover nadenkt wat daar allemaal gevbeurd is, de mensen die opgeloten werden konden onmogelijk ontsnappen aangezien het midden in de Gambia rivier ligt.

Aan het einde van deze trip had Mo een lunch geregeld ter plekke, om vervolgens weer richting de ferry te gaan.
Interessante dagtrip, de meerwaarde van onze gids spreekt voor zich...alles perfect geregeld En hij kon weer mooie foto's van ons maken.
 Big Mo is een aanbeveling als je op zoek bent naar een betrouwbare, goed Engels sprekende gids, prettig in omgang is en alles perfect voor je regeld. +220-703 15 53

reviews.title: A Living Museum in The Gambia
reviews.text:
Along the Coastal Road, halfway between Tanje and Batukunku, the Tanje Village Museum (find it in Google Maps) was an unexpected and pleasant encounter; greeted by the smiling welcome of the young curator, I paid a small entrance fee (GMD 200.00) and was accompanied on the tour of the premises.

In addition to typical pictures, exhibits, cloths, costumes, agricultural tools, musical  instruments etc. regarding the culture and the traditional ways of life of the major ethnic groups of the Gambia, I was surprised to find, actually, an ethnobotanical museum, with standing trees and plants utilized for building, alimentary, ritual and/or therapeutical purposes.
I also watched a weaver busy with his craft and listened to traditional songs played by a band of musicians while sitting in the bantaba sipping tea and trying to appease my customary curiosity by firing unending questions at the knowledgeable guide.

A modern extended family (owners of the museum) live in the same large compound enclosing the museum, and I could see men, women and children carrying out their daily chores and activities, thus transmuting a simple visit to a museum into a unique, "unplugged" experience.

When I left the compound, I made a late discovery: lodges, a conference room and an ethnic restaurant  are available for a full immersion museal – and gastronomic – adventure. Gambia, here I come!

reviews.title: Gambian National Museum
reviews.text: Our tour guides were very knowledgeable regarding the artefacts in the museum. Both Hadden and Omar were extremely nice, patients and great people to speak with. Thank you for the time you took to explain the different areas in the museum and for explaining what happened during the different dispensation in your beautiful country.

reviews.title: Well curated little museum
reviews.text: The  exhibits in this small museum have surprising scope and depth with lots of black and white photos, maps, costumes, instruments and prehistoric stone tools - but no masks.  Some to the themes include weaving done by men, ceramics by women, Gesseh wedding rituals, shell mound burials, tribal languages and  the slave trade.  On the negative side, the display cases appeared very dusty and some of the exhibits were very dated - with explanations that appeared to be prepared using a type writer!  Recommend.

reviews.title: Great view over Banjul
reviews.text: This monument is big and you can go up and see very good view and you can see over the Banjul city from here. Price to up is not much,  but view is nice. Defenetly worth of visit.

reviews.title: Great way to get a good view of the city
reviews.text: Walking up the stairs in the west-african heat may be a bit of an unexpected workout for some,but its worth visiting. Its not that tall a building, but given that there are no tall buildings in The Gambia, you can enjoy very good view of the city, take some great pics, enjoy the breeze and educate yourself in the small museum.

reviews.title: Waste of Money
reviews.text: I am aware that the arch is a commerative one but surely the money spent on its construction would have been better used elsewhere.

reviews.title: A must when visiting banjul
reviews.text: Banjul is very known for this arch which is why you should see it if you’re ever in Banjul city. Not really that big of a deal but still.

reviews.title: So much potential but run down
reviews.text: The arch is one of those must see monuments in The Gambia. Unfortunately it’s not been well looked after and maintained- the elevator doesn’t work and the stairway is really dark which is dangerous because it’s a winding, loopy staircase. When we reached the top after a long climb, I was expecting to see some sort of history or information on the monument but there wasn’t. For a small country, it’s still worth heading to for a look around.

reviews.title: an arch with a bad history
reviews.text:
When you are in Banjul do go for a visit to this Arch. It isn't that beautiful but it has a bloody history that will tell you about the dictator and the killings going on in front of the Arch.

On the other hand, going really on top of the rach gives you a great view over Banjul. There's also a small exposition above about the dictator and the Arch itself. 

Be advised that there is no elevator, so you have to climb by stairs!

reviews.title: Worth going for the view and history
reviews.text: This monument now celebrates the freedom of the Gambian people after the fall of the dictator Yahya Jammeh. The view from the top is good and there is a small exhibition (not really a museum) about the peaceful change of power. I don't think we paid to enter the Arch 22 but it would be worth a dollar or two.

reviews.title: The entrance to Banjul city
reviews.text:
We had a private guided tour of the city and stopped here to learn about the recent history of the nation. The lift was out of action (I think it always is) and our guide suggested there were 100 steps up - maybe there are but it didn't seem that many once you started the climb - it's 114ft at the highest point and is supported by 8 huge columns. It is named July 22nd Arch in memory of the 1994 revolution.  

The museum is not worth the title - but the views are definitely worth the effort. From the new National Assembly building, down Independence Drive and right over to the ocean. It is possible to walk outside onto the bridge to have photographs un-obscured by the window glazing

reviews.title: Wasted potential
reviews.text: Feels like a tourist trap! Museum at the top was very disappointing. Perhaps the only good thing is the view you get from the top and it makes for a good picture. I would not go our of my way to visit this place. If its part of your city tour then thats ok. But if you're planning to just head out to the arch and make a day of it? DON'T!!!

reviews.title: Gambia in a house
reviews.text: The National museum which is located in Banjul offers visitors to revisit the ancient past of The Gambia. The museum chronicles all aspect of Gambian life and how people used to live 1000s of years ago. My journey to this historic museum was very interesting as I had the chance to know more about the real Gambian culture and way of life.

reviews.title: Worth the climb!
reviews.text: For a meagre 50 dalasi (less than £1, depending on the exchange rate!), Arch 22 provides a great view of Banjul and the Atlantic Ocean. A slight climb to the top gives an opportunity for some great panoramic shots, and the chance to see the city’s Parliamentary building, Independence Drive and dwellings. With it being such a cheap excursion, it’s a must-do when visiting Banjul.

reviews.title: Views from Banjul
reviews.text: I had the chance to visit the Arch 22 which was build to commemorate the 1994 revolution. The Arch houses various Gambian artifacts, and beautiful view of the capital.There is also a restaurant where you can eat and relax for the day.

reviews.title: nothing special, just an arch. Take some pictures, that is it
reviews.text:
Just an arch and you can take pictures. There were some seatings to the side across the judicial hall. 

Seriously, nothing exciting. 

If you are traveling, make sure to take your passport. There were several checkpoints and the police give you a hard time without one. 

Easily accessible.

reviews.title: Arch
reviews.text: It is the only historical place what you can see in gambia so it is definetely good to visit this place and there is a nice view on the top of the arch as well.

reviews.title: Not what I expected!
reviews.text: The arch was built for the coup of President Jameyh, who was just voted out and forced to leave the country. They said there was a museum in the Arch. I don't know if I would call it that. It was an interesting building and had good views of the surrounding area. I think it is supposed to be free but there is usually some government worker at the entrance extorting money to gain entry.

reviews.title: well worth a visit
reviews.text:
Tanji Village Museum is the first private museum in The Gambia and well worth a visit. It is easy to find on the South coastal road about a kilometre beyond Tanji village. It is on the lefthand side of the road with the sea to the right.
 You can rent one of their round houses if you wish. (Simple, basic, and inexpensive allowing free entry to the museum whilst staying) 
 Admission 200 dalasi and well worth it. The large grounds contain many indigenous plant. There are demonstrations of traditional crafts many items are available at fixed prices. The guides are knowledgeable and informative.
 Finish your visit in their Bantaba, perhaps with some refreshments listening to local museums

reviews.title: Nice museum
reviews.text: We came across this museum while wandering in the surroundings of Tanji. It is privately owned. The guide told an enthusiasticstory. Before we entered the museum we had a small drink in the canteen of the museum where a number of musicians brought us a serenade.

reviews.title: Like communist monuments
reviews.text: My guess is that they built this place for "once a year" parades. It look very communistic. But there is a nice small museum in the arch (entrance fee 50D = 1 Euro), you get a good view over Banjul from the top floor balcony. And there is a free toilet next to it. :)

reviews.title: Gambia
reviews.text: Visited the arch, was OK lovely view stairs were quite dark and damp as a cleaner was washing them. Not somewhere you would spend a lot of time doing as not a lot at the top just for the view .

reviews.title: Quite interesting
reviews.text: Quite a hike up the steps to the top of the arch but a good museum display at the top. Great views of the area great photo stop

reviews.title: Disappointing
reviews.text:
This is a concrete building. The inside was complete empty. You can climb to the top of the building to have an overview of Banjul. The view isn't great (nothing particular to see in Banjul). Entrance was 50 dalasi or +/- 1 euro.
Visit takes 5 minutes

reviews.title: nice place
reviews.text: not much to say but if you are in Banjul go and see the arch you can climb to the top for a good view

reviews.title: Impressive
reviews.text: Built to commemorate the coup on 22/7/94 this huge impressive looking arch is well worth a visit if you are in the area. You can climb the steps to take pictures and you will also get far reaching views when you get to the top.

reviews.title: Newly constructed arch and building
reviews.text: Great to see this monument newly created in Gambia. We went to see this beautiful arch and building at its slender. The history is very interesting about the revaluation that took place. Lovely restaurant here with goof coffee and food. Parking area also at the venue.

reviews.title: Impressive looking arch
reviews.text: Impressive looking arch and a great photo opportunity. Commemorates the revolution and worth an hour of your time if  you get the chance

reviews.title: Great photos of Banjul
reviews.text: For many years it was am impressive arch to drive around and photo.  Now that you can climb up it is worth it for the views.  I have taken great city life photos without hassle.

reviews.title: Great view from the arch
reviews.text:
The view from the arch is great and the history displayed inside is really interesting. 

Not the best thing to do in the Gambia, but worth a visit.

reviews.title: Beautiful view
reviews.text: For 50 dalasi, you get a tour of the arch all the way to the top, and an excellent view of Banjul. However the museum at the top is extremely underwhelming (for lack of a better word). Half of the exhibit was pushed to the side and looked as if no one had been there in decades, but the view definitely made up for it.

reviews.title: An adventure on its own!
reviews.text:
You pay a ridiculously cheap entrance fee to the guardian (the staff at the hotel said it was free...) and here you go, up the arch.
It was under renovation so it's a bit rough, you go through sand and over wheelbarrows. The view is incredible, and you have several points of view depending you stand on one side of the arch or the other and there is different heights. The view of the old town was my favorite.

reviews.title: A privat monument of the president.
reviews.text:
its build by the president Jamme and its his privat monument over him self. Its just a building and nothing speciell to se or do there. And the building is not fitting the in the area and to the other buildings in the area.
I can't recommend any to make a special visit just for this.

reviews.title: Arch 22
reviews.text: A nice place for a short visit if based in Banjul as we were. Wouldn't bother, however, driving a long distance just for this. Freshly renovated for Feb 18th 50th Anniversary of Independence from Great Britain. Pleasant inexpensive cafe at its foot.

reviews.title: A lot of steps for not a lot of view
reviews.text: Greeted by two lovely ladies and set the task of counting the steps to the top I was quite disappointed by the rather tatty 'museum' exhibits on the way up and not really knowing what to expect was quite underwhelmed by the view(s) from the top. Stupidly expecting some sort of award for counting the steps I was then delighted with the cafe/bar next door which had recently changed hands. The arch is really just a piece of ego massage for the president.

reviews.title: Nice arch, poor view
reviews.text: It is a very nice arch in a city that doesn't have a lot to offer. However, the views aren't all that special, as you may expect from the desolation of the Gambian landscape.

reviews.title: ARCH 22 IS OKAY
reviews.text:
There is nothing really serious about the arch 22. just that from the top you can have the are view of Banjul and is a sort of symbol for the the Gambia.

The museum is not that historical as an African, it may makes more meaning to the Amerians, Europeans, Caucasian, Asian etc.

But in all i rate 5/10

reviews.title: Ok
reviews.text: Great views from the top, but the 'museum' is woeful and some lighting in the stairs would have been nice

reviews.title: Good for quick stop
reviews.text:
The entrance is just 100 dalasis to the museum which will tell you quite a lot about history of Gambia. There is also pretty good toilet. The “pool” is just a few seconds walk from the museum and it is “free” as it is included in museum fee. I am seriously against to touching while animals and make me sad that so many people taking “cool” photos while “sitting” on crocodiles. 
There are 3 parts … one where you can go to crocodiles very close and touch them. Pool where you can’t go close to them as they are aggressive (well that’s their nature right?) and then where you can see babies.  I have had great guy to talk to and we were joking and talking not just about crocodiles but life generally. You can contribute some money if you wish to keep this place running and I think it’s worth it

reviews.title: Barely worth the bother
reviews.text:
The grandiose Arch was built to commemorate the coming to power of H.E. Sheikh Professor Alhaji Dr. Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh,
President of the Republic of The Gambia and Commander-In-Chief of the Gambia Armed Forces.

In a country that has so much poverty, this structure seems both unnecessary and ill-advised.

Tourists can ascend the Arch in a lift. There is a moderately-interesting museum near the top and you certainly get some good views over the town and surrounding countryside. However, there are better museums (e.g. Katchikalli) and better roof-top views (e.g. Bakau Guest House), so I really can't recommend this.

reviews.title: Boored me...
reviews.text:
Thinking of Arch de Triump, the view is nice but the stairs and interior is so boring... 

If you are there.. go for the view and only that..

reviews.title: Good and bad makes average
reviews.text: Looking the Arch from a distance makes it attractive to visit this monument. I don't judge the architecture here, since this is a personal taste. Banjul doesn't have many high buildings, so the Arch is about the only monument to overview the city and the direct neighborhood. Positive is the nice view; negative is the absolutely insufficiently maintained art exposition inside. Better to show nothing, than showing this sad collection. Better to concentrate the art work in the Banjul museum?

reviews.title: Life of Banjul from up above....
reviews.text:
We went to The Gambia in October 2012, and Arch 22 was one of the 1st sites we came across. You can park right beside the arch which, offers great convenience. The arch itself is not in great condition, and if we remember right, the entrance fee was 50 dalasi per person.
A museum is located half way up the arch, which displays Gambian culture before their  independence from Great Britain. Once up on the balcony of the arch, you now have a great view of the city of Banjul. if you have been to the city of Banjul, then you will know that the place is nothing special. But the views overlooking the city are great. Different stories are being told at every angle of your view, so take advantage because you won't have a better opportunity! At least the president has given the tourists a positive side of Banjul....

reviews.title: Great views
reviews.text:
You can't miss it when you enter Banjul.
The view from the top balconies is great. The arch is certainly impressive, although its design is a metter of taste I suppose.
You also wonder whether the money spent on this mightn't have had a better purpose...

reviews.title: worth a stop off and a climb to the viewing platform for the view
reviews.text: We climbed the stairs of the Banjul arch,there is a lift, and found there is a museum type of display to look around and viewing platforms where you get a lovely view all around Banjul of the mosques,the sea and creeks over the rooftops and you see many of the modern buildings that the President has had built,standing alongsides the locals humble buildings-this says it all !!! Theres is a cafe near the base of the arch in a green area offering pleasant refreshments where you can sit and watch everyday life going on around you.

reviews.title: It's ok
reviews.text: We visited Banjul and arch 22 was the best part of it the city itself is grimy dusty and other than the fish Market didn't find it that interesting good views from arch 22 it's worth a look but that's all.

reviews.title: A bit shaky!
reviews.text: Banjul itself is a dirty, dusty place with little to see. The Arch is fairly ugly but the view from the top does give a good vantage point over the city. Apparently it's not too stable so it may not be standing in the future!

reviews.title: A good viewpoint for Banjul
reviews.text:
The Arch 22 is a good point to get an overview of the capital. The Arch itself and the exhibition on the top level are not really spectacular. You can - and I recomment to do so - take a lift up to the top level.
It was built in 1996 to mark the military coup on 22 July 1994.
The arch stands on the Banjul-Serrekunda highway. A statue of the unknown soldier can be seen near the base of the arch.

reviews.title: Arch22
reviews.text: It is not quite what it seems..It was built to celebrate the military takeover of the current president... there are two lifts, but only one works and you have to pay a fee. No one says you can walk up the arch for free until you get back down.  Up top it was disappointing.. the view was OK for long distance camera shots....but the top floor was a poorly equipped musuem and and a small tacky shop. The first floor was supposed to be a resturant at some time in the past , but was now shut.

reviews.title: The trip was as good as the crocs
reviews.text:
We met a lovely person on the beach named JoJo that took us on the trip. 

It started with a walk (15 minutes) through "the real africa" were the Gambian people live their day to day lives. 
This walk was a big "eye-opener" and gave me and my girlfriend a lot of emotions, to see how they REALLY live. You can't experience that at the hotels. 

Then we arrived at a small museum where we learned about The Gambia. And after that we meet the reptiles. It's crazy how close you can get to these beasts. 
But it's very safe and the owners are there to comfort you, haha. 
I can really recommend this trip. 

And i want to give a big shoutout to our new friend JoJo. He made our Gambian vacation a lot better.
If you want to experience The Gambia i really recommend you guys to contact JoJo.

reviews.title: worth visiting
reviews.text: Very cheap entrance fee, little museum is good and to be literally stepping over crocodiles and being so close to them is great experience !!!

Panoramic View of Banjul Located on the Banjul-Serrekunda highway into Banjul, is the commemorative arch built in 1996 Provisional Ruling Council over...
Important to put this museum in perspective By today's European standards this little museum is a museum piece in itself. The displays in the natural ...

reviews.title: Nice little museum at the top with a really good guide
reviews.text: We went up there to activate our kids a bit - we expected a nice view, which was indeed nice, but were happily surprised to find a very nice and competent guide at the top too, in a little museum. He could talk for hours about Gambian history.

reviews.title: Worth a Stop if You're in the Area
reviews.text:
I found the stone circles interesting. I had a good guide who shared a great amount of knowledge about the stones. It's a small area but it's impressively clean and the stones seem to be well maintained. My guide said that it was maintained by the community and they are eager to share stories of the stones. It was interesting to learn about the area's history but be aware that the guide will speak at length, so let him know if you have any time constraints.

Perhaps it was a miscommunication, but my guide said that he was a volunteer. I left a tip, but my driver said that they are paid. I'm not sure which was accurate.

I would recommend a stop if you're in the area. I was a bit on the fence about going, but I'm glad that I did. It was something different to see in this region of Africa.

reviews.title: Stone man is a bit lost
reviews.text: Stone circles in Wassu are Okay, there is a small explanation room with photos and text. The stone man who shows you around is a bit lost in theories about numbers... he hardly tells anything about the stone circles..

reviews.title: Highly recommended amazing energies
reviews.text:
My husband and I stopped here on our way to George Town we got to talk to the most knowledgeable man ever the stone man he really knows his stuff and explained everything to you and things start to add up once he starts to explain it all to you , as myself and my husband are into Spiritaul things we just couldn’t get enough of the place . We had a good stop here and also had a drink and lunch . We did notice a lot of the tours were just using it as a toilet stop and didn’t give the opportunity that we did with our tour guide, we saw some people that wanted to learn more but wasn’t allowed as it was a flyby for them, if this happened to myself and my husband I would of been so angry as you need to get to hear the history to understand the stones.
If you get the opportunity to visit this amazing place please take your time to talk to the stone man as his knowledge just wowed me. What I couldn’t get my head around was that all of the stones are in the sun but if you touch one it will be really hot and then another one will be cold .
It’s Gambia’s very own Stonehenge .

reviews.title: Wassu Stone Circles, Gambia  - Not to be missed
reviews.text:
We drove from Farafenni to Wassu (Farafenni is about 3 hours away from the Kombo/Serrukunda, including a crossing at Barra). The journey took us about 2 - 2.5 hours. We made the mistake of not leaving for Wassu at crack of dawn, so the heat in the car was unbearable (no air con).

Wassu is a UNESCO site with several ancient stone circles that, according to the guide, are older than our Stonehenge -  5,000 to 7,000 years old (the building of these circles happened over 1,500 years).

The circles are in fact burial  mounds for kings and high ranking chiefs and only one circle has been dug, in the 1960s. Due to local beliefs and respect the other circles have not been excavated.

There is a very good and informative small museum on site (see my photos), and we could even get a cold beer. In the middle of no-where, in a country where electricity is a luxury, that was a very special treat.

The entry fee is small however unclear (the ticket stipulates one number but the guide charges more - I think for their services). It does not matter, we are talking peanuts, up to 300 GMD for two people.

Stunning special place. The stones themselves are beautiful, and to think that they are over 5,000 years old is mind blowing.

I strongly recommend visiting Wassu, either by hiring a car or by organised tour from the Kombo. There are not many roads in the Gambia so it is very unlikely that one will get lost. It is 1,000% safe, the people are lovely and friendly.

It is not a big site but I needed more than an hour to cover the site, to see each circle and to take photos and videos to capture this beautiful site. However my husband, who was distracted terribly by the heat, would have been happy with a 30 minutes slot to cover the whole site.

The pile of small stones on the stones is a sign of respect from visitors.

Last note - even though this is a UNSECO site, unlike Stonehenge, visitors can access each corner of the site and touch the stones freely.

reviews.title: Fascinating Insight to Gambian culture.
reviews.text:
This small museum gives a fascinating insight into the Gambian way of life and its traditions.

There are a few rooms dedicated to a particular theme, eg musical instruments especially different kinds of drums. A weaver making cloth the traditionally way.  A reconstructed tradional hutted Village.  Entertainment in a cafe/ resting area by two drummers.

Then went on to the fishing area by the shore.  Saw fish being smoked. Then the boats came in laden with fish.  It’s very busy with folk (mostly women, but guys with wheelbarrows) collecting the catch.  It got extremely crowded (but not as pungently awful as the smoking area).

An interesting experience.

reviews.title: Interesting glimpse into everyday lives of Gambians
reviews.text: I enjoyed both the little museum and the fishing village with its colourful boats and people. It can get very busy at the beach, but you will get a great glimpse into the everyday lives of Gambians and many Senegalese fishermen that come here.

reviews.title: Very good and interesting museum
reviews.text:
This was one we were touch and go about visiting, but really glad we did. We took our guide from the hotel, which enhanced the visit.
It's a bit rural, but it is the Gambia!

reviews.title: WELCOME TO THE GAMBIA
reviews.text:
Very interesting to see Arts and crafts batik in senegambia craft market for the Best local Guide to show you around please kindly contact +220 7647423 

Thank you for your kindly attention! 
Welcome to the Gambia smiling coast of West Africa

reviews.title: Dont Go Alone
reviews.text:
Senegambia market is huge filled with people shoulder to shoulder selling everything from sunglasses to cement and anything inbetween.
The roads are packed with taxis ,stalls it looks totaly unorganised  but i am sure it.
If you get the chance go just to experience Gambian life but do take a guide

reviews.title: Interesting to know, easy to reach
reviews.text: This historical very interesting fort is easy to reach for Individual Tourist and can be combines with a stroll Through Barra and along the Coast and several other places on the north shore. It is not very big but has an excellent Museum. The Museum guide Was particularly helpful and explained the history of the place in Detail. I Highly recommend this place for a half-day or day trip from Banjul.

reviews.title: Worth a stop
reviews.text: The island itself isn't big, so it doesn't take long to visit. However, hearing the history definitely makes it an important and worthwhile visit. As another review said - I do wish they would keep up with it more if possible, as it's likely to be gone one day in the not-so-distant future due to decay (per our guide, even). Overall, definitely worth the stop and knowledge gained.

reviews.title: Great day out
reviews.text: Lamin marong picked us up from hotel at 6.30am took us to a cafe for breakfast then across on the ferry, where he had a taxi waiting to take us to the boat to the island. After the interesting information about the cruelty of the British slave traders we toured the museum on the mainland and met some school children, then back to hotel. A very interesting, sad, happy day, thanks to our guide Lamin. £85pp

reviews.title: Informative and Authentic Experience
reviews.text:
My visit to Kunta Kinteh Island was excellent. I've visited a few slave trade sites in West Africa, but this one was different. I was the only tourist there and, although it was dilapidated, it felt very authentic. There are a few points of information throughout the island that provide some background and it's quite impactful to walk around the small island itself.

I would recommend a guide / driver as there are a few steps to the journey of getting there, especially from the Serrekunda area. Once we arrived, a local guide took the boat with us and escorted me around the island. He was very knowledgeable and answered all of my questions. I had read that the island is being impacted by climate change, and the local guide said that efforts are being made to restrict any impact. I hope that these efforts are a priority as this island should definitely be preserved. There is a museum on the mainland which is informative, but I believe that a fee is required to take photos.

I would recommend a visit to Kunte Kinteh Island to anyone visiting Gambia. I learned a lot there and really appreciated the knowledge from my guide and the museum.

reviews.title: Long journey but quite interesting
reviews.text: This is an interesting and important place to visit on a trip to Gambia. However, a word of warning, the journey to get there is long (took us 10 hours there and back through there was a problem with the ferry so might be 8 on a good day). We went with a guide to make things easier, though you could figure it out yourself if you wanted. We were staying on the coast in the beach resorts (Kololi/Senegambia). First you drive to Banjul. Then get the ferry to Barra (not very regular, maybe 1 every 1.5 hours, takes about 30 minutes to cross). Then another taxi to the museum (this leg will be easier soon as they're halfway through tarmacing the road). Then a pirogue boat to the island where a guide (with not great English) will show you around for about 30/40 minutes. Then you visit the small museum about the slave trade, which is interesting but a bit basic, again 30/40 minutes. The guide charged us £80 for the day for 2 people (including lunch and water) and then we had to pay another £33 for the museum/island/pirogue. Then tips for all the guides and drivers. I expect we were overcharged and while it's a good place to visit, and the ferry and pirogue were also good experiences, I don't think it was worth it in terms of the cost and time travelling.

reviews.title: Enjoy This Fun Friendly Farm Walk
reviews.text:
The cattle market proved an interesting experience in culture and animal knowledge. Our wise local guide pointed out three types of cattle, from Sénégal, Mali, and The Gambia. Soon we were able to distinguish the breeds.  He gave us info on likely trading prices and the keys to pricing cattle. We also strolled around sheep and goats, and had a great time taking pictures of animal antics. 
This is a great piece of a trip to The Gambia

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nothing but exploitation
reviews.text:
If you are staying at a beach resort, the drive to this place is long, bumpy and polluted.
Once there the entrance fee isn’t much - but OF COURSE you need a guide. Then they’ll try to rent you binoculars.
Our guide was nice enough but basically it’s a long walk down a path through bushes. That’s pretty much it. If you love leaves, knock yourself out.
There’s a crocodile pool where you won’t see crocodiles.
There’s an ‘education centre’ where a man will ask for maintenance donations stood next to a couple of torn posters that haven’t been replaced in 30 years. And of course, next to all this non-learning, there is an ‘opportunity’ to buy stuff you don’t want.
Then more walking until finally you get to the world’s most depressing zoo - where they’ll tell you some thoroughly unconvincing nonsense about why these baboons needed to be in an enclosure rather than just free. Clearly just an excuse to get tourists there and to have them buy peanuts to feed them with. Felt really sorry for them.
And there’s the three pens with hyenas and vultures co-existing (emphasis on ‘existing’). 
Can’t see how anyone but the most ardent fauna and bird fan (not that we saw many of those either) could get anything out of this place. Avoid and do literally anything else.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Interesting Artifacts
reviews.text: Located in Banjul is a small two story museum loaded with exhibits that date from the stone age to the early 20th century.  The museum is dated and many of the displays are exposed to open windows and dirty.  You are warned to not touch anything and if you want to take a photo there is an extra $2 US charge.  Some of the exhibits are interesting and are not seen in other museums we visited in Africa.  I found the costumes particularly interesting.  At a leisurely pace expect to spend about 30 minutes in the museum.  There is access to a toilet just outside the entrance.

reviews.title: worth a look
reviews.text:
Its not very large but crammed with interesting exhibits ,from the stone age to present day .
Its 100 Dalasie to get in and an other hundered if you take photos
Oh and dont touch anything we got told off (but in a nice way)

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: A bit worn down but still very interesting. You get the story from Stone Age toEnglish Colony. You should go with a guide if possible.

reviews.title: Lots of reading
reviews.text: It’s a small museum but with a ton of material to read. It was interesting for me to see some of the items that originated from my country and had been adopted by the Gambians. It’s worth going to and having a look about. I think it’s advisable to make this one of your fist stops whilst in Gambia so that one can understand the country better.

reviews.title: Interesting 20/30 Min Tour 🙌🏻
reviews.text:
In overall it was good, the museum part is good and very informative and the display are great( some scary masks etc 🤪)  The people are really proud of the achievements of the traditions over the years etc .. our tour guide was definitely that… 
Re the Crocs … cool to see but I am a bit sceptical how they stay so still .. medicated maybe … we kinda got rush thru it but we were glad we did as had our kids with us so no chances taken etc .. 
overall it was good 👍🏻

reviews.title: Fun and thrilling
reviews.text: Amazing time, our guide Keba was very kind and helpful at getting us to all of our destinations. The pool is run by a nice man who makes sure to do his best without governmental or NGO funding, I highly recommend leaving a donation so they can maintain their work. For a guide give Keba a message on WhatsApp +220 635 8648

reviews.title: Crocodiles Up Close, so See You Later Alligator
reviews.text: What a great visit to the crocodile pool today for our group.  Living in Florida, I know to keep a safe distance form alligators.  These scared crocodiles are mostly tame, IF you follow the guide's exact instructions! We observed their mostly laidback behavior with a few movements and a few yawns.  Under the guide's direction we were able to touch the albino alligator.

reviews.title: Very strange “museum”
reviews.text:
We payed the lady downstairs to go upstairs to have a visit, it was very dark and we had to turn on the lights as we walked along the upper floors. The stairs up there were very low, so be careful with your head if u are a bit taller (I’m 5.11 and had to duck a few times lol...)

Also be careful in one of the rooms there was a large square hole in the floor into the room below, with no balustrade around. 

Most of the exhibits seemed very old and dusty but it was interesting to read the informative boards of the Gambian history etc, it didn’t seem very looked after though which was a shame.
There was no one apart from me and my friend up there and no staff available. 
There had been a restaurant up there we were told but this had moved down to a small adjacent park which didn’t seem very busy.

Nice views from the upper floors though so interesting to see.
Luckily we had a torch with us though as when walking down the second set of stairs was in complete darkness ...

reviews.title: Fascinating bird reserve
reviews.text: I last came here 8 years ago and it was the highlight of my trip to The Gambia. This time it was still wonderful but there were far fewer birds and rather more people. A good guide is essential

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Very nice arts and crafts!
reviews.text:
Very nice arts and crafts! Be adviced, take a good trusty guide for the best prices!
You can find almost everthing nice there. Best wood carvings in town. And after shopping you can drink a beer at ALEX across the street.

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: It’s always interesting to look around the craft market. Some lovely items to barter over. The only thing is that some of the stalls need to sell different things as many of them try and all sell the same.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Go the fishing village!
reviews.text: Get a good guide and go to the fishing village, it's an unbelievable experience.  The colours, the people, the way of life.....  Fantastic.

reviews.title: Tanji Village Museum
reviews.text: We visited this attraction with a friend over here on holiday. The attraction is a little tired but incredibly informative, with a well versed guide. They have someone making things and a reproduction ancient village. We enjoyed this attraction, and found it to be educational and would definitely recommend you stop and see for yourself how Gambians used to (and some still do) live in the past. It is about a mile and a half from Tanji on the land side of the coast road going towards Kartong.

reviews.title: Don't waste your time without a knowledgable and private guide
reviews.text:
This is a good reserve if you are really interested in exploring the nature and go without any set expectations.  There is no point going there just to tick the box on the places you visited.  You need a proper, experienced and knowledgable guide with you to enjoy this park.  I do not recommend taking "any" guide at the park as most of them are useless.  Also do not go in large groups as you will scare the animals out and will only be able to see the ones in the cage.  You need to have a lot of patience and stamina to walk for at least 90 minutes.  The best time to visit is in the morning when the sun is not heavy on you.  We went during the rainy season so it was a different experience altogether.  However, the walking paths were a bit muddy and we had to be extra careful but we thoroughly enjoyed our outing.  We had an excellent guide with us who was very knowledgable and knew everything about the park.  He was our private guide, not costly at all.  If you are visiting this country then spend a little extra it will be worth the experience you get compared to others.  We saw many beautiful birds on our way as well lot of red monkeys.  They are very shy of humans so make sure you do not make any noise when you spot them.  It is a treasure to see them jumping from the tree branches or just sitting over there.  We spotted two chameleons and our guide said that you must very lucky to have them.  He got one of them before it ran away and put them on a stick and handed it over to us.  We could see it changing colors before we let it go free in the wild and had enough of pictures with it.  The experience with Hyena was great as well as this was the first time I saw them and so close.  They do look dangerous but we had a 
Ranger protecting us while we take our picture with them having behind us in the close proximity.  The Rangers will be quite supportive if you go with a known guide and that is the difference.  They too will share lot of knowledge with you.  Eventually, you need to be friendly and taking interest and then everything else will automatically fall in place.  Don't be like another tourist.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Must visit,The only architecture site in the Gambia
reviews.text: There is nice place to see, having excellent view to Banjul from its top balcony. Banjul is one store city, so it is a topmost point from where you can take nice shots and views to all city. Please, mind that elevators inside the column are usually broken, so you will need to climb up the spiral steps  to the top. For old people it can be hard task. There is a state museum inside with an information about The Gambia history. It is quite interesting/ I hope they will soon replace an exposition honoring their "great" doctor professor academic state savior etc. etc. former president mr. Jammeh, who was 20 years holding power robbing The Gambia so extensive, that after he was pushed out by Senegal forces in 2017, the State Treasury  appeared empty with last few millions of dollars transferred during  the last days of his presidency out of the country/ He even did not forget to take with him his luxury cars - god knows where he suppose to drive them in the Africa mostly without roads....

reviews.title: Arch 22
reviews.text: Very good and interesting place to visit, free of charge by the way and who minds giving a tip for the worker who sits by the door at the end of your visit !!

reviews.title: with guide to be sure not to get lost
reviews.text:
Albert market is really a must see. It's big so getting lost is so easy. You are walking amongst sellers and buyers and the 'streets' are really narrow which makes it easy to get claustrophobia. taking pictues is really hard here because being so narrow the sellers do notice you taking a pic which they don't like at all. So be aware that they shout towards you or even are taking something to throw at you. 

We did it wit our guide Mamadi from Checkpoint Charlie tours. No stress, his task is to protect and serve and even walking at amongst the fishers on the beach gave you a save feeling. Don't forget to do that too. 

It's dirty and smelly, count on that but what a joy to visit.

reviews.title: Book A Guide BEFORE You Go
reviews.text:
As much as I wanted to visit Abuko I was almost put off by some of the things said in the negative reviews but we were booking some bird watching trips with a bird guide and he assured us it was an important place to visit. He was not wrong! 
Our very informative guide, Musa Manneh (+220) 7834098, showed us a total of 51 different species of wonderful colourful and spectacular birds that day along with an abundance of information about the various plant, insect and animal species we were seeing along our walk. Although he predominantly a bird guide he is very knowledgeable about the natural history of Gambia and will give insights into the local culture too. 
It is very evident to me that the way to get the best out of this place is to arrange with someone who understands it to take you there. Avoid booking a trip with a mini bus full of people, you will disturb any wildlife as the mass of people tramp through the well trod paths of the reserve. Individual guiding is not as expensive as you might imagine in The Gambia and it pays massive dividends in how much it improves your experience of these places. You only have limited time during your holiday so why waste it by handing a poultry sum to a bumster who will walk with you but not give you any insight or understanding to the things you are seeing and not help you to see the things that prefer not to be seen! 
During our time there so many people walked right past us as we were standing watching some magnificent bird, once or twice people would stop to look in the direction I was pointing my camera lens and we would point out what we were seeing. 
A guide you have employed to take you there will ensure you avoid unwelcome advances from the bumsters and ensure you are proceeding at a pace that suits your stamina and ability, at least that is what we experienced with Musa. 
We set off early so we could avoid being there at the hottest time of the day. Musa also took us to explore an area of paddy fields opposite the reserve before we went in and that area was simply amazing. If anyone wished to book him before they leave home then they can do so via email musaamanneh56@yahoo.com and you can find his website by typing Musa Manneh Bird Watching Tours into your search engine. The man is a gentleman who will provide a car with a very safe driver and take great care of you, he speaks perfect English too.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Fantastic
reviews.text:
Visted around 11am and it seems to be a good time to go. Not busy or rushed. Guide was knowledge and good fun. A wonderful opportunity to find out and get up close to these fascinating animals.
They are well cared for and happy to tolerate humans as they are well fed. Do listen to the guide as some pregnant crops will not be so happy to be approached. 
Great local information in  series of rooms on the way in about tribes, musical instruments, and info about military history.
Entrance fee 100 D and an opportunity to leave a contribution to help towards food for the crops.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: Unbelievable experience,  we get to touch the crocodiles and the staff was very helpful and informative.  Fee entrance is only 100 dalasi which is nothing so we donate some money as well

reviews.title: à voir
reviews.text:
very interesting site, apparently in activity since centuries. 
There is a little interesting museum, a  park and LOTS of crocodiles.
You may even touch some of them. 
The explanations given by the guide on how the keep the crocodiles number under control were not convincing at all, so we remain with the question.

reviews.title: Interesting and fun
reviews.text:
Never believed I could be comfortable walking amongst a bunch of very large crocodiles, and even petting one, but I was. There is an interesting history to this place. The owner has fed the crocs only fish for their entire lives, and they have been acclimated to people, so as long as you follow their instructions to move slowly and ONLY pet their backs, you are safe.

Makes for a great photo op! And the museum outside is definitely worth a stop.

reviews.title: A very worthwhile trip.
reviews.text: My wife and I visited the crocodile pool whilst on a recent holiday in Bakau. We hired the services of an excellent  local tour guide, Babucarr Fofana. Babu's office is in a street kiosk directly in front of the Ocean Bay Hotel in Bakau. Babu took us on a walk around Bakau to see some sights we were interested in. We went to the National Botanical Gardens, where Babu organised for us to tour the gardens with the Director of the gardens, who explained the plant species we were viewing and the relevance of the plants to the Gambia ecology and economy. Babu then took us to the Bakau Community School and onwards to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool. Babu gave us a guided tour of the museum at the pool and then the pool itself. He is a very knowledgeable guide with excellent English. Babu said we would have the opportunity to stroke the crocodiles, but what he hadn't told us was that they are free to roam the grounds. At first we found this a little alarming, but the pool guide explained that the crocodiles were fed every morning and that they would then not be interested in people unless disturbed. Indeed, all the crocodiles were sunning themselves and quite amenable to being stroked....carefully. The purpose of the pool and the crocodiles was explained to us and its continuing importance in Gambian folklore and society. All in all an excellent and interesting trip.

reviews.title: colourful
reviews.text: Okay for a quick browse,( take a guide with you unless you are firm). You will be hassled and it's the same type of thing, but very lively and colourful

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: A bit diasapointing
reviews.text: We went here by taxi and a guide was waiting for us to show us around. The guide seemed to be in a rush and didn't take time to tell u something about the parc. We saw some monkeys but you can see them in many places around. There are some hyena's and other types of monkeys but they are caged and seemed to be very bored. It is easy to find your way around the parc, a guide is really not needed, so I would save the money next time.

placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Interesting but not worth a return visit.
reviews.text: Their information centre needed updating when we were there four years ago -perhaps that has happened by now?  The monkeys were engaging but the crocs were a bit shy and hiding away when we looked  for them,

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Fun to walk around
reviews.text: We walked from our hotel to this market area.  It was interesting and easy to walk around with very little hassle.  Had a teak bread board made for us and it was delivered to hotel

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Nice way to spend a few hours
reviews.text: We hired a taxi from our hotel to take us here nice little place to spend a few hours and you can touch the crocs if you dare, it’s only a couple of quid each to get in and has a little museum which was interesting

reviews.title: Be aware of pickpocketers
reviews.text: Took a guide from outside hotel. offered great information and we were guided through the museum followed by the elephant tree and the croc pool. While we did not have any issues we heard from other visiter their phones got stolen. Be aware.

reviews.title: Don't Expect Much
reviews.text:
After visiting the Crocodile Pool. 

The Museum is small but very informative/interesting history of the Gambia. You will learn about the ancestral rituals, music, history of the British colonisation until recent days...By itself this was a good highlight for me.

The Crocodile Pool itself, is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. Didnt take any photos with the crocodiles, because it didnt felt right for me.

It is an Okay way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction

reviews.title: Lots and lots of crocodiles including the elusive albino Charlie
reviews.text: This was a really bizarre experience. The guide was telling us that it was perfectly safe to stroke the crocodiles and have photos taken with them. The reptiles were practically comatose, now bearing in mind that they are cold blooded creatures, they should have been very lively indeed in a temperature of 34-36 degrees. When questioned about the state of their inertia we were told that they have been trained to only perceive fish as food, which l am sorry to say was a complete and utter load of Croc! They were undoubtedly sedated which was very sad to see and l and 1 other in our group refused to participate in such a farce.

reviews.title: Interesting but not best value
reviews.text:
The Positives:
Interesting area to browse and close to all the main Kololi hotels. Good range of crafts that make good tourist souvenirs. Interesting beak from hotel/pool/beach. 

The Negatives:
The merchandise is very tourist oriented and the best prices you can get here are much higher than you can get elsewhere. Some stall holders are too pushy - once you show even the slightest interest it is hard to get away without buying something. 

Overall, it is an interesting place to visit, but if you have the time, it is much better to visit Banjul market where you will find a much wider authentic range and get lower prices.

reviews.title: Very Interesting Market for Loacl Handicraft.
reviews.text:
There are many small stalls displaying hand crafted goods. Some of the carving is superb and very cheap considering the work that has gone into it.
There are of course many trinkets, drums, local clothes, carvings etc.
The people there are extremely friendly and desperate for you to buy from them, without being pushy.
A very interesting place to vist.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: An interesting landmark.  Unfortunately, marking the President - who himself has some very controversial views on the world.  Dirty, and dusty and not particularly well looked after.

reviews.title: Good view
reviews.text: the view over banjul was brill, entrance fee was very cheap less than 50p theres a small museum inside which is interesting, and when you come down across the road is billys bar where they sell good cold cheap drinks service with a smile.

reviews.title: Highly recommended for your excursions
reviews.text: All the staff were brilliant, they looked after us all (7 in our party) superbly well. They were informative, we enjoyed their company so much that we asked for the same guides again.

reviews.title: Interesting museum and crocodile pool
reviews.text:
Place was easy to locate - look out for the colorful wall 
It cost $100 to visit the museum and pool 
Although museum was small it had a lot of info about the music, culture, women, history and nature of Gambia 
Thé croc pool was small but interesting as gâtés were left open 
You are encouraged to wander inside, with guide to bring you close to them which we declined 

We prefer to let sleeping crocodiles alone 

The kids were more aggressive though - with endless demands for soccer balls, physical items, money and all things under the sum. 
Watch out for them instead.

reviews.title: Worth a visit if you are in Banjul
reviews.text:
We visited as a couple but with a guide - so pleased we did as I imagine I might get lost in the alley ways. Our guide also assisted us in taking photographs - the locals were not keen on the camera - but he stopped at a few stalls and bought some fresh ingredients for his evening meal - as he got into conversation with the stall holders we were then able to take some candid shots without offending. 
It's a warren of narrow allies, some stalls covered with bright sun umbrellas and some stalls in the covered market. All sorts on sale from the enormous smoked fish being sold from a wheel barrow to Sunday dresses and flip flops. Of course the usual fruit and veg. 
It's even possible to have a shirt tailor-made - several guys working away at their sewing machines at the back of the market. 
We spent half an hour here - could have easily stayed longer

reviews.title: Eye opening
reviews.text: A real insight into Africa. A must do experience for all the family. Not much to buy but great to see. Make sure you take a guide with you.

reviews.title: Great Views
reviews.text: Well worth a visit and very close to the Laico Atlantic, would recommend climbing to the top as you get great views of Banjul, for those who don't want to climb the stairs there are lifts available, there is also an interesting museum. Entry is only £2 well worth it

reviews.title: Worth a look
reviews.text: As great views of the city and has a very qwerkie museum at the top. It's a short walk from the Atlantic but take a guide in yellow/mustard tops with you and you won't get hassled

reviews.title: Great Views of the capital.
reviews.text:
Short walk from the Atlantic Hotel, great views and interesting small exhibition.#You dont need a guide for this one.
Nice place in the gardens at the bottom of the arch for lunch or a drink.

reviews.title: Best view of Banjul available
reviews.text: Go with a Government guide and pay just D 50 - walking up is easy although one part was dark where a light bulb had not been replaced.

reviews.title: Not much to see. Guides useless
reviews.text:
Went to Abuko Nature Reserve with good intentions, and was met by a guide that wanted 400 D for a tour (ended up with 300 D) and gave the impression it was manditory with a guide (it is not). He talked a little about the history of the park and the trees. Walked around paths with trees, bushes, a few birds, monkees and butterflies. Ended up at the orphanage with monkees and hyenas in cages.
Dissapointing experience.
If you go don´t take a guide.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Amazing place
reviews.text: Very interesting to see but very very busy , the shop owners are very pushy which can be a bit to much at times. Very interesting to see items being made although the fish can be very smelly and full of flies.  Amazing to see all the items on sale and a real look at gambian people and there life.

reviews.title: Worth a look
reviews.text:
Worth a look, but not overly impressed. The prices are much more than the local markets you find and a lot of the items are not as well finished. However it is a good experience and as always you will meet a lot of friendly locals! I would recommend taking a guide/driver in with you to stop most of the hassle you get. 
Good fun and interesting to see how other cultures live and shop! 
The hustle and bustle of Gambian lifestyle!

reviews.title: Banjul's most interesting offering
reviews.text: We took a taxi from our Kotu hotel and, on arrival, our driver unexpectedly got out of the car to come with us - so glad as we got to see things we'd otherwise have missed - in particular the areas where the fish catch is brought in and, next to it, where the fish is smoked. We were also able to browse at our leisure without any of the usual requests to look in every stall. We've been lucky to see many similar markets around the world and always find it very interesting (once we've put aside our squeamishness!!) to watch how local people shop and what for. Our driver was stunned when he showed me the huge baskets full of oysters and I told him how much oysters can cost back home.

reviews.title: A real eye opener
reviews.text: A very interesting morning seeing different crafts and an insight into the daily life of the locals.Watched all the fish coming off the boats before being taken to the market to be sold.

reviews.title: Interesting place to see
reviews.text: The craft market is very interesting and has amazing handicrafts. Always remember to bargain! The sellers are trying to get visitors' attention all the time, which is somewhat annoying. Having a local with you might help as he can show around but it doesn't help with noisy sellers.

reviews.title: not very interesting
reviews.text: A lot of standard tourist nic nacs and every man/woman tries to get you in his job. At the entrance you've a few fruit stalls with really nice ladies working there, without the aggressive approach.

reviews.title: Great experience
reviews.text: Always worth a visit when staying in Kololi. If in doubt take an official guide with you. Excellent value. They really know their stuff and will help you with any haggling, language difficulties etc.

reviews.title: Sure, why not. Pet a croc.
reviews.text: It is an interesting place,no doubt. I ve seen and held crocodiles before so maybe I was bit more immune to the excitement other people experienced. Still, it was a good way to spend some time and the opportunity to touch them and pet them is great. You can get some nice pics. I still keep wondering why were they so lazy, even to eat a fish, barely moving,almost all of them. I ve been assured they are not sedated, just overfed... .

reviews.title: Great Reserve, Wally Faal, Great Guide
reviews.text:
I arranged this with expert bird guide Wally Faal (wallyfaal@yahoo.com).

We had quite the adventure and Wally really knows the Reserve and his birds.

When we went, Wally did not have his own vehicle, but he adjusted his rate and we all took a taxi.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Take a guide for a small fee
reviews.text: Nice walks in the forests with plenty of wildlife. We had a guide to take us around which was great. Very informative. I have visited here twice and enjoyed both visits.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Interesting but very quiet
reviews.text:
We went on a day excursion from a cruise ship in Banjul.
The demo of palm tree climbing, juice tapping and the walk through the forest was interesting, but only worth doing on the basis of "we aren't likely to be coming to this part of The Gambia again". The constant demand for tips can be very wearing, though.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Hardly worth a visit
reviews.text: I made one of my Gambian friends take me here last year. There was little to see in return for a long walk in the heat. The guide insisted that we needed him, but gave hardly any information and neither the entry fee nor the guide's fee were cheap.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A must do
reviews.text: See,smell and hear how Gambians shop .A real experience This is a trip you could do on your own but a guide gives you so much information you would not otherwise know.

reviews.title: A must if you visit Gambia
reviews.text: Serrekunda market is huge so it a good idea to take a guide along to help you navigate, we spend a few hours at the Market experiencing the amazing sights sounds and smells never once did we feel threatened or had any hassle from the stall holders. Our guide Ba Ba I must say was marvellous and made sure we didn't get lost. Well worth a visit to see to have a real Gambian experience!

reviews.title: Good experience
reviews.text:
I probably chose one of the worst times to visit the market this year as it was rainy season, so the heat was pretty unbearable. Not the first time I have been to the market, and it surprises me every time I go. A very busy place, lots of items on offer from jewellery to cloth, watches to clothes and shoes. Please be cautious though it is very easy to get lost and with the heat dehydrated as well. The place is sprawling and if you don't take a trusted guide you will probably not enjoy it so much. It is quite an experience to visit such a busy place, but please be careful, the streets are a bit rough and you can lose yourself quite easily. I would advise not taking young children there as them getting lost could be a real problem. Take water and if you can find a trusted guide from one of the more well know hotels then take them also. You will find that once guided properly around you can enjoy some of the wonderful wares on offer, and also the prices, (if you haggle a bit then the prices can be really good). The atmosphere is pretty amazing, its just so busy and to be fair most people are friendly. Overall an experience that sometimes I enjoy, but when it is this hot not so much. 
Just remember: Take water
                          Take a guide
                          Don't take young children
                          Use your common sense when dealing with people

reviews.title: meeting locals
reviews.text: very interesting visit although the smell at certain stalls can be sickly. one thing to be wary of is some of the locals do not like you taking photos or videos of them. they can get annoyed with you. something to do with taking the spirit out of their bodies.

reviews.title: Overpriced
reviews.text: Expect quite a lot of hassle; much more interesting and better value at Serrekunda market (which is probably the source of many of the goods on sale here!)

reviews.title: Crowdy but interesting
reviews.text: Definitely a place to have a look at for the brave. Be aware of the hassling. Be firm but polite and there is a lot of goodies to find.

reviews.title: Old Crocs
reviews.text: Worth a visit but nothing to write home about, the small musemn before you go in is very interesting and tells how life was in the earlier days.

reviews.title: A walk down the lanes
reviews.text: We had our taxi driver as a guide for this trip. I think we would have got lost in all the little alleyways otherwise. He took us to lots of interesting stalls and it was fun battering with the stall holders who were all so friendly. Pity about the rubbish everywhere but this was typical of The Gambia. Put up with it and the place is so interesting. We saw school children, having finished school, learning the trade of making the colourful clothes worn in The Gambia and even smaller children carrying trays of water contained in small clear plastic bags which added to the rubbish. Noisy and cheerful. A great experience

reviews.title: a sensory delight
reviews.text: Everybody should go to this market, it is a sensory delight. This is a must visit, as photos do not give you the different smells and sounds. Get a good guide and this experience you shall never forget.

reviews.title: not your typical market
reviews.text: A bit hectic but interesting, noisy  but friendly, some of the stall holders tried their very best but alas not all were successful

reviews.title: Banjul Market
reviews.text:
Bustling and colourful ,friendly and interesting ,but the stallholders will do Anything to make a sale,and will chat for ages.
We went with a guide and were surprised how many aunts sisters and cousins he had running stalls . When we joked about it he said 'we Gambians are ALL family at heart '

reviews.title: Good for bird spotters
reviews.text: A pleasant outing, with lots of opportunities to spot fantastic bird life in the mature undergrowth. Our guide was knowledgeable but a bit uninspiring. We were sorry we didn't see crocs from the lookout point across the pool, and were disappointed and saddened by the dirty-looking 'animal orphanage' - even if they did have hyenas and pelicans. The refreshment point was a bit dull, leaving us exposed to the entreaties of the stallholder nearby.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A cancelled trip
reviews.text: I had booked Birds and Breakfast in England before I read a TripAdviser review which said it would be better to go to Abuku with a specialkist guide. The trip was cancelled so I followed advise from TripAdviser and had the most wonderful time using a local professional guide. I also discovered The University of Warwick (probably LifeSciences) have been working at Abuku for some years as part of a research programme. The little booklets are excellent and well worth the money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Take a drink with you
reviews.text:
It's very hot take some water with you.
Lots to see as you walk with your guide.
Binoculars were a God send.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Peacful, beautiful and easy to see the birdlife
reviews.text: My guide, Francis Gomez, led me through the reserve pointing out the local birdlife.  Within minutes we had seen a dozen or more species I'd never seen before and over the three hours I was there, he was helpful, friendly and informative.  He helped me see the species unique to the site which I probably would have missed without him.  Admission to the reserve is very cheap but a guide will cost you about £20 upwards, depending how long you want to stay.  Apart from the birds, there's a chance you might spot a croc and definitely monkeys.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Must do
reviews.text:
This is a not-to-be-missed experience, the colours, the smells and of course, the people.
Go with a guide.

reviews.title: Was determined not to go
reviews.text: Before leaving the UK this was one place I had made up my mind I definitely wasn’t going. However, we booked a last minute day trip - and this was included so I decided to brave it. I wasn’t aware of the museum at the start so that was nice and very interesting addition. Particularly enjoyed the instruments which our guide said I was allowed to have a go on. On the walk from the museum to the crocodile pond there’s a very interesting tree trunk formation which you can walk inside. Don’t miss it. I was so busy walking and talking to the guide I didn’t realise til I was right upon the crocodiles! I thought my heart would stop. They were laying across the bank, motionless with their mouths wide opened (this is how they cool off). There were some others with their mouth closed and the pool guide invited us to come stroke them. It took me over 15 minutes of coercion to gently touch one with my finger. The guides are really good, patient and knowledgeable. There’s a little gift shop there. I found it impossible to relax at all whilst there as I was so scarred but once I’d left a sense of adrenaline overcame me and I couldn’t believe I had braved it. Guide took a great photo of the inside of one of the opened mouths. Good, clean toilet.

reviews.title: Don’t miss this
reviews.text: What an experience! Very cheap to get in, lovely little museum at the start, the crocodiles roam around, I touched one!!! Our guide was brilliant telling us all about the crocs and it was really interesting, I’m so glad we visited, highly recommended

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: The park was within walking distance of our hotel however we incorporated this into a tour day with Abilie Jobe( his stand is opposite Ocean Bay Hotel he is a great guide excellent English speaker very knowledgable and much cheaper than the tour operators price) I got to stroke a crocodile. The museum at the park is very interesting 100 Dalasi just over a £1.

reviews.title: Fascinating Place to Visit
reviews.text:
We were brought here by our guide for the day. A fascinating place to visit where the sleepy crocs come out of the water to relax in the sun. They look very relaxed and seem used to visitors touching them.
There's a small museum to visit on the site and some unusual birds to observe within the grounds of the pond.
We could also see the local ladies working on the adjoining allotments where they draw water from a well and then use a bucket with holes in the bottom to water their crops - slow hard work!

reviews.title: A must.
reviews.text: Had an amazing time visiting this centre, our guide was most informative. Paid 100 Dallas I on entry, but tipped our guide for his work.

reviews.title: Amazing to stroke them
reviews.text: Went along to the pool and quite a few crocodiles. Texture of them is very strange but well done to the staff and guide. An experience well worth it

reviews.title: Interesting visit
reviews.text:
Good way to pass a couple of hours strolling tgrough tge museum and getting to know a bit about the history of Gambia. The crocodiles are fed twice a day and happy to be stroked and photographed following the guides instructions. 
There are around 100 crocodiles that roam free in and around the pool area, so watch where you walk. There are also lizards roaming around and a fascinating Elephant tree. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Crocs....
reviews.text: We came here as part of our 6 in 1 day tour.  The little museum was interesting - our guide explained about the musical instruments and tribal culture and then you go to see the pool which is still considered sacred by the locals.  I would question the taking of tourist pictures with the crocs on the bank and suspect that the creatures are doped up in some way to make them docile and allow people to get up close to them.  There were hordes of people milling around when we were there which seemed a little surreal.  Worth seeing for the experience but like I say, I do question the photo taking......

reviews.title: Wild Crocodiles you can touch
reviews.text:
The town of Bakau, just 12 km from Banjul, the capital of The Gambia, hosts an interesting site.  A pool with crocodiles, which inexplicably allow themselves to be touched and petted.  The pool is named Kachikally (also Katchically or Katchikali) and belongs to the Bojang family which has been administering it for 500ish years.

The site is promoted to be a sacred pool in which barren women can bath to wash away whatever has been holding them back from conceiving.  After performing the sacred ritual bathing, she is told to remain faithful to her husband and not to shake hands with other men for a year.  Faithfully adherence should bring her a child.  Required elements of the ritual includes bringing “a humble petition” of “Kola-nuts and other small offers” to the Bojang family.

Entering, I was met by a guide who collected my entrance fee and led me about a hundred yards to the pool (after I suggested that I would visit the museum at the entrance at the end of my visit).  The pool and its surrounds are a kind of oasis in the middle of the town.  The approximately 9 acre site is surrounded by trees and swamp-like growth and you quickly forget that you are in the middle of a populous town.  Right in front of the pool lie the main attractions, 2 meter long crocodiles sunning themselves with their mouths wide open (which is their way of keeping cool).  I was the only visitor at the time, but it was startling to see several guides seated just 8-10 feet from these reptiles which strike such fear in southern US States and which generate headlines when their encounters go horribly bad for locals (and often their pets) caught by surprise. 

I took a step closer, and then another one.  Then there I was, bending over and petting a live crocodile, smiling at the camera as my guide took my picture.

As I said, I can’t explain why I became complacent.  It just seemed perfectly natural to wander around the crocodiles, touching them, asking questions, and staring into their gapping, tooth filled mouths.  Their semi-catatonic state made me think that perhaps they were sleeping (though their eyes were open and eerily followed you as you moved around).  I asked my guide about this, and he smiled again (in fact, I think he never quit smiling).  He asked me to get my video camera ready.
