He said that they were always alert, and ready to pounce on food to which they would be alerted based on the vibration it would make when it hit the ground.  Sure enough, he tossed a stick, and as you can see in the video in my blog, they jumped when it hit the ground, and only stopped when its smell didn’t register as food.

I have more information about Kachikally in my blog, including a list of reasons you may want to visit and a video of how active the crocodiles are.  The link is in my profile.

reviews.title: Take a guide
reviews.text: Use the local hotel tourist guide for this very busy and narrow market - its fantastic.  Sharpen your bargaining skills,

reviews.title: A vibrant colourful market
reviews.text: Take a Government Guide (yellow shirts and a badge) and you can look around freely without any hassle.  Fascinating insite into the Banjul way of life.

reviews.title: Museum and crocodile park
reviews.text:
Great little museum, lots of local information, ceremonial masks,instruments.. Was kind if disappointing so short but, worth it.. 
Crocodile park definitely needs investing but, if you can block that thought, its a nice little park.. Guide had lots of information not just about crocs, also fauna and wildlife..able to get close and take pictures guide very patient!!
Nice afternoon out..

reviews.title: Fun
reviews.text:
The little museum at the entrance is very interesting and it was great to see all the crocodiles at the pool.  

It was recommended we visit late afternoon, glad we took that advice as we got to see so many of them!!

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.text:
We were taken here by our OTG tourist guide. There is a little museum on site followed by Croc pool. Yes, crocs are everywhere and there is also another guide who will speak to you a bit more about this attractions and will take you around the pond and let you touch some of the crocodiles. 

It's pretty cheap to visit, so do make sure you find a time to come here during your holiday.

reviews.title: Aggressive guides
reviews.text: When we refused to talk to and shake hands with some annoying "guides" there, we were called racists. It is interesting to have a possibility to get in contact with crocodiles, I recommend this place for this opportunity, but beware of the "guides" at the pool

reviews.title: Crocs everywhere!
reviews.text: A gentle tour round the small museum, then on to see and touch the crocs. Was it scary - yes! However, we felt very safe with our guide and the Croc Pool staff.

quotes: Nice little museum at the top with a really good guide We went up there to activate our kids a bit - we expected a nice view, which was indeed nice, b...
Worth a Stop if You're in the Area I found the stone circles interesting. I had a good guide who shared a great amount of knowledge about the stones. ...
Stone man is a bit lost Stone circles in Wassu are Okay, there is a small explanation room with photos and text. The stone man who shows you around is...

reviews.title: It is beautiful to visit the circle at wasu where you can spot different types of stone
reviews.text: I had a very wonderful experience.. visiting the stone circle wassu..it's also part of the history of the Gambia.the Stone respecting UNSCO..i believe it's also a holy place.in the in Gambia

reviews.title: Nice for learning mire about the culture
reviews.text: This museum is nice for knowing a bit more about the Gambian culture, nature, animals, instruments. I got a tour around, which i liked. When i asked i was also shown the houses you can stay in. They were comfortable. Don't expect a fancy place like one of the hotels in the touristic areas, but you have everything you need, like flushing toilet, comfortable bed, shower, etc.

reviews.title: A little local museum
reviews.text: Worth visiting this little museum to find out about the culture and fauna of the area. It is a little faded but the information is all there and we learnt a great deal.

reviews.title: Well worth a visit
reviews.text:
I wanted to learn more about traditional Gambian life, and this was the ideal place to go. There is a museum, a reconstructed traditional village, complete with tools, cooking utensils etc, a nature trail and demonstrations of traditional crafts and drumming.
Our guide was very knowledgeable and I came a way with a real insight into traditional Gambian village life.

reviews.title: Worth a Visit
reviews.text:
Did this a part of the South Gambia Tour.
Found it very interesting and the only place we visited that you did not get badgered.
Prices in the shop were genuine and good value.

reviews.title: A lovely little gem
reviews.text: We really enjoyed it here and spent longer than we expected.  The artifacts etc are quite dated but they are well put together and that adds to the charm of the place, and there were traditional African huts, and a wooden tree hut to explore.  We loved watching the weavers at work, one of whom spoke about being part of a family of weavers and handing down the tradition.  We also sat and listened to a Djembe drummer (they often have a full band apparently), and he was great fun.  A really good introduction to the Gambia.

reviews.title: Infos about Gambia
reviews.text: Very informative exhibition especially on culture, music instruments, history and fauna of The Gambia

reviews.title: Be prepared to have a lot of options
reviews.text: It’s beyond impressive that the people of Africa have kept traditional crafting so alive and well. Everything is one of a kind, and so authentic! MOST ITEMS ARE HAND MADE. From paintings, to carvings, to jewelry. You’re sure to fall in love. Also, everything is so well priced. Be sure to enter with some self-control, because it’s easy to want to buy every single thing you see!

reviews.title: Real Gambia
reviews.text:
The Real Gambia
That’s what we experienced in our tremendous three week stay in February-March 2009. We were based in Brikama – a medium-sized town about 20 kms inland from the Atlantic and an hour south of the capital Banjul. It’s a fascinating town with a vibrant feel but none of the tourist-area trappings and hassles.
People are very hospitable and very warm to strangers – especially those who are respectful and show a genuine interest in life there. 
Our host, Abdoulie Sarr, is a young entrepreneur whose aims are to create a range of locally-based enterprises to enable visitors to genuinely engage in the life of an area: get to know local people in depth; learn something of a local language; be part of local events; explore the beautiful country areas, learn about a different culture and exchange experiences; and to spend their money in ways that benefit local people rather than international tour operators.

Accommodation and Food (Vegetarians catered for)
He provided excellent quality accommodation and three substantial meals a day whist we were in Brikama. Breakfast consisting of a choice of very tasty rice porridge or omelette was delivered to our accommodation every morning and we had the option of having the other meals brought to us or of eating with his family. My travelling companion is vegetarian and we thought this could be a bit of a problem; nothing could be further from the truth. He was served excellent food with his ‘not even fish’ requirements fully respected and catered for.

Local Life 
Eating with the family was much more fun and gave us the opportunity spending time talking with people and playing with the children. In fact, we spent a lot of time just talking and debating a wide range of subjects and laughing a lot– a real exchange!
Brikama is a fascinating town to explore and Abdoulie’s relaxed but efficient style meant we could go it alone or have him take us to specific locations of interest.

Exploring The Gambia
We wanted to see the country and Abdoulie organised a three-day trip into the interior travelling by local transport and combining road and river journeys. We enjoyed travelling in the normal vehicles that Gambians used and not in luxury coaches or 4X4s – much more real.
Our trip took in the Wassu Stone Circles (evidence of ancient civilisation here); the wonderful Janjanbureh Camp with its perfect location on the River Gambia and good quality accommodation and food; the historic towns of Janjanbureh and Kuntaur, the bustling ‘crossroad’ town of Farafenni, the  riverside Tendaba camp and the rural villages along the country’s South road.

Birds and Animals
We saw hippos and crocodiles and a huge variety of bird-life along small backwaters that make the Gambia so attractive to bird-watchers
Abdoulie was an excellent guide with a wealth of local knowledge and contacts which made the trip run smoothly and tailored to what we wanted to see we never felt we were being herded along on a package tour.

Music
Back in Brikama we became familiar with the local music scene seeing a number of bands and talking with the musicians. Brikama is major centre for music using the Kora.

A Real Experience
The trip was a mind-altering experience into the way of life of a country with wonderful people and beautiful scenery in which the hospitality was outstanding and where we felt welcome and safe at all times. 
At the end we felt we had had a real experience and had got to know a place and some of its people in depth – a place that is now very special.

Contact details
Abdoulie Sarr provides a range of tailor-made options for accommodation, travel and local experiences across The Gambia and we highly recommend his professional yet personal approach.
Contact: Abdoulie Sarr Tel 00220-7722099/6720999; 
email Abdouliesarr@hotmail.com

reviews.title: Incredible tour and history
reviews.text: I visited Barra on a whim, not particularly for the fort, but for the ferry ride there and back. I approached the fort, not really thinking much of it and thinking I would have a peak then turn around. However was amazingly welcomed by Ebrahim when I arrived. He gave an outstanding tour of the museum and fort. It was amazing to learn about the history and significance of the structure itself as well as the history, language and culture of the Gambian north bank. a spectacular experience - this should be so much more well known and on everyones Gambia bucket list. Easily accessible and hugely enlightening. If you are going, give Ebrahim a ring (you can find his number on the door of the fort if he is around) to make sure he gives you the full experience.

reviews.title: An introduction to The Gambia and the slave trade
reviews.text:
A guided tour of the remains here is a good introduction to the positive role that Great Britain played in trying to end the slave trade. There are artefacts from the past when the fort was to help protect the entrance to the river Gambia and prevent boats collecting or taking slaves. 
Worth a short visit to the site and the museum but there is not much shelter on a hot day. The guide was informative and worth having.

reviews.title: A FORT TO FIGHT THE PLAGUE OF SLAVERY
reviews.text: After the United Kingdom abolished slavery in 1807, it took active steps to end it. Fort Bullen was part of that plan, built to counteract the slavery practices of other nations. The guide was excellent, visiting the entire complex. There is a very good museum on site. The cool breeze was welcome. The fort is part of the Kunte Kinteh and related sites that comprise a World Heritage Site.

reviews.title: A really Illuminating experience
reviews.text:
The Fort is both a historical monument itself and a working museum. Halima, the excellent tour guide, provided us with a fascinating insight into how the fort operated; its role in the abolition of slavery and the wider historical context.

I left with a much greater understanding of the significance of the river Gambia, the specific role of the UK, and the human cost. 

Just up the beach from Fort Bullen, a local educator is putting together a black cultural archive. The day we spent in Barra was a really interesting part of the trip.

reviews.title: Great visit
reviews.text:
Get a guide to take you over on the ferry from Banjul and then walk 10 mins. A well done museum  with ghoulish artifacts but a wonderful history of the terrible slave trade presented by a very enthusiastic curator who showed us around. Great views of the Gambia river mouth over to Banjul. On the way back look at the timber boat builders on the bank pieceing together huge planks of mahogany to make fishing boats. 
A lovely half day trip and the ferry alone is worth a visit.

reviews.title: A surprisingly good museum
reviews.text: The fort is easy to find, has a convenient parking and nice scenic views. It's fairly small, but it has a surprisingly good exposition and even better guides who gave us a very informative tour about the role of this site in the history of Gambia. Also, it's just nice to stand on the wall and enjoy fresh breeze, so even if you're not into history, you might still like it.

reviews.title: Kunta Kinteh Island
reviews.text: Although basically an interesting trip it was spoiled by the lack of investment in the sites visited, this is generally the case for most things in The Gambia. The government really ought to put some money into the more popular visitors sites, the Slavery museum and its exhibits were of poor quality and Kunta Kinteh Island could do with a complete makeover before it suffers from further decay.

reviews.title: a deeply moving story
reviews.text: A beautiful place with a terribly sad history. The story heard from the natives, whose ancestors were part of it, reaches people differently. Traveling with Malcolm  from Gambia Favourite Tours is always interesting and well organized. The history of this place moved me deeply.

reviews.title: Kunta kinteh island
reviews.text:
Day trip to kunta kinte island. With a local tour guard.  We offer the best service eve 
With keba ecotours gambia u get the best experience u need to now

reviews.title: Thought provoking
reviews.text:
Don't go to see this island with a big tour operator in my opinion as you will lose out.
You need the layout and history explained virtually one to one as the island now is only a quarter of the size it was back in the days when it was occupied by slavers due to erosion and rising sea levels.                      
The island is a very disturbing piece of history and a place we all should visit a very poignant and thoughtful place.

reviews.title: Worth visiting
reviews.text: A fascinating day trip around the island learning about the slave trade and past history.  Both of us enjoyed looking around although it was hot the day we visited

reviews.title: kunta kinteh island
reviews.text: A UNESCO world heritage site. Come learn about the dark history of the West African slave trade and its history. Start off at the museum, and then take a boat ride to the island itself. Our guide Abdul was so insightful and knowledgeable.

reviews.title: Roots Tour with Armstrong Tours
reviews.text:
My friends and I booked the Roots day trip to Kunta Kinteh Island with Armstrong Tours, who were based opposite the New Wild Monkey Bar on Serrakunda in Kololi.

The trip was excellent, but what made it stand out from the trips that we booked through our hotel was Armstrong Tours, their lovely drivers and our guide for the day; Abdoulie.  The trip was cheaper, the group smaller (we didn't lose an hour picking up from various other hotels) and the transport was in a mix of pick-up trucks and jeeps, as well as the ferry to the North and the small boat to the island.  We had a much more authentic journey than that we would have experienced in an air-conditioned coach!  

The journey from Kololi to Kunta Kinteh is a long one, but well worth it to learn more about the appalling trade in human lives that was carried out.  Abdoulie sat in the back of the jeep with us en-route to the small museum and told us stories about life in Gambia, before passing over to another guide at the museum (I'm sorry, I've forgotten his name) who also took us over to Kunta Kinteh island, who was passionate about passing on the information about the trans-Atlantic slave trade, much of which originated from this point, and ensuring that what happened is never forgotten.  

On the return journey we stopped at a small village to distribute notebooks and pencils purchased on the way out. It seems like a minor thing but Abdoulie assured us that having grown up in that area he knows how important and appreciated these items are.  They stop at a different village each week so that everyone gets the chance to receive these books and pencils. 

Before boarding the ferry back to the South we returned to the local restaurant where we'd had breakfast and had a traditional Gambian dish of chicken yassa which was absolutely delicious.  

Any trip to the Gambia should include this historical Roots Tour, which most of the tour agencies carry out, but please think about supporting a local business before booking all your tours through your hotel or your travel agency, as not only are all the proceeds then going towards a small local business, but you will also receive a much more authentic, interesting, personal experience.

reviews.title: Look into the local village life
reviews.text: Museum located near the coastal road so very accessible with the taxi. The museum shows different aspects of the local culture, meaning music instruments, fauna and flore, batik, ... You also have to opportunity to talk with the people over there or buy some table cloths or paintings. Entrance fee is almost free. Negative point however is that the museum needs maintenance, everywhere you look there was dust on the pictures and artefacts. However, when you ignore that, really nice to visit, certainly in combination witht the Tanji fishing village.

reviews.title: Village Life
reviews.text: This was an intersting display of the traditional Gambian campground showing quarters for men and women, etc.

reviews.title: Simple but interesting
reviews.text: When we visit Tanji fisherman village and all its particulars, the tradition of the smoking fish its also very nice to visit the museum.

reviews.title: A great working fishing village, with smoke houses
reviews.text: We rode bikes across the beach from Kololi, and were met by the fishing boats coming in - there was no way of passing, so we watched the hassle and bustle, the fish being carried in from the boats in the sea in baskets, and being sorted on the beach by the ladies, and then taken off to stalls to sell.  It was very colourful, and was fascinating to watch.  We walked up through the beach area up towards the road, passing men repairing nets, and children playing, there were a lot of local people there who were mesmerised by two tourists cutting up through the smoke houses with bikes.  We were taken into the smoke houses and the process of smoking was explained and demonstrated - it really is quite primitive but highly effective.  We ate a smoked herring with a local, who I gave 100d to go and get some drinks from the local shop.  He came back with three bottles of Coke, and handed me 70d change...I gave it to him for giving us such a nice tour of the smoke house.  He was very pleased, and walked us up to the road, and waved us goodbye.  We rode back to Kololi using the road.  It was a great visit. To Tanji village, and a real joy to see how the fish are smoked, ready for export.

reviews.title: A nice surprise
reviews.text: I have watched this privately owned museum develop over the years into a place that gives one a glimpse into life in The Gambia.  It is well worth the time to drive out to visit.  You can get a feeling of life in the bush and how the local population live.  If you have a local guide plan your visit around the time when the fishing boats come into shore selling their fish.  I have amazing photos of the museum and the fishing boats.

reviews.title: This Lovely Museum Left Me Wanting Much More of Gambia History and Culture
reviews.text:
This well-worn museum carries many gems of the history, archeology, and music of The Gambia. The artifacts cover from the Stone Age to the present with photographs, pottery, and displays. I really enjoyed seeing the musical instruments of the various groups. These precious, valuable historical items are not well-protected and exposed to air and people touching them,  The items merit a financial investment to upgrade how the items are conserved.
Very interesting museum with sculpture park in front with 5 sculptures and a mural.
Restroom is in another building, not wheel chair accessible.

reviews.title: This is the story Gambia likes to tell about itself
reviews.text: One of my favourite things to do when travelling around the world is going to the musea where countries tell something about their national history. The National Museum of the Gambia is not like the Louvre, Uffizi of the Hermitage, but it shows on its own way a story of national struggle, pride and hope. In a way, walking around here learned me more then a guided tour in the Grand Gallery. Ask your tour guide or hotel if they could drop you off here and spend a moment of your time to look around a d have a chat with the people working here, they love to tell you more about the history of the Gambia. Don't forget to leave a tip, as they will use it for the maintenance of the museum.

reviews.title: One of the smallest national museums I have ever been to.
reviews.text: This is one of the smallest national museums I have ever been to, but it was not a let-down. Crammed full of objects and displays it attempts to convey the prehistory, pre-colonial, colonial and post-colonial story of this country that looks like a finger into Senegal. The museum does demonstrate the divisiveness of colonialism. If in a somewhat haphazard and no-strings manner.

reviews.title: Intersting exhibits on the (colonial) history of Gambia
reviews.text:
Three floors of exibits, sketching the (colonial) history of The Gambia. We were here as part of a group tour, but free to wander on our own. Most exhibits have an explanation an English nearby.
Stairs ony, no lift.

reviews.title: A summary of Gambian culture and history
reviews.text: When in Banjul, take a look into this small but fairly well organized museum over Gambian history and a glimpse of the local culture.

reviews.title: Worthwhile visit.
reviews.text:
We took a guide/driver. 20 mins from our resort. He explained about the history of the pool.
D100 to get in. Tour of the museum of several small buildings and walk amongst  some monkeys and up close and personal with the Croc's.
They do ask for a donation to "feed" the crocodiles and some locals selling pencils and books for the local children. But on the whole, a good morning without too much hassle.

reviews.title: It was a pleasure to visited Al the historical places in the Gambia
reviews.text: Very interesting to visited crocodiles pool in Bakau please kindly contact for the best local Guide +220 7647423  the more you be with the locals the more you get good experiences Welcome to the Gambia in west Africa!!

reviews.title: Authentic local market
reviews.text:
This is a very large local market, where you can buy anything.
The shop owners can see that you are a tourist, so if it is a fish shop they won't bother you, but those selling local clothes and handicrafts can be rather annoying. They don't take no for an answer.
Go with a local guide, or you may get lost.

reviews.title: Monkies and more monkies
reviews.text: Every where I looked I saw monkies.  We took an interesting walk in the reserve and were told about the different vegetation, the history  and the purpose of the reserve. Because I am a city girl the monkies were a delight.  For lunch we were served a delicious meal of african cuisine and entertained with african music and dance.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not What it Appears
reviews.text: Some interesting African products but tmany stalls appear to be fronted by an english speaking assistant with the stall owner in the background. Very similar products to many other local markets. Quite surprising that the stallholders were unhappy if you wouldn't enter the stall, but often thanked you for entering even if you didn't make a purchase.

reviews.title: Great fun
reviews.text: We had a great couple of hours haggling for a few trinkets to take home to family. I was shown how to play the local game consisting of some beans and a wood carved long dish I think she said it was called Baku Baku. Everyone was very friendly and just want you to buy from them, I laughed and explained to one lady I didn’t have enough money to spend on every stall, she laughed to so a polite no thank you and I’m all spent up was enough for them to stop, but we never really felt like it was a shark frenzy we thought everyone was very friendly, and would happily go again again for an hour or two.

reviews.title: Introduction to Gambia's history
reviews.text: The collection is rather small but reading the info text will give you a brief understanding about the country's past. The only employee was friendly and helpful. There are some postcards, books and other merchandise for sale.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: Located in an old colonial building it is home to historical documents and displays concerning the Gambia. There is a 50D (1 Euro) admission fee. Visited in the morning but I returned later that day for a nice stay in the garden, as Banjul has no parks.

reviews.title: Real africa
reviews.text: Love all the colourful costumes the local women wear.locals a bit too pushy with tourists just be firm and walk away.a poor country but so many locals have mobile phones

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Return visit
reviews.text: After visiting the country for over 30 years we always take school groups here. This safe, relaxed and authentic market offers value for money and some terrific souvenirs. Haggling is a must but all part of the experience. Any taxi driver will know where you need to go........Bakau.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Almost a must-see
reviews.text: If you travel around the town, you are almost bound to pass under this arch at some point. It is very much a local landmark. Built by the previous President, to commemorate his coming to power. One wonders if the new President is tempted to knock it down?

reviews.title: Great visit
reviews.text: This is worth the time to go and see it. Off the tour visit for sometime but worth going in a taxi, 200D each to go in very informative and lots of live craft to watch done in the traditional way, We have not been for some time and it has improved, would not visit every year but would return in future

reviews.title: history of african village life
reviews.text: pleasant experience of varied history and local crafts from the weaving to the metal smith and different exhibits reflecting the way of life in the villages hundreds of years ago. Good demostrations and our tour guide was informative and friendly i think the wildlife section could be updated and the old huts where the head of the villiage and the families lived could do with a repaint otherwise i enjoyed my visit to this museum located to the south of tanji on the main highway traditional african drums and other instruments are played and you can sit in the bar to listen to the africian music and partake in light refreshments at reasonable prices. Admission prices low at 100 &150 dalisi per person

reviews.title: Great for presents
reviews.text:
Nice relaxed market without much hassle. Usual bartering skills required but good fun. Wife bought usual wooden carving and stuff for presents to take home (or tat as I call it)   
Easy to find at crossroads on the strip. 
Pleasant way to spend an hour and support the local trade

reviews.title: Large and colourful, very busy
reviews.text: Lots to see, probably not much you would want to buy, great to experience local life and ways and flies!

reviews.title: If in Banjul....it is there...
reviews.text:
Nothing monumental about any architecture in The Gambia and you will find some more interesting if empty modernistic office buildings dotted about. And this is no monumental arch of significance. Bland white concrete that has aged reasonably well.

Built post '94 to celebrate the military coup, which has now itself just ended in a mess of lost cash and economic tourist collapse, it has been largely ignored by the locals.  50 delasi get in and a hike of steps to the upper balcony, you do get a good photo view over the low town buildings and over to the dock cranes, over to the other side of the river on a clear day.  A bit of an ad hoc display of local art and history.

So an if in town option perhaps along with Albert Market and the football stadium.  Don't let your green car driver overcharge you on this one.

reviews.title: Croc Pool
reviews.text: Informative little museum about the different tribes and history of The Gambia. Wonderful experience to stand amongst the crocodiles!

reviews.title: Amazing experience
reviews.text: Different experience, touching crocodiles. We went with a local guide Lamin Marong, who picked us up from hotel , drove to the pool, guided us through the museum and then to the pool, where a keeper told us which ones we could touch, then Lamin drove us back, with a brief visit to a war graves cemetery, all for £20

reviews.title: Crocs, crocs and more crocs
reviews.text:
Never seen so many! The more you look, the more you see. Very knowledgeable guides ensure your visit is safe. There are some cross you can actually touch
Also a very interesting museum about Gambias recent history is on the same site.

reviews.title: Awesome Experience
reviews.text: This must see site was in walking distance from.our hotel,but it did mean a walk through Bakau old town which is a poverty striken area with lots of kids begging for sweets, so I was glad we hired a guy of the beach to take us there, as his presence made the journey there very easy.  The entrance fee is only 100 DL ( just over £1) and there is an interesting museum about the history of Gambia to go through before one hits the jungle trail. There is a well trodden path, through some huge trees and local monkeys until you hit the pool, where rangers will arrange for visitors to pose with and touch the crocs for some great photo opportunities.  These are fresh water crocs and are fish eaters, and well fed. So humans are quite safe, but even do ard visitors are told to keep well away from the crocs mouths in case you confuse the crocs and they take a bite. If you are lucky on your visit you may get to see Charlie the albino Croc. A good and cheap way to spend a couple of hours.

reviews.title: Well worth a visit
reviews.text: The craftmanship put into the figures are outstanding true Gambia products. Very busy market and plenty of stalls to visit and gifts for home and very reasonable priced. Get yourself a local guide for these markets to stop getting hassled. Good and pleasant exsperience.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Craft's
reviews.text: If you want to take away any local gift's, then this is the place to visit. If they haven't got what you are looking ffor they will make it for you so you could have it the next day an amazing place to try out your haderling skill's.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Good views
reviews.text: Worth the small entrance fee and climbing the stairs for the views from the top floors.  Some art and history displays to look at.  The building is poorly maintained, watch where your stepping and take care on the stairs.  Not one for very young children.

reviews.title: Worth a stop
reviews.text: Bakau is quite small and has limited tourist attractions but this place and the croc pool make it worth visiting. There are about 15 traders selling a range of local crafts - all very friendly and keen to help. Quality was reasonable and we were able to get a couple of really good deals - bartering is part of the process but good fun. Worth stopping if passing through Bakau.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Beautiful all round
reviews.text:
We visited the crocodile park with Black and White tours.
First there’s a history museum which was very interesting on the history of The Gambia, then a walk do to the crocodile pool.
Wow what lovely creatures.
With guidance we were able to have photographs with the crocodiles and learn how they live and eat.
Great trip all round

reviews.title: Highlight of our trip.
reviews.text: Loved it here. Great experience and the staff were brilliant. Highlight of our trip. Lovely museum with some interesting history.

reviews.title: Interesting excursion
reviews.text: The site actually starts with a small museum with different rooms on Gambian culture - traditions, music, war etc. Then you go to see the crocodiles where the knowledgable keeper will tell you all about them and you can take photos. I think entry is 100D and then you can make a donation to the care of the crocodiles too. Good place to combine with other places to visit - we then went to Serekunda Market.

reviews.title: was so peaceful
reviews.text: was so peaceful and amazing all at the same time worth a visit, for a tour and culture and traditions and seeing the baboo's

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: nice view
reviews.text: Grand Arch built for the president the only problem is only the president can drive through it .This causes a huge bottleneck of local traffic because it spans the main road !

reviews.title: Very Interest
reviews.text: Quite a lot of stairs to climb but its worth the walk.  The top floor has a little bit of information about Gambia and its history and the view are great

reviews.title: Well worth a visit
reviews.text: Historical artefacts, costumes, traditional personal items, masks, bad ju ju area, lots of interesting things to see and read about. The viewing tower is good for a view of banjul. Take your Gambian friends, I doubt if they will have been by themselves, I'm sure they will enjoy the visit. Soft drinks can be bought from the cafe/ restaurant.the entry fee is nominal, and is much lower for Gambians. There are clean rest room facilities. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Great views
reviews.text: Cheap to go in and an option of lift or stairs to the top. Once at the top you have great views of Banjul and beyond. There is a small museum at the top which although isn't bursting with items, it does give you a good insight to the history of Gambia. Make sure you take a camera because there is nowhere else in Gambia where you can get views like this.

reviews.title: Strange national structure
reviews.text: Interesting to see some of the Gambian political history. Good views. Don't make a special journey just for thi, but worth it if you're wandering g round Banjul for the day

reviews.title: Great place
reviews.text:
Well there can’t be many places in the world where you can have your photo taken stroking a crocodile.
The history of this sacred pool is very interesting and being so close to the crocodiles is an amazing experience.

reviews.title: Spotkanie z krokodylem
reviews.text:
Zobaczysz oraz dotkniesz krokodyla w tym parku. Krokodyle chodzą swobodnie po obiekcie bez klatek oraz bez terrariów. Gady karmione są rybami przez obsługę. W porze suchej krokodyle nie wykazuj dużej aktywności, w przeciwieństwie do pory deszczowej gdzie ich aktywność znacznie wzrasta.
Polecam wycieczkę z lokalnym przewodnikiem:
Travor J,  WhatsApp number +2203113578
https://pl.tripadvisor.com/Profile/alasanaj2020?fid=04065aa2-e2d1-4f07-b51d-c20a68cfbf31

You will see and touch a crocodile in this park. Crocodiles walk freely around the object without cages and without terrariums. The reptiles are fed by fish by service. In the dry season, crocodiles do not show much activity, unlike the rainy season, where their activity increases significantly.
I recommend a trip with a local guide:
Travor J,  WhatsApp number +2203113578
https://pl.tripadvisor.com/Profile/alasanaj2020?fid=04065aa2-e2d1-4f07-b51d-c20a68cfbf31

reviews.title: Interesting and busy
reviews.text: Go here to see some of the local life and understand how life in a third world country can be. Bring a guie or a trusted local if you feel insecure when being approached by bumsters. Most people here are really nice. Ask before taking pictures, som people will say no, ofters will be happy to pose for you (and do not charge). Some will even encourage you to take pictures of or with them. Be aware that this is a busy and sometimes dirty and smelly place so do not dress in your best clothes.

reviews.title: A revisit with a local and some serious shopping...
reviews.text: And she knew where to go, what she was looking for and what to pay.  Always of interest to me the colours the smells the bussle of activities. Got herbs and spices, house goods and bike bits lot cheaper that supermarket, cloth apparently better bought at Serrekunda, photos to follow.

reviews.title: Arch 22
reviews.text: nice view over the city. within the tower you find a neglected exposition of jujus and traditional living.

reviews.title: Very aggressive seller
reviews.text: Small market with lots of salesmen hunting  for the tourists. You can find the standard range of useless nick nacks. Prices are very high. The fruit seller women at the entrance are much more authentic Gambian and certainly worth a chat and spending a few dalasi for a banana or so.

reviews.title: Neglected building but great view
reviews.text:
We took the short walk from our hotel and paid the fixed entrance price of 50 Dalasi. Inside the building is sadly neglected and poorly maintained but for the view alone it is certainly worth a visit. The lift may not function very well as we were encouraged to take the stairs and told by the attendant that 'excercise is good in the morning'! The spiral stairs are manageable and should not cause any concern for those of any age or ability. 

The exhibits are interesting and fill you in on the ancient tradition of 'Juju' culture in Gambia. Juju refers to the use of objects and other things to perform a form of witchcraft and a range of such objects are available to look at and learn about. These are a little dusty and poorly maintained but provide a fascinating insight into Juju culture in the Gambia. 

The view from the very top of the structure is best and worth continuing to the top for.

reviews.title: One of the few places to visit in Banjul city
reviews.text:
We were told at the entrance that the price for taking the stairs or the lift is the same. Infact, the person at the front encouraged us to take the 'safer' stairs.

The place has a wondeful history of some of the traditions of Gambian tribes called juju. Also you get a good view of Banjul, not that there is much to see.

reviews.title: amazing views
reviews.text: Fabulous views of the island of gambia, very interesting history lesson too.

reviews.title: looking for an experience
reviews.text: Take a leisurely walk around the craft market which has fantastic local carvings & jewellry. You can have fun haggling with the locals.Try the local street food

reviews.title: Lots to see
reviews.text: Lots of interesting little bits to buy, you have to barter very hard and can be a little intimidating if you don't be firm. The products are usually good with lots of carvings, art and local jewellery etc, also good for little shoe repairs if needed.

reviews.title: Quite different!
reviews.text: A good local trip and interesting museum that explains a great deal of the Gambian History. The crocs were very "crocy"

reviews.title: You get really close to crocodiles
reviews.text: This place is great!  You can actulally pet one of the crocodiles.  The history of how the pool was established was interesting.  Worth a visit!

reviews.title: Authentic Gambia
reviews.text: This local market you have to see. You really get a glimpse of the locals' everyday life. Take a local guide with you.

reviews.title: Running the gauntlet
reviews.text: I love this craft market but it is not for the faint-hearted.  If you love to barter, don't mind a bit of hassle as you try to find what you are looking for, then you could really enjoy yourself here. Nice little local café at the entrance where for just a little money you can sample the local food, fresh fruit and cold drinks available too at the entrance.  My advice here is to keep your sense of humour, don't get dragged inside the stalls as you WILL not get out without buying something you may not want, but enjoy the fun, the bartering and the genuine openness of the lovely Gambian people. They are trying to earn a living, if you respect them, they will respect you.  Never pay the asking price, it will usually be at least double what they expect you to pay! Fabulous clothes and jewellery and lots of wonderful wooden artefacts to take home as souvenirs. There are even tailors who will whip up an outfit for you in very little time for very fair prices.  Happy shopping and smile!

reviews.title: Go early before it's too budy
reviews.text: This is a lively market used by locals, there was lots of food and flies, boys operating sewing machines as fast as lightening, many examples of local crafts, a guide of your choosing saves the hassle of being followed around by an opportunist who will want money for guiding you, we used the taxi driver, not really big enough to get seriously lost though, everyone wants you to look at their stall, bartering essential!

reviews.title: Be brave.....
reviews.text:
dear traveller.  Be brave.

The sights, the sounds, the smells can all be over-whelming and the hangers-on (bumsters in the local parlance) who will magically appear, can be a total pain in the posterior --- but be brave.

Grit your teeth, ignore the bumsters, and go your own way, and you won't be disappointed.........  but time it right. To do the market justice you must allow 2 to 3+ hours and in the heat it can get stifling, so time your visit for either very early in the morning or the late afternoon, and don't forget your water!

reviews.title: Busy Place
reviews.text: An interesting experience as you get to see how the locals trade and buy daily goods. It is however very food orientated so of limited interest to tourists. There are some craft stalls which sell local wood carvings and cloths - quality is good and we ended up buying a couple of articles to take home. The place is very crowded and could be a bit intimidating if you were on your own. We went with our taxi man plus a guy from the hotel so didn't experience any hassle from the bumsters. They also showed us around the town & port areas. Would recommend a short visit but take a minder.

reviews.title: Lively Local Experience!
reviews.text:
A local guide is essential,but well worth the visit. A real taste of gambian atmosphere haggling for goods is a must aim for about half the asking price its fun and you'll get a great bargain. Everthing on offer clothes, shoes, trinkets, hand made arts and crafts goods wonderful array of local produce.
Will try to force you into deals or purchases but be firm and friendly if you dont want it say so!
Don't go on your own as the "bumsters" as they are known are relentless to tip or buy from them.

reviews.title: Get out of your hotel and see the people
reviews.text: this market is a must see, it's busy smelly and dirty, it's fantastic, it's great to see the local Gambians, rather than being stuck in your all inc hotel, bite the bullet get a taxi (very cheap) and go see the sights, we found it very safe.R

reviews.title: My trip to The Gambia
reviews.text: A great place to visit if you enjoy a place that caters to the traditional family. There are wide range of food and items to get at the markets.

reviews.title: BOTHERED BY BANJUL MARKET'S MINDERS?!
reviews.text:
BANJUL, GAMBIA 18 MARCH 2014

This country was made well-known to the world thanks to Alex Haley and his book “Roots” which was made into a television series, and tells the story of a native of The Gambia who is captured as a slave and sent to Virginia in the USA and the trials and tribulations of his life.

Gambia which is only 4,360 square miles is the smallest country on the continent, and has a cooperative relationship with its neighbour Senegal, despite having separated from the federation of Senegambia in the early 1990's.  Its first historical accounts come from the Arab traders in the 9th and 10th centuries, it was then taken over by the Portuguese who subsequently sold the trade rights to the British, becoming a colony in 1899, before finally becoming independent in February 1965.

We didn’t dock until around 11.00 am, so had a leisurely breakfast and a good sail in up The Gambia river.  The shuttle bus service dropped us off in the city centre, at the Albert Market, where we went inside the market itself.   This was almost a repeat of the other markets we had seen, particularly in Takoradi, and had the same produce as in Ghana.  

We then decided to stroll around the surrounding streets and we very shortly gained a "minder", who started to point out various buildings, as I was photographing.  We had been warned by the ship that informal guides known as "bumsters" abound.  Initially we ignored him, but when it became too problematic, I told him to go away in Arabic, which not only surprised him, but also did the trick, and he melted away into the crowd.  We then picked up yet another, who purported to be from "the security" force (which he wasn’t); he had a badge round his neck to confirm it!  He also proved a pain, and we stopped at some genuine police in the streets to ask the location of the internet café for which we were looking.  Having made certain we were on the right track, we tried to ignore Mr. Minder No. 2 only to find the original guy several paces ahead.  So we then had two “minders” to ignore!

Off the main thoroughfare, the streets were rubbish-strewn and potholed.  Even though we were the only white people, we did not feel threatened because there were plenty of locals around.
 
We eventually came to the Internet cafe and ascertained it would be US$1 for an hour.  As the internet speed was really slow, and after checking there were no urgent emails, we left after 20 minutes, thereby fooling our two minders who may have been waiting outside when the hour had elapsed.  On arrival back at the ship there were many stall holders displaying their wares on the quayside and I was tempted and bought a scarf.

At 5.30pm in the evening the ship recorded the shade temperature as 99.7 F, - 38C!!  However several hours later for deck barbecue, many people repaired to the dining room because of the very cold wind across the open decks, and the residual dining room staff had to be augmented by pool deck staff.

reviews.title: gambia at its best.
reviews.text: people are nice,very polite,we ate a lot outside of the hotel&the senegambia strip with the locals.if u ask a local what he /she wants to eat its always chicken.

reviews.title: good local market
reviews.text: all locals go here,great market to get the local feel of gambia,we had local guide,explained everything,not much to buy,but great experience

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
What an amazing experience from when you arrive to see the interesting museum with local instruments and the history of The Gambia, then on to the crocodile pool. not quite knowing what to expect its surreal to see the crocodile roaming free and to be able to touch them. All this for 100 GD.
 bargain.

reviews.title: Nature at its finest
reviews.text: With a historical museum to walk through, educating us of Gambian soldiers who fought in the world war and local traditional practices, and much more was a nice informative way to start of a great trip. To see crocodiles up close in the flesh, at such peace is a true experience. Been twice now once with and once without children. Both very enjoyable experiences.

reviews.title: Good experience
reviews.text:
Very busy and bustling market, lots of stalls selling, fruit/veg products, fabrics souvenirs and local craft items.
Be prepared for the selling culture and to haggle down the prices of items.

reviews.title: Not very interesting
reviews.text: personally I was dissappointed, I did not see any wildlife except the caged ones and all i got was hassle from people trying to sell me woodcarvings. I found it boring an not as advertised. I would say go out and look around yourself and you see more but don,t rely on local bumsters to show you.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Local market. Must see it.
reviews.text:
I good market to start with. There is a bigger one in Serrakunda. You will need a guide that will help you arround on both places.
We recomand that you take a guide and a driver. Then you and the gudie can focus on the trip. No problem with parking etc.
With some tour companies you will get this city tour for free if you book two full day tours.
We can recomand 4*4 south gambia and the safari in senegal.
We used www.bushwhackertours.com with an exellante guide called JJ. We went on four tripps with him. He was very good at adjusting the trip after ours needs.
Well edjucated in history and local coustums.

reviews.title: busy busy
reviews.text: lots of things to see here, mostly local hand made goods, shopkeepers were nice and chatty, not too much hassle but bartering part of the fun, worth a visit

reviews.title: Great hidden gem
reviews.text:
Great place to visit, has a small museum with aincent masks and musical instruments together with the history of The Gambia.
A short walk and your at the pool, surprisingly small but has lots of crocodiles. You actually get the chance to touch and feel a real crocodile 
This is a charity so all donations are welcome, a few locals selling their souvenirs but no hard sell
or hassle 
Well worth a visit

reviews.title: Well worth a morning or afternoons visit
reviews.text: We had an amazing and extremely knowledgeable guide who's name I'm ashamed to say has completely escaped me. He gave us a wonderful insight into the area's history including the part many of them played during the war for the allies as well as the tribal history of the area. The crocodile park itself is amazing, your literally a few feet from them and if you work with the guides you can actually touch them. Was a shame to see a few tourists not abiding by the guides requests/rules and putting themselves into dangerous situations so please listen to the guides as they are experts with these animals and are extremely aware of keeping them safe too. Make sure you take a bag of lollipops for the local kids too

reviews.title: Touching Crocodiles
reviews.text:
I visited cricodile pool with Black and White tours. There is a little museum which has intetesting history relating to Gambia and tribal culture. The pool itself is fenced off but the crocodiles are together by pool. There are guides based there for different languages. They let you touch crocodiles but dont touch the crocodiles heads. My guide from Black and White took great pictures.
You can buy real crocodile teeth.
An amazing place to visit

reviews.title: Enjoyed
reviews.text:
Been here a few times when in Gambia with my children . They love it. You get up close with the crocodiles as they move about or lay there resting after been fed on fish . You can see them in the crocodile pool swimming by. 
 Before you get to the crocodiles there is a very intesting museum with history of The Gambia and it’s men who contributed to the war for England . A place with traditional musical instruments and another room with cultural jujus . 
The guides are very good and will take you for photos with the crocodiles. 
I would recommend a visit here when visiting The Gambia .

reviews.title: 6 in 1 tour
reviews.text: There's probably a few travel operators providing this tour and there's certainly plenty of locals offering a taxi style trip. But mine was booked through our Gambia experience rep and included the crocodile pond and museum tour. These fish eating crocodiles! once fed are quite content to bask in the shade whilst tourists mingle with them and touch their bodies. It's quite surreal and has a complete disregard for elf n safety or so it appears. The museum is small and informative on the history and culture of the country. Other stops include markets and a tea and coffee stop at a waterside lodge and a traditional wrestling match which was fun. A beach stop to a very pretty beach was some drive  and a decent lunch provided. The last stop to a fishing village was cancelled due to time. Travel was in a open top bedford lorry which was also fun, generally a good experience albeit a little expensive.

reviews.title: A must experience
reviews.text:
Yes it might be overwhelming or even unpleasant at times but to not visit the Albert Market in Banjul would be missing out on the essence of what this place is about. It is a fantastic assault on the sences, best take a local with you and get him to keep you out of the tourist section, no hassel from sellers then as they know you wont want what they sell! 
Dont miss the fish and meat sections.........
Carefull who you point your camera at though, the attention is not always welcome.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
This place is good value for money, as a small museum is also on site.
I would advise you have a taxi or take an official tour to get there as it is located in the middle of a busy local area and may be difficult to find as there is not much in the way of signage!

reviews.title: Possibly most unnerving experience ever....
reviews.text:
But really glad we did this. 

Go with a local guide. There’s a nice museum at the entrance and a local guide will give you a real flavour of history here and talk about their own tribal histories and customs. 

The walk to the pool itself is interesting - very old tree as well as flora and fauna. 

You suddenly come upon the crocodiles and the first thought is “oh that’s a realistic model” and then you realise the croc next to your foot is alive....

The crocodile keepers are excellent and touching a live croc was something I won’t forget. Which is good because I’m not doing it again either!

This was a real highlight. The animals are well cared for and are not drugged or mistreated. Definitely something to do whilst visiting locally.

reviews.title: Interesting and a little scary
reviews.text:
Before you enter to the crocodiles zone, you can visit a good museum showing a bit of Gambia's history, and an exhibition of musical instruments and traditional artifacts, it already starts good.
When you leave the museum, you will be located on the surroundings of a natural pool full of crocodiles, some of them resting around, or directly on your path! the guides know them all (at least this is how it looks) and they tell you which ones are dangerous and which are not, even those that you can touch and how to do it.
Maybe they shouldn't be selling souvenirs with crocodiles teeth, it's the only drawback for this attraction, however, I don't think that they kill them for that.

reviews.title: Crocs & A Lesson on The Gambia
reviews.text:
Yes you get to see crocodiles. Lots of them. You get to touch a few of them as well. Quite an experience.

What I feel should be mentioned is the little tour of the history of The Gambia as well as the people that you walk through efore getting to the crocs. Its well worth it to get someone knowledgable to take you through the little museum they have there.

No doubt the crocs are the main attraction but why not get a history lesson as well?

I think we paid D100 as an entrance fee. You'd be mad to pass up on this!

reviews.title: Great experience and well worth a visit.
reviews.text:
Small park area with a central pool containing circa 100 crocodiles. The guides claim they only eat fish and don't touch meat but he wasn't prepared to take the £100 on offer to prove it by swimming across.
The opportunity to get up close and actually touch a crocodile. They do seem very tame but no doubt can 'turn' at any time so be careful. 
There's supposed to be a large albino croc called Charlie present but we didn't get to see him as he only appears at feeding time they say.
Lots of little crocs around out of the pool just basking in the sun. Don't walk off the beaten track though as you could easily stumble upon a nest of eggs with the mother watching over them. There's also a few snakes around so perhaps put on some long trousers for protection.
Small entry fee of 100 Gambian Dalasi (around £1.50)
Nice little museum at the entrance charting some of the history of the area and the influence of the British under colonial rule.

reviews.title: One to make sure you visit!
reviews.text:
A really good place to visit in The Gambia. 

A lot of history and cultural significance to the area, a really interesting little museum. 

Highlight obviously the pool and touching the crocodiles! 

As always, expect to be asked for ‘a tip’ on top!

reviews.title: fasanating
reviews.text: fabulous place with a small museum showing the history of the gambia and the crocodiles are amazing to see and touch.

reviews.title: Quite a small pool with a large number of crocodiles
reviews.text: Called at Katchikally after a visit to Calypso Bar at Cape Point. It is a small pool with a large number of crocodiles in a fairly small area. 200d to enter the site, where there are a number of huts displaying Gambian history before visiting the pool. On reaching the pool a guide approached us and showed us around the pool. The crocodiles are well fed and very docile to the extent that they can be touched

reviews.title: There be crocodiles
reviews.text: As with most things in Gambia this attraction is very run down and could do with some cash input, perhaps a bit on the admission fee would help towards that. However the guides were knowledgeable. They even managed to coax the 6 teenagers in our group to touch a crocodile. There is also a small museum on site which gives a bit of an insight into the counties heritage. Overall it is worth a visit

reviews.title: Great place to visit
reviews.text:
We were very interested to see and touch the crocodiles at Katchikally crocodile pool and hear about the history and beliefs of the local people. 
Touching a crocodile has to be a bucket list things to do & we were not disappointed. our guide explained how the crocs are cared for and fed and it was a very interesting trip.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: We visited this as a family, the museum is really interesting but small; it gives an insight to the history of the country including war and politics. The croc pool is okay, not sure how much I believe about them not chasing us cos they only eat fish.

reviews.title: Dundee
reviews.text:
Went through the museum at the beginning where your shown a bit of the history of the Gambian people going all the way back to their magical beliefs up to when the queen visited and also the recruiting of troops from Gambia in the Second World War 

The crocodile pool is pretty good they’ll be couple out the water where they’ll be a chance to have your photo taken with the crocs. They’ll also explain about the spiritual beliefs of the pool. 

On the whole not a bad bit of money spent buy don’t get prepared to be blown away

reviews.title: A crocodile petting zoo with local heritage museum
reviews.text:
We’ve been here early October before high Season (Oct 15th-Dec)

It’s a small place best visited out of season. The guides have time to show you around and tell something about the crocs.

If you take of one of the locals to take you there you can stay away from the tourist traffic days. I wouldn’t wanna be there when there’s a group of 20-30 tourist that just got there.

That said, it’s good fun and a good thrill. Even though they’re well fed with fish, it’s still an exciting event to be able to touch them and feel the skin of these prehistoric survivors.

Entrance fee is about 100 dalasi.

This includes the museum with some of the festive and traditional clothing, music instruments and the juju (voodoo) department.

reviews.title: Snappy!
reviews.text: We had a great time here. The museum first of all was insightful, learning about local tribes and their tools of trade. Then through to see the crocs. There were a lot of crocs so everyone could take turns in stroking them. The keepers would tell you which ones to stay away from and which ones to touch. They were on the ball and made sure everyone was safe. Even my children got to touch them. Great place to visit.

quotes: It is beautiful to visit the circle at wasu where you can spot different types of stone  I had a very wonderful experience.. visiting the stone circle...
Nice for learning mire about the culture This museum is nice for knowing a bit more about the Gambian culture, nature, animals, instruments. I got a t...
A little local museum Worth visiting this little museum to find out about the culture and fauna of the area. It is a little faded but the information ...

reviews.title: The Gambia's weird stone circles
reviews.text:
The stone man will tell you all about the stones. Except he won't, really. He'll get lost in numbers and theories  without really enlightening me on the origins of the stones. 

Which is fine. We don't know the truth about the origins of these amazing stones which makes the whole experience even more mystical.

If you're in the area, why would you not go?

reviews.title: Bargains to be had
reviews.text: Well worth a visit to see local carvers at work and displaying their item for sale if you see something you like always haggle and you will get it for somewhere half the asking price. It's amazing what the guys can produce and the quality is amazing!

reviews.title: Be ready for an all day adventure
reviews.text:
The experience as a whole is definitely one that everyone should take time to partake in, but be warned that an entire day should be set aside for this adventure. Depending on where you start out, this trip can be very time-consuming, especially if you're on the southern bank and have to use the ferry to cross from Banjul to Barra. The ferry is inconsistent and isn't in the best of shape. 
Regardless the island itself is slowly deteriorating and the locals try their best to make it an enjoyable experience. The island itself can be seen in roughly ten minutes but I've found that the guide often makes the experience better depending on how much they actually know about the island's history. This is typically followed by a tour of a slave trade museum which is housed in an old British warehouse. The museum is informative but could use some better upkeep. Entry to it is free, but if you desire to take photos then you'll have to pay 100 Gambian Dalasi. 

Overall I think it's a great experience and adventure to have, but I think it's a one-and-done kind of trip.

reviews.title: A must
reviews.text: We were taken there at 16:00 on a Sunday just after all the boats had arrived. Fantastic atmosphere with many people from small children upwards all making a living from the fish

reviews.title: A real eye opener
reviews.text: An excellent experience for the Princely sum on just £1.00, Yes £1.00! and it is not straight in and out, Read all about The Gambia, did you know that Gambians fought on our side in the Second World War?

reviews.title: Culture meets nature truly amazing
reviews.text: This was such an amazing experience, where else in the world can you roam around touching crocodiles while taking pictures while visiting a museum all under one roof, I highly recommend this place it’s both fun and education at the same time.

reviews.title: Excellent african market experience.
reviews.text: Watch your wallet gents. Ladies do not carry a handbag. Do NOT wear jewellery. ( you become a target). Professional PICKPOCKETS everywhere .Its like Fagin and Oliver Twist.. EVERY TRICK IN THE PICKPOCKETS BOOK. you would not believe it unless you experienced it.!!!

reviews.title: Brilliant
reviews.text: Fantastic  place  to go to beautiful wooden  caving gorgeous . wish I could  buy lots and lots of things .it's brilliant  to just watch these  people  making  these cavings

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: It's fish all the way here!
reviews.text: Tanji Village is the principal fishing port and you can spend hours watching the boats come in, the sale of their catch, the smoking of the fish and the wonderful collection of ancient freezers to store the ice before the fish are moved on.  A great experience!

reviews.title: Very talented
reviews.text: Sand pictures are excellent and you can order your own designs. A lovely selection of sizes and styles.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: absolutly amazing xxx
reviews.text: my gambian friend took me to bakou with my other friends, I truly would urge anyone to visit and pledge a little donation to the guys whom keep these sacred reptiles from harm please donate if you visit as its an amazing expiriense Karen Soreadbury

reviews.title: fantastic set up
reviews.text: Excellent value, Knowledgeable and friendly guides, reliable and punctual. Had to cancel one trip on the actual morning of the trip due to onset of Banjul Belly, and they gave a full refund with no quibbles.

reviews.title: Good view
reviews.text: Went up arch 22 amazing views from above Banjul and the lovely beaches . We came down and had a lovely drink and a sand which with the locals and Billy's bar

reviews.title: worth a visit
reviews.text:
A little run down, but the views are fantastic.
The museum / displays at the top are a bit of a waste of time, but it is a good experience.
A fantastic photo opportunity

reviews.title: An experience !!
reviews.text:
This  market was manic  amazing dirty unbelievable place they were selling chickens fruit Shea butter handbags clothes food aluminium cooking pots  and everything else you could think of ! People were pushing wheelbarrows full of stock in narrow walkways full of people ! The noise was incredible but all the people were smiling ! Women had babies on their backs or breastfeeding whilst selling the goods ! 
There were hundreds of stalls all the same I cannot believe they ever sold it all if anything !  But you have to go to believe it

reviews.title: Very nice place
reviews.text:
A very nice and friendly place. Lots of excellent crafts and good prices. 
Friendly people.
Recommended for everyone.

reviews.title: Great Expierience
reviews.text:
Me and my girlfriend went it was an amazing experience 
You get very close to the crocodiles and can even touch them 
Definitely a must when in Gambia

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: Hotel needs a little tlc , but look pass that and u would have a wonderful holiday , staff were so friendly and we had a laugh with lot of them , and went out with one of the staff for the day , good ok , pool kept nice and clean by ( chicken legs ha ha ) he was a great laugh, pa for fishing trip (great day out ) and well pa in side bar he crazy and so much fun ,ok to go to town the boy do wait out side hotel but you can just say no thank you , we didn't and they carry yr shopping and tell u about the town ( all they ask is a English pound , that's cheap to learn a lot . Great hoilday all round . Food ok .

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Fantastic!
reviews.text: What a great place! Really enjoyed going around the museums, very interesting, but absolutely loved seeing the crocodiles, I got to stroke one, which is a first for me. Wonderful experience!

reviews.title: Lamgil trips
reviews.text:
Another leg  of our excellent trip with lamin (lamgil trips and excursions).

The guy who talks with s brilliant English accent talks with passion how he looks after the crocodiles.

A brilliant experience and please leave a tip as this is how he feeds the crocodiles.

Brilliant

reviews.title: Artwork
reviews.text: I bought some great artwork and the vendors were a lot more layed back than those in other areas. I found lots of examples of unique pieces of canvasses and the locals were happy to make alterartions to some of the leather goods I purchased. I would say its a nice place to pass through rather than spend a extended period.

reviews.title: Fish section - if you have a strong stomach
reviews.text: Exciting place with so  many things to see. The fish section however was a challenge. As there is no cooling, fish are covered with flies and the smell is very very intense.

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: Excellent food, great staff and a beautiful location.  The seafood is wonderful, home grown herbs and salads, good wine and garlic bread to die for!  Live music by two talented guys made the evenings special.

reviews.title: Not worth a visit
reviews.text: What a shame this reserve has been allowed to go to rack and ruin.  Everything very shabby.  We were told that it used to be a wonderful place when it was first set up.  We saw very little and were very disappointed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Doing the place up nicely
reviews.text: Went to see the crocodiles today with my family, the  museum has had work done to it to make it much better for the public and also the crocodile place was having work done to it too. The tour guy was amazing who walked us round and supported us to touch the crocs. What an amazing experience this was thanks so much to everyone who was part of this.

reviews.title: Amazing to see them up close
reviews.text:
Off the beaten track and through a very poor area in Bakou, you get to see a more real side of Gambia on your journey there.

There are dozens of crocs here, most of them down in the pond which is fenced off so you can look down without fear of them approaching or you falling in... There are also 1 or 2 up at the top where the guides allow you to go to close to them and take pictures as well as touch them. Crocs are fed a lot of food on the morning so they are not interested in attacking (or even moving), hence the guides assuring you of your safety (They aren't drugged despite the bad reviews)

Definitely worth a visit with a tourist taxi rather than a big group, there were less than 10 people there when we visited, well worth spending an hour or so there

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: wow wow wow loved this . Can’t believe we touched a croc. Amazing and a experience and memory that will last a lifetime

reviews.title: Great opportunity to pet a croc!
reviews.text: This croc pool is an excellent place for you to experience what it feels like to pet a crocodile! The place offers a nice visit and the guides there are really good. It is said that more than 100 crocs live in the pool, which is quite amazing since the pool isn't that big (but 5 meters deep and has underground cave system). There is also a local museum inside the park area.

reviews.title: Wow!
reviews.text:
An amazing experience and a must-do...to touch a crocodile is a truly fantastic thing and they are not 'crunchy'!!!
Look out for the gigantic 'elephant tree'...it's something else

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
It’s only a small place but well worth the visit, the crocodiles were so calm!

The guide was very knowledgeable and you were able to able touch the crocodiles which was pretty amazing.

For the price you pay you wouldn’t get this experience in England!

reviews.title: Great place to get up close to crocodiles
reviews.text: it is amazing to get up close and touch the crocodiles. The entrance fee could be a bit higher so that the guides can get their salary and the crocodiles their fish. You then know what you pay for and there is no need to harass visitors about donations and tips.

reviews.title: Make friends with the crocks
reviews.text: Waw! It was a very exciting experience visiting this very historic place in my own home town. The crocks are said to be sacred and believed to have healing powers.Good place to mingle and touch the crocks. The staff are very friendly and gives good info about the place.

reviews.title: Great!
reviews.text: Definitely worth a visit amazing to sit by the mangrove whilst seeing the sea in the distance. Lovely drinks and food.

quotes: The Gambia's weird stone circles The stone man will tell you all about the stones. Except he won't, really. He'll get lost in numbers and theories  wi...
Bargains to be had Well worth a visit to see local carvers at work and displaying their item for sale if you see something you like always haggle and ...
Be ready for an all day adventure The experience as a whole is definitely one that everyone should take time to partake in, but be warned that an enti...

reviews.title: A nice little museum - but if you've time take a tour instead!
reviews.text:
The museum offers a nice introduction to Gambian life but, having just returned from a 4-day trip along the River Gambia with tour company "Tour Gambia" (100% recommended), we felt we knew a lot of what was told us and/or had already seen many of the exhibits in a more natural setting - i.e. in a real village, or had seen the wildlife or birds along the river or mangrove backwaters.
So, if you have time and opportunity, I'd recommend a tour, even a day trip. You'll get a far greater, in-depth and more authentic experience, and a better understanding of this wonderful country.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: I think it was a nice walk, although it was at the end of the dry season, and at 37"C!!! We saw several vervet monkeys, the red colobus, a squirrel and an antelope, as well as several birds of all sizes. But the 1,5 litre water bottle was the best.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not great, pretty run down reserve
reviews.text: Not a great place to visit, there is a “museum” where they try and make you buy something to help with upkeep of the park. There aren’t too many animals there through the forest other than plenty of bugs. The zoo part had 4 sad looking hyenas, a cage full of baboons that looked they were going to break out at any minute and some slightly aggressive monkeys. Overall not great

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nature park
reviews.text: Beautiful peaceful place.  Some animals can be seen in their natural environment but you are not guaranteed to see everything as they are free to roam.  We had a guide that was very helpful and friendly and at a good price.  Staff were not pushy at all and were friendly.  Like everywhere in the Gambia you need to negotiate and know what's reasonable.  Be prepared to walk but enjoy it.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Dreadful place - just a way to con tourists. Avoid !
reviews.text:
Myself and my partner enjoy nature reserves and also sighting animals and so we believed that this would be the perfect place to visit.
We got a taxi there and the taxi driver would wait 2 hours. This was fine. It all went wrong after this! 
The park is 35D each which is fine but then they are white tourists coming and then the coming starts! Suddenly the price was 370D and forced into having a guide and paying for the taxi driver who wasn’t even joining us! Apparently it is too “dangerous” to go without a guide. Then after this rip off we had to hire binoculars for all the birds and wildlife we will be seeing. Another 100D! So far it has cost quite a lot more than expected. First impressions seem run down so I now wasn’t expecting much and was annoyed at being ripped off. What followed was a walk with a very sweaty guide with foul body odour who spoke not very good English. What I could make out was mostly about palm trees and the English man who originally founded the park just over 40 years ago. We were taken to the crocodile pool. No crocs to be seen. Disappointing. Two birds in the distance - use the expensive binoculars. Surprise, surprise they don’t work! We were then ushered into a dreadful “gift shop” selling over priced junk and almost forced to buy something. With a very poor booklet at 450D we just gave a 200D donation to get out of the room! 
After this it was a boiling hot walk through a sandy path with more nonsensical waffling from the smelly guide. We saw some monkeys in trees but this was it. The walk led (after what seemed like ages) to an abysmal excuse for a zoo. Hyenas in cages with vultures and baboons in another cage. Such cruel conditions. Some monkeys roamed around wanting to be fed which resulted in another attempt to take money from us. We refused. A man was trying to sell wooden ornaments. I didn’t even bother looking at them. Was so disappointed with this place. Luckily the guide didn’t demand a tip at the end otherwise the tip would have been - this place needs shutting down.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A beautiful park
reviews.text: A beautiful park, the fact is that there are animals in cages but they are animals that were saved from illegal breeders.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not for us at all...
reviews.text: I'm not sure what we missed as this received so many good reviews but we did not like this attraction.  The museum is very informative and worth checking out and that may be why so many people rate this experience high, but the crocodile portion is disturbing.  The crocs are so lethargic they seem to almost not be alive.  I can't imagine how they are so docile... they say it is because they are well fed, but I would think they would have to be way overfed or medicated to lay around as they do. As soon as we entered the "pool" area and saw the crocodiles like that we walked right through and then out of the park.  I understand that animal attractions can harbor a lot of feelings and I entered into this with an open mind but I can't recommend.

reviews.title: Very enjoyable visit
reviews.text: What a fantastic couple of hours spent here. We walked from Cape Point (approx 20 minutes) with very little hassle so had the added bonus of seeing where the locals live. It is only D100 per person to enter although when you get to the crocodiles you are asked for a donation for their food. It's all written down in a book so you feel as though it will be used appropriately. The museum is fascinating and worth spending time in each room, although is all written in English so you may want a translation tool if you are not able to read in English. It is worth not rushing to the crocodiles if you love nature and spend some time the other side of the pool as we saw numerous birds including two types of kingfisher.
