There are also monkeys and rather randomly goats. If you are in the area you should make the visit and from further afield it would be worth negotiating a price with a local taxi driver. We didn't have a guide nor did we feel that we needed one.

reviews.title: Excellent.
reviews.text: Up close with some monkeys and up close with the crocodiles.   You can touch the crocodiles.  The price of entrance is less than 2 dollars.   There is a small museum in the park as well.   What more could you ask for?

reviews.title: It was a fantastic experience
reviews.text: It was a pleasure to teach my guests about the history of the crocodile 🐊 pool where we have the oldest crocodile cherly an over 100  crocodile 🐊 inside that pool

reviews.title: Kachikally Crocodile visit
reviews.text: Must go to this place when your in Gambia, Moses is so informative and friendly tells you what you want to know about the crocodile. You can also have your pictures by them as well.

reviews.title: The crocodiles are not fake they are real. They give them lots of food, and you are allowed to touch them take pictures
reviews.text: We took some pictures and they really enjoyed it,, the museum and the big three which is been there for so many years,,we saw some bird's and the small beautiful garden,, lovely nature

reviews.title: Ok for a couple of hours
reviews.text:
My wife and I love our wildlife be it birds or 4 legged animals.
The guide from our lodge took us here for the morning.
We visited the large hide and got some great sightings.
There is a shop where you can buy T shirts and other small items, also nearby is a European type toilet, which is clean(ish).
The walk through the forest was easy and most of the pathways fairly wide.
It's then that you get to see the green vervet monkeys. Most stay still long enough for a photograph.
At the end is a very sad and neglected 'zoo'.
A couple of stir crazy hyenas, an adult baboon with a couple of youngsters and some vultures.
In Europe this would have been closed down.
There is a small cafe and some very smelly toilets.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nothing there now
reviews.text: Been before and was great. Now sadly neglected.  Only hyenas and vultures now. Still a nice walk through forest and a few monkeys to be seen if you are lucky. Only 35 dalasi  to enter and no pressure to take a guide so cannot complain.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: Great place to visit but make sure you take water as it gets quite hot as you are walking through. The monkeys are tame, however, they can become aggressive when you are feeding them and the food runs out. Be careful with young children

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Distressed animals
reviews.text:
The reserve consists of a fairly narrow strip of land with paths meandering through it. We didn't see much bird life but it's probably there. We did see a few monkey, but not many.
Sadly the "zoo" at the far end has an air of dilapidation or down right abandonment. There are hyena incases that look distressed, one of them just lying there constantly rubbing his muzzle with his forelegs. There were no staff seen at anytime except at the entrance gate. We were glad to leave.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Rather sad to see.
reviews.text: A long trip for not very much.  Such a sad place - yes, there were lots of birds around, but the rewards of seeing and hearing these were more than overcome by the mangy hyaenas (in the same pen as), vultures etc.  I think in a ThirdWorld country this Reserve would be closed down forthwith.  The monkeys were interesting, the cages with reasonable labelling etc.  But, overall, don't waste your time and money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A good guide is a must
reviews.text: We came here with a guide from our guesthouse, but he only guided us through some paths so we didn't see too much. The park itself is a nice place to see birds and monkeys (we saw more monkeys here than at Bijilo park), I would had liked to stay longer and with a better guide, definitely the park worth it.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Birds galore!
reviews.text: We visited this nature reserve as part of a birding holiday in The Gambia. We had our own birdguide, Mas Sangeng, arranged by Farakunku Lodges where we were based, however there are guides available to hire at the reserve. Our guide was excellent and we would not have seen half the birds and wildlife without him. The area around the crocodile pool was a bit noisey, some boats were being taken on to the pond and this disturbed any birds there. Green Vervet Monkeys played around the benches and seemed used to visitors. It was further along the pathways we started to encounter the more interesting birds,  Green and Violet Turaco, Western Bluebill and African Paradise Flycatcher to name just a few.  With patience and a good guide the possibilities are endless.  We had no interest in visiting the "zoo" preferring to spend our time looking for birds and we were not disappointed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A nice walk, but not much else . . .
reviews.text:
Situated on the side of the airport road to Serekunda and the beach resorts, the park is easily reached by taxi from most hotels, and is an ideal ‘on your own’ half day out when you have exhausted your tour operators organised trip portfolio.

The self-appointed title ‘Nature Reserve’ does however raise the expectations of the first time visitor, which are unlikely to be met, hence the string of negative reviews.
On arrival, first stop is the ticket hut, where you are relieved of a modest 35 Dalasi each . . . so far so good. You are then directed to an open hut where several ‘guides’ are waiting. We told them we had been before and were happy to go unaccompanied; the reply is ‘snakes sir; lots of snakes . . . if you don’t know where to look, very dangerous’.
The guides were all wearing combat trousers tucked into high laced army boots while I was wearing M&S linen shorts with a pair of Reeboks; I figured they may well have a point.
In an act of extortion that The Peaky Blinders would be proud of, we were instantly relieved of a further 300D, but they had not finished yet . . . ‘you will need binoculars’ they tell us, and whoosh, another 100 changes hands.
What follows is in essence a very nice walk following a well worn path through shady and peaceful woodland, a few birds along the way but nothing you won’t see around your hotel, an army of ants crossing the path, some epic spider’s webs, but not much else.
Next stop is the natural lake containing several hard to spot crocs; you are led up wooden steps to an observation platform which doubles up as a gift shop; another hard sell along the lines of ‘the park runs on donations and what the tourists spend’;  we were in need of a few trinkets for nieces back home, but sadly the variety of gifts was on par with the variety of wildlife, and we escaped wallet intact and empty handed.
Another meandering walk with more of the same; 20 years ago, the path was lined with monkeys, eager to be fed with the bananas that were sold at the entrance; no bananas this time, and no monkeys; there is now a snack stall at the enclosures, and the monkeys learned very quickly that simply hanging around here will keep them well fed with the minimum effort.
They have however become very spiteful and greedy, and will quickly snatch the newly purchased bag of monkey nuts from your hand. The photo opportunities are there, if not a little predictable and staged, and short of a few hyenas in a large pen not much else here to detain you.
Exit is via another walk along another path, and is a different place to your drop-off, but your taxi driver will know this and be waiting for you. A gift shop is at the exit, giving another couple of desperate women one last opportunity to mug you before you disappear forever. The guide then hints heavily that he is not paid and relies on tips; you say I have already paid 300, he says yes but I don’t get that, we part with one final 200 for the guide and find our taxi.
We asked our driver to stop off at Lamin Lodge on the way back for a lunch break; we then detoured back via the pharmacy for a few bits, then the mini market for a few more; all in all, a good half day away from resort, but a nice shady walk only; no more, no less.
Hugely overpriced for what it is; (we spent 670D plus cokes and monkey nuts); better opportunities locally to resort for both monkeys and crocs, and at a fraction of the price.
Don’t expect too much; don’t bother with binoculars, and ditch the guide if you can.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Don't bother coming from the beach resorts
reviews.text: I happened to be staying nearby waiting for a flight so spent the morning walking around the reserve. Don't expect to see any wildlife except birds and a couple of monkeys. The animal "orphanage" is really depressing and the guides let a tourist get in the enclosure with two hyenas which makes me think they have no idea how to deal with and treat animals. I only gave two stars because the forest itself is quite nice to walk around and I came with low expectations but I had the opportunity of taking a day trip from one of the beach resorts earlier in my holiday and I'm really glad I didn't

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Absolutely awful
reviews.text:
I went there with a friend last week ( 2/12/17)
We went equipped with a book of birds, binoculars, 'ít aint half hot' outfits etc expecting to see wild birds in their natural habitats etc.
There were no birds at all.
 Only a few baboons and a couple of wolves like creatures  in cages and that, as they say, was that.
This is a classic case of a really good bloke who had a dream once that was realised and when it was created and nurtured, it must have been fabulous.
Now, it is a ghost town birdwatching place with no birds but just bumsters having taken over what was once probably something worth seeing.
Don't go.
There is nothing here to see.
The local chancers have taken what's left of a dream over and the place is a shell.
There is nothing to see. 
Really. 

Don't waste your money.
Don't do it.
This is a vacuous dump.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Dubious interest to a casual tourist
reviews.text:
I've visited this site several times in search of birds.  Whilst home to many species (some of them very rare) they are not easy to see in the forest, and I'm not convinced that this is a location that a casual tourist would enjoy.  If you do go, make sure you take your insect repellent!

The "animal orphanage" is a central element of most visits, but the conditions under which the animals and birds are kept are really depressing.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Wonderful forest to walk through
reviews.text:
Abuko nature reserve isn’t like the big safari parks.

There isn’t any big wildlife here but there’s plenty other stuff to see and check out.

The walk itself takes about a good hour and it’s best to bring water and avoid the high noon. 
We saw some of the big lizards, monkeys and beautiful spiders. It is said there are some cobra an python snakes as well in the area but you’ll have to be lucky.

Halfway the walk there is this big tree with vultures. Loads of them sitting there. Best not stand underneath them too long...😁

The Hyena’s aren’t there anymore and neither the crocodile. They have been replaced.

As it is with nature parks...you can be really lucky, or really out of luck.

With an entrance fee of 40 dalasi each it’s worth a shot!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Birdwatching with Mustapha Barry
reviews.text:
One of the first trips i made was Abuko nature park. I was with Mustapha Barry,birdwatching guide, i was amazed by his knowledge about birds and nature,
We had a nice walk and he spotted the most butifull birds like the violet and green Turaco, red-billes Hornbill,swallow-tailed Bee-eater and many more.
Also differend kind of monkeys . It was a very nice experience especially to do it with Mustapha Barry and i can recommend him as being honest,reliable and driver with his own 4x4 car. You can contact him at Kotu Bridge or by telephone (+220) 7165867

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nice forest but sad caged animals
reviews.text:
The forest itself is a nice and peaceful place where you can see some animals in their natural habitat. Even some rare elusive red monkeys may be seen. You can spend a relaxing hour or two walking the trails and listening the nature.

However, there are some caged animals, such as hyenas and baboons, where the trails start. They didn't seem to be doing very well and had very small space to move around in their cages.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text:
When we first got there the guy behind the desk was so ignorant and wouldn't answer us and when he did he had such a bad attitude. 

Went around the park with a guide, very long walk, saw a few monkeys but he only really showed us trees and termite mounds, didn't see no birds, snakes or crocs.

He took us to the baboons and explained they are in cages as they are violent...
Went to see the large vulture that flew down from its perch to us, loads of other vultures flying about in the area. 
Went inside the hyenas den which was definitely an experience especially when they started walking towards us and wanting us to rub them like dogs and trying to play. I didn't know hyenas could be friendly!!

Then on leaving the park there is a massive hippos head on display, the guide said they killed the hippo as he was eating the locals rice fields, told him it's cruel and sick for keeping the head on display, he didn't agree....
 
The park has potential to be better and house more animals as it did a few years back but they need to make sure animals are taken care of and I don't think tourists will appreciate seeing a rotting hippo head!!

Apart from that, nice few hours out and a lot of walking.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Stunning bird life
reviews.text:
West African Reserves are not to be compared with the Wild Parks of  East Africa or
Botswana. The main attraction of Abuko are the rare Red Colobus Ape and the truly stunning birdlife, so the best thing to do is to stroll the Reserve accompanied by a good bird guide. There are two hides available for birders.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not many animals!
reviews.text: We had a nice walk round the park, but did not see any animals, and not many birds. Maksutu Cultural Forest or the monkey park near Senegambia were more fun.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Caged animals in awful conditions
reviews.text:
The 'protected' forest itself is very disappointing and most of the animals have left, bar a few monkeys. We walked through the forest with a guide but there really was nothing to point out. At the end you come to a 'rescue' centre. There are caged vultures, monkeys, tortoise, pelicans (all in one cage) and loads of uncastrated hyenas in others. 
Not a nice experience at all and sadly the 'staff' couldn't understand why we thought it was cruel and that this wasn't something that tourists wanted to see.
Very sad! Please don't visit!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Interesting place
reviews.text: This place is beautiful if your after a sedate but long nature walk with lots of birds and monkeys. The animal orphanage needs some tlc and some education on environment and animal rehabilitation but they are making the best of a bad job! It is worth a visit especially if you see the endangered west red colobus monkeys.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Amazing monkeys
reviews.text: Great place to visit although quite a long walk. The monkeys are wonderful to see but the other animals in the cages don't seem quite as happy although still well looked after.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: An Amazing Area of African Forest Close to Banjul
reviews.text: This nature preserve/research station/wild animal rehabilitation site is a must visit for anyone interested in the natural history of Gambia.  The trails are safe and easy to follow, but be careful not to stop on/near a stream of ants on the move.  Local experts are available to guide birders and further information is available at the observation deck of the Darwin Research Station.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Day trip
reviews.text: Beautiful place to visit for young and young at heart, monkeys were amazing, a little greedy but very friendly 😁

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A simple forest reserve
reviews.text: You can see only voltures and Monkeys and a few hyaenas. It may be a good idea to take a walk with a guide. It is a different place in the Gambia.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A nice place to walk but I don't want to see anyone in cages
reviews.text:
Most of the Abuko park is nice and the monkeys are free, but there's also a part where they keep some monkeys and even an eagle in cages! The cages are too small and they do not seem to have a nice and happy life. I don't think that such intelligent creatures should be held in a prison and it made me sad to see that.

But if you skip the zoo part you might enjoy it, because it's a really nice place for a walk. They don't want to let you go inside without a local guide, but don't mind them, you won't get lost! If you get a guide, you need to pay for the entrance fee and also some tip to the guide - not worth it. You'll see the monkeys and lots of birds anyway :)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nothing outstanding but a nice nature walk
reviews.text:
We visited this park along with Lamin Lodge on a tour from Kololi. 

They insisted we paid for a tour guide to take us through the park, the guide was very uninformative, not really talking to us or telling us about the park but simply trying to get around as quickly as possible the forcibly asking for a large tip. It would have been much nicer to simply take our time and wonder through the reserve.

It was generally a pretty reserve and we did see some green vervet monkeys who were quite happy to have their photo taken but if this is what you are looking for then Bijilo park is a much better nature park with more monkeys and just as nice/nicer scenery.

There were Baboons and Hyenas in cages in one section but I tend not to like seeing animals unnecessarily in cages so did not find this an enjoyable part of the park. They had also had a hippo there which had died recently and they kept its head on display (not pleasant to look at!)   

We had a nice day but I didn't think this park and any advantages over Bijilo

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great Photo opportunities
reviews.text: We visited Abuko as part of trip with Arch tours and really enjoyed it, great photo opportunities for bird watching and general wildlife.  We saw loads of different birds including a giant kingfisher. At the end of the trail is a small zoo area which has baboons and Hyenas, however this is not best part of reserve.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Go see the crocodile
reviews.text:
Lovely place  But make no mistake these listen to your guide if you want to touch them I did and must admit my heart was racing 
But well worth going to see them up close

reviews.title: Don't Shed Tears for These Crocodiles
reviews.text: Over a dozen crocodiles laying al around the pool, mostly sleeping.  You get to walk a path with your guide around the place when suddenly you notice there is no fence between you and those crocodiles about 4 feet away.  Luckily, only a few are moving and you are really glad they were fed earlier in the day.  I would question your fitness as a parent if you brought your kiddos on your visit.  Just remember if you want to touch one (and people do) touch the crocodile as far away from its mouth as possible.  If you love Komodo Island and its free roaming dragons you will like this place.

reviews.title: Fantastic experience
reviews.text: This was my 2nd visit to Katchikally Crocodile Pool once again it was a remarkable wondrous experience. We went quite late in the day plus it was ramadan time so it was very quiet. We were the only people there. There was a 200 delacies entrance fee. Before going to see the crocodiles there is a small museum we walked around which consisted of 3 rooms with information  about the area , pictures and a few historical artefacts. The whole way round we were accompanied by a cat. He literally walked everywhere with us until we got to the exit of the rooms. Instinctively the cat stopped at the door and left us to continue out towards the crocodiles. She obviously knew not to go out there around the crocodiles, we stopped at a very ver old massive cotton tree on the way towards the crocodiles. The young man who cared for the crocodiles were so informative and put us at ease as when we got out towards the crocodiles. On this occasion, there were plenty of them out on the land. We counted at least 12 crocodiles amongst leaves and against the trees. This was a scarily wonderful experience to be this close to the crocodiles, we even saw the albino crocodile which was so big. The young man showed us the crocodile eggs and told us about the crocodiles. We made a small donation towards feeding the crocodiles as they must go through a large amount of fish to keep them going. This was a fantastic experience. Definitely not for the faint hearted.

reviews.title: Pool of Crocs
reviews.text:
Located about 30 minutes from Banjul, in the Bakau district, is the Kachikally Sacred Crocodile Pool believed by the locals for its healing powers and as a place of last resort for infertile women who wish to conceive.  the women seeking the special blessing are washed by trained women and are told not to shake hands with anyone in Bakau. Others with ailments come to the pool to seek luck and make offers to the crocs in return.  The walk to the pool is reached from the mail road by a 600-meter dirt pathway that is lined by poverty-stricken housing and dozens of young children approaching you asking for money or school supplies.

The  entrance wall is colorfully painted with wildlife scenes. Once inside, you walk on a path towards the pool where it is said that there are over 80 crocodiles in and around the pool  but we only saw four small crocks. The well-fed crocs are docile.  Visitors are allowed to touch or stroke the tail--not the head.  

Expect to spend about 30 minutes in the facility.  Other than the few crocs there is not much to see.  Worth a visit if you are in the area but otherwise not much to see although it is described as a popular tourist site.  At the end of the tour the owner requests "donations" to feed the crocs.

reviews.title: Lots of Crocs!
reviews.text:
Yes this is good to do if staying in the area, but you will need a taxi to get there. The park itself is off the main highway and at the bottom of a very local impoverished area.
Entrance fee is 100 dalasi per adult (guides/ drivers free). You do not need a guide for this attraction. 
There’s a very small museum beside the park, a very short walk to the crocodile pool and that is all there is. 
You can “stroke” the albino crocodile, see others lying around in the sun and there’s opportunity  to make a donation towards the cost of feeding them. Allow 30-45 mins max for this attraction. 

Truthfully the poverty on the streets surrounding the park was more of an experience and impacting than seeing the crocodiles but that’s the reality of living in The Gambia….for some life is very hard.

reviews.title: Poor quality zoo with some wild monkeys.
reviews.text:
Situated just outside town this reserve is said to host “displaced” animals in an attempt to help preserve Gambias wildlife.  There are plenty of sightings of Vervet Monkeys which are well habituated to humans (they can be very amusing)  and some Red Colobus Monkeys are also present.  

But essentially it’s really just a small open air zoo.  A troop of Baboons is kept in a fairly spacious enclosure,  with a couple of cages Hyena nearby to the drinks stall.
People tell of ongoing improvement work,  but there was no sight of actual improvement on the ground since 2012,  and considerable degradation since that visit.

Worth a visit  -  I don’t think so.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nice walk
reviews.text: Visited here with my gambian boyfriend, my son and another couple. I thought it was a really nice walk and plenty of animals to see. I particularly liked the fact that the majority of them were free to roam around.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Excellent place to  see birds, crododiles and small mammals
reviews.text: If you like nature, this is a must see in Gambia. In particular the view point on the little lake was marvellous with its many birds and crocodiles. We saw several monkeys. There are fierce looking hyenas in a separate fenced area.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A lot has changed in a year
reviews.text: The park was a good day out last year with hyena, cheetahs, a lion cub and monkeys, however in the past year both cheetahs and the lion cub have died raising my concerns. The monkeys and hyenas are still nice to see though

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great for bird watching
reviews.text: Hundred of birds to chase with a camera and tripod or a telescope. You are welcomed by monkeys then as you walk trough the forest, you can enjoy the beauty of the jungle as it is, with birds and lizards and butterflies and crocs. You definitely need a good guide, not for not getting lost but for information about the birds, trees and everything.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Perhaps Not A Fair Review
reviews.text: A taxi driver took me here recently only to be told when we arrived that the place was closed. He was surprised to hear this. However, I spoke a few days later with a different, experienced taxi driver that I have done a lot of business with, and he explained to me that many of the animals that had been there had died, which is why they had to close their doors. I am not sure what happened and I am not sure when they will be opening again but I thought I would post the information I was give here for other people who might be planning to visit Abuko.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text:
Lovely walks through forest,  chance to see Crocs in the Lake, and in the centre they had free roaming monkeys who came and happily took peanuts from your hands, and anything in your pockets was lovely. My best experience was befriending a young baboon there, he was very friendly and affectionate and was a delight seeing him playing with the other Monkeys. They had hyenas there, vultures and a little place to get a bite to eat. Easily spend a couple of hours there. 
You can take a guide or go in on your own,  easy to find your way around doing it alone. 
Truly loved it!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Money scam
reviews.text:
I had an experience very similar to that of zippideedoodle below.

My group and I (consisting of Gambians and Europeans interested in conservation and wildlife) had wanted to explore the park freely for the local wild nature.  We were pressured into hiring a guide who was not overall very informative but did point out some different species, 

The guided then took us out a side gate to Eagle Heights, without informing us this is what was happening. He wanted us to pay another guided to show us some of the animals they have there  - an experience we didn't even want. We did not pay and got walked back along the road to the entrance of the nature reserve. 

It could have been a very different experience.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: monkey park - fab
reviews.text: went for a day at the monkey park.  You aren't supposed to feed the monkeys but our guide got us bags of nuts.  the monkeys jump on your shoulders and take the nuts out of your hand.  very friendly and cute. well worth a visit there.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Good walk round but beware that the English owners charge europeans more for entry.
reviews.text: Visited in Feb 2015 and enjoy Abuko very much having a walk round and feeding the monkeys. Seeing the lion was nice as was the birds and snakes all in all was worth the money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Like and big park
reviews.text:
For many years ago it was a nice place where they had names on evert special trees and there were so many different animals there, but now I'm disappointed because it's mostly apes and births there now day. It's like the forgotten place where they just send tourists for having anything to do.
If you want to go there take your time early in the morning or around 6 in the evening. Then you will have a chance to se some of the animals.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nice experience
reviews.text: A local taxi driver drove us to the place - the museum is very small, but the things on display are quite interesting. The pool itself and the opportunity to touch a crocodile - quite unique. The guys at the pool took good care that everyone had a chance to take a picture with an albino crocodile in a safe and organised manner. In general, a place to visit if you want to look the croc in the face :)

reviews.title: Educational visit to a well managed and inexpensive nature site.
reviews.text:
After paying 100 dalasi each, we passed the small museum walking along a smooth shaded lane to the pool entrance.  Here we were met by the middle aged caretaker who gave us a 15 minute tour that included touching the back of a well fed male albino crocodile who was resting peacefully among 15 more of normal color. He showed a video of their morning feeding, tossing plump fish from a full wheelbarrow as the crocs emerged from the pool in increasing numbers. He then guided us along the pool trail pointing out the unapproachable aggressive females and several semi submerged crocs among the 80 that live around this pool. 
Further along, we stopped to admire an old Kapok with huge buttress roots when a monkey appeared that was nursing babies. Finally we were shown a rice field(matured at the end of the wet season) soon to be harvested and prepared for planting dry season vegetables. 
Before departing, we signed a book to make a small contribution to feeding the crocs.  
Delightful ½ hour visit.

reviews.title: Close up experience
reviews.text: If you have never been close to animals like these before it's probably a life times experience for you, although they are so well fed they are not very active but it is possible to touch them which gives most people a thrill. Should visit this place if just for the historic connection of Katchikally.

reviews.title: Not what is advertised
reviews.text: Went here paid 900 dalasai  and saw none of the cheetah or lion or orphaned animal advertised on the pamphlet. Don't know if there are 2 eagle heights but definatly not what is advertised on their pamphlet. There was some old hyenas and a few monkeys caged up. Guide was quite good in pointing out birds and wildlife but as per usual in Gambia expects a tip.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

reviews.title: Abuko and Eagle heights conservation reserves
reviews.text: Seeing the monkeys and crocodiles different bird's and hyena and going to Eagle heights conservation area where they are trying to breed the cheetah that they bought over with them from their park in Kent England not far from where we live.... And seeing the beautiful lion cub Buba and hope that next time we visit we see it in a lovely natural enclosure and possibly with a mate....

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

reviews.title: Worth a Short Trip, but Don't do 2 hours
reviews.text: Parts of this place are very cool, such as what they called the orphanage where you can see hyenas and lots of monkeys. Other parts are a bit boring. I would recommend having your car take you all the way into the orphanage rather than doing a 1 or 2 hour walk around the reserve. You can buy peanuts or bananas to feed to the monkeys at the orphanage, and that was quite fun.

Didn't spot a lot of birds but we didn't go at the good birdtime :) and if there were any our guide did not point them out. Also went to the zoo, there was a lion in a really really small cage. placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Warning! Reserve Now Occupied by Unmonitored Scammer Bumsters!
reviews.text:
The Abuko Nature Reserve is a large forest protected by the Government of The Gambia. It was once developed and maintained by the University of Warwick in the UK as a Darwin Field Station for biodiversity study, a project that ended in 2005. Since then, the developed portions of the Reserve have been abandoned and taken over by "bumsters" who know nothing about nature or biodiversity, but have figured out a number of scams to take your money. 

For example, the true entry fee for the park is 15 Dalasis as shown on the official receipt you are given...upon payment of 400 Dalasis!. In my case, I did not notice the receipt until I had paid the 400 Dalasis...too late sucker! Mysteriously, I was given a sticker to enter a privately owned exotic animal zoo on the highway outside of the park as a consolation. These "proprietors" apparently figured out an arrangement with the owners of the zoo to sell entry to that separate enterprise, off-site, under the guise that it was a mandatory fee to enter the Reserve. I was then asked for another 100 Dalasis to rent a pair of binoculars with no strap. I later found that the 10 X 50 glasses had been dropped and damaged so that the mirror prisms inside had been knocked out of alignment rendering them useless. Inasmuch as they were extremely heavy and without a strap, I simply pitched them into my sack and carried on with my own self-guided walk through the pathways of the Reserve. 

I respectfully declined the extremely high pressure mandatory but voluntary but mandatory requirement to hire a guide for another 300 Dalasis because I did not want to be accompanied by an unofficial "guide" who knew nothing about the faunna, flora and wildlife except what one could see anyway with the naked eye. The last thing I wanted was someone talking to me incessantly for the duration of my experience which did turn out to be a very beautiful 2-hour stroll through a luxurant forest full of wildlife. 

About halfway into the Park, I came across the remains of the Darwin Biodiversity Field Station which is adorned with old rotting posters and two bumsters dressed in disco garb and sunglasses who, not surprisingly, were requesting more "donations." They presented a "guestbook" that was undated, but appeared to be signed by people who were donating up to 500 Dalasis for a project that unbeknownst to them was terminated in 2005. The donation box was not only unlocked, but it had disappeared with the slot simply allowing the money to fall on the floor. When I asked who would get the money, the "boys," probably in their late 20s,  stated that the money would go to "the man." The station had some displays of bones that the boys had collected in the forest, lying on a table, and the remnants of old biodiversity exhibits. This field station offered no information about what was going on in the park. 

Notably, no one in the park, at the entrance or at this field station, could sell me a simple map of the park. For all the come-ons for money, one would have thought the easiest sell would have been a map of the park itself so that patrons like myself could find their way around the winding pathways, as obvious as they are. But then, enabled with a map, who would need a guide? This was a very simple thing to prepare and distribute for which I would have paid gladly. The absence of maps ws designed to compel the purchase of a guide. Who wants foreign visitors to have a pleasant walk through the park on their own? Certainly the proprietors do not. 

Nevertheless, continuing on from the field station, I had an extremely pleasant experience noting crocodiles, many more exotic birds than I had anticipated, and plenty of monkeys. It truly is a beautiful experience if you would like to take a walk for a couple of hours on your own. At all costs, however, I would avoid the sucker plays of everyone who is offering you something for money, especially their delightful company and incessant banter while you are trying to listen to the nature and take it all in. 

Near end of the pathway on the interior of the park there is what appears to be a legitimate zoo which contains hyenas, baboons and wild monkeys. These animals are kept in these cages on the explanation that they were once domesticated and the proprietors are attempting to allow them to re-adapt to their natural environment. They would be released in six months. I cannot imagine who would have domesticated the hyenas that I saw in those cages. They were huge! Domesticated baboons? Finally, the exit trail leads you onto, of all place,  the main highway far from your starting point. There you will find the UK owned zoo that contains some exotic animals outside of their natural habitat such as lions and cheetahs. Although I had unwittingly been forced to pay for entry into the Reserve, I passed on the idea, walked down the driveway onto the main highway, and then walked about three quarters of a kilometer down the highway to reunite with my vehicle at the entry of the park. It seemed an odd configuration to enter at one end, and then be dumped onto a main highway only to walk along noisy and fierce traffic to get back to your starting point. 

In the end, I did enjoy the walk and the exposure to nature that I found there. I'm afraid, however, that the fact that it has been spoiled by fraudulent tricks and and parasitic squatters who have taken over a once well-maintained biodiversity project assured me that I would not return to this place. Left alone, it is a beautiful place. Unfortunately, it is been spoiled by the unnatural. There are many other better maintained or unmaintained nature reserves in The Gambia that are well worth my time and money. Be forewarned!

reviews.title: eagle heights
reviews.text: went to abuko to a place called eagle heights,this is owned by English,they do flying displays and are very informative,but their main aim is conservation ang getting wildlife back into gambia,we did a walk with ba ba the lion cub which was amazing so please visit and support wildlife is dying out

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Saw some amazing wildlife.
reviews.text: Hired our own guide for a walk around this very manageable wildlife park. Saw some memorable sights including crocodiles, pygmy bee eaters, fire-finches and an African darter. There is a rather sad zoo towards the rear of the park where there are one or two sorry looking hyenas and baboons but I understand that the plan is to improve this facility in conjunction with the near-by Eagle Heights Park which is also worth a visit.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: wildlife Gem
reviews.text: This is a huge nature park.  It has fascinating flora and fauna. If you are a nature lover with an interest in birds, it's a must! We were lucky enough to see two species of Deer and crocodiles - spotted by our eagle eyed bird guide, Ansu Dunor.  I cannot recommend him highly enough.  He was very patient with us and wished to ensure we saw as much as possible. Beware of fake guides - to ensure a good guide, we recommend you ask for Ansu at the Bird Watchers Association located next to the Bridge in Kotu.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Something Old something New
reviews.text: This new nature site is at Abuko Nature Reserve,it is called EAGLE   Heights it says"face to face with nature" and so it is the people want to try and bring back some of the animals that Human beings over the years have destroyed eg Cheetars, (they have a cub) brings tears to your eyes.Lions, different birds  of prayand so much more, but they need our help so please visit and see what they have done in a short time, there are toilets, some benches under trees to drink cold Coke, water etc.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Very Highly Recommended
reviews.text: Excellent and very knowledgeable guide Ismaela showed us many animals and kept us save as he walked with us around the park.  He took us on a long tour and allowed us to borrow his binoculars to view the crocodiles and kingfishers around the water.  We also saw vultures, ospreys, termite mounds, bushbuck antelopes and inside the Eagle Heights Centre (which is within the Abuko Nature Reserve) we saw baby vultures, tortoises, birds of prey, a lion cub called Babar and even a cheetah couple!  Very educational and the conservation work they are doing here is excellent.  The animals are very well looked after and if any are in cages this is only ever for breeding or rehabilitation purposes.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Loved it!
reviews.text: A real feel of African wild life. Animal sighting and nature- great way to spend your day if you're bored of sitting by the pool (don't get me wrong, I still got a tan that day). At times it look like scenes from Lost. Would do it again!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Waste of time
reviews.text:
Arrived here early afternoon. As we didn't have much time, our driver wanted to drive us to the centre to see the hyenas & feed the monkeys. We have been a few times in the past, many years ago & had a good time, although I was never too keen on the condition the animals were kept in. We were taking friends out for a day & thought it would be nice to visit. 

On arrival our driver enquired about the price & said we just wanted to drive straight into the centre. He was told its 400 d each!!!! And we had to take a guide for the walk through the forest. I understand this is the guides only mean of income but we didn't want to do the walk, we've never had this problem before. We explained we only wanted to see the centre but was told we had to do all if it so we got back in the car. The man came over & said ok what will you pay for what you want to do. I said it's too late, as he was being greedy we would just go to lamin lodge for a drink. Bad luck, you lost out. 

Some other friends of ours did visit, on my recommendation (from past experiences) they said it was extremely overpriced, the animals were in appalling conditions & overall it was rubbish. Sorry guys, had I known how badly it had gone down hill & how expensive it was I would have told them not to bother. 

Stick to the crocodile pond at 50d each.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Beautiful nature walk
reviews.text: The walk is wonderful, shame there were too many noisy tourists scaring the crocs away! A guide named Billy had excellent knowledge, I felt it a real Shame that these guides are not employed by the park which is government owned & it's quite expensive compared to other tourist attractions in Gambia, so it was shocking to me that Billy only got paid the tips! There was a very wounded hyena which was a little concerning, apparently he had fought with the others. All other animals seemed happy & healthy. Eagle heights is very new & therefore they don't have many animals to see but the staff are very knowledgeable.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Vile disgusting place
reviews.text: This part is written for the government own part of the so called nature reserve. We went with Thomas cook who had it advertised as a National park and Animal orphanage. Never seen animals is such appalling conditions, no clean water, Hyenas that were so mange ridden it must of been awful for them in the heat. A monkey in a cage that was paralysed from the waist down, had to drag himself to the food, questioned the keepers who lied and said it only arrived the previous day, which later was found not to be true it had been like it for over a month, I offered to pay for the vet to come out and humanly put it to sleep!!!!!!!. It is not an orphanage it is cruelty beyond believe. !!!!!!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Excellent customer service
reviews.text: Our roots trip did not happen due to a administrative error, however the CEO Abdul apologized personally and offered for us to go on the next trip for free, however we would be leaving the Gambia on that day. Instead he gave us a free trip of what we wanted to do we chose to go to the crocodile and monkey park with a personal guide and free water thrown in. I would have no hesitation to recommend or use Arch tours again.

reviews.title: Strange, different but wonderful!!
reviews.text:
What a great place! This is not a zoo, this is where the crocodiles choose to stay and live, they are free to leave if they want, we loved to see this natural place and pool and the crocodiles are very calm, looks peaceful!
Ask your guide and they will help you! Count on about 2 hours to walk around! Bring some cash and give about 5-10€ in tip inside to the crocodile manager, the money is for fish to feed the crocodiles in the mornings!
Well worth the time and that small amount of money!

reviews.title: Crocodile Park
reviews.text:
I visited the crocodile park. I found the Museum small but very informative with a lot of history.
I was shocked to see a crocodile just lay in the park, unmoving with its mouth wide open, the only thing that moved was its eyes, it must surly be drugged to stay like this. I did have a photo taken with it, like every one else but I now wish I hadn't

reviews.title: Crocs up close
reviews.text: Great to be able to touch these terrifying animals. Amazing to see up close. and in a natural environment.

reviews.title: Amazing if you're a Birder
reviews.text: Easy to get to by Taxi from Banjul.  Good number of Gambian Bird Species and mammals.  Well run with guides available.  Early morning or late afternoon visits are essential to have the best birding experience.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A vast improvement at Abouko.
reviews.text:
New look Abouko. 
03 November 2014, 15:29
Lovely to see Abouko Park has been taken over by some responsible people,now renamed Eagle Heights,it puts on flying displays each morning,various new animals are presant including Leopards and baby lions and various raptors,its being well run and the animals are being well cared for,theres a new refreshments area and a nice shady lodge where you can now view the various activities,most important the various indigenous animal species will,overtime,be introduced back into the park,details are on FB.

03 November 2014, 15:34
Eagle Heights Gambia is NOW OPEN! 

Eagle Heights Gambia is based at the beautiful Abuko Nature Reserve in The Gambia, West Africa. Set among almost 500 acres you will be entranced by the flora and fauna around you. 

Currently at the Centre are our 2 Cheetah with which we are hoping to begin a successful breeding project. A selection of Birds of Prey including a Crowned Eagle, Lanner Falcon, Tawny Eagle and Bateleur Eagle! 

The current orphanage inside Abuko will be collaborating with us enabling us to move the Hyena from their current enclosure to a new and improved version. This also applies to the Baboons and any other animals that arrive at the orphanage from now on. 

Daily Talks will take place along with a flying demonstration. You will also be invited to take a pit stop at our Bar for an all important refreshment!

Following the opening of the centre we will then begin our second project, Reintroduction! We will be reintroducing many once indigenous species back into the Abuko Buffer Zone. These are species that once lived there naturally but were unfortunately wiped out by humans etc.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Superb!
reviews.text: Set In a dry rainforest there is much to see here, many birds of which there are too many to name an in terms of mammals if you arrive early and go to the hide that looks over the small lake you have a high chance of seeing vervet monkey, red colobus monkey, bushbuck, sun squirrel and if lucky sitatunga! There are also a pair of resident nile crocodiles that inhabit the lake.. You can see many of the kingfisher species here aswell as palm nut vulture, violet turaco, hammerkop and a few hornbill species! Small fee to get in but if you have a good guide the cost of your guide normally means they pay for you! At the end of the trail at Abuko there is a woodland bar where you can get close to the vervet monkeys but don't get too close as a scratch or bite could lead to worse! By the bar is an animal orphanage of injured wild animals in recovery including baboons, Patas monkey and spotted hyena

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great Birding Venue
reviews.text: Anyone visiting here should be well aware of its birding heritage, what I would say is hire a good reputable guide. I have visited twice although the first visit yielded a good array of birdlife the second visit was much more productive mainly down to the guide.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not much to see
reviews.text:
We went to this park with taxi and spent there maybe 2-3 hours. We had a guide and it was useless. There weren't many animals or much to see. Day was really hot in February (47 celcius )
There are better places to go in Gambia so i don't recommend this place :)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: We went at the wrong time of the day (11.00am) so we were still walking through Reserve at midday and beyond (takes about 2 hours).  It was very hot but we survived and enjoyed the experience very much.  If you don't like the heat (or monkeys jumping out of the bushes at you!) don't got at the height of the day.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nature reserve
reviews.text:
We went here as part of our group bird watching tour, out guide was very good and we was able to see a lot of different birds, we did other animals as well including monkeys.
We didn't really like the conditions the hyenas were kept in the cages seemed small and they were quite dirty.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great park, I enjoyed the trip
reviews.text: Lot of serious birders wandering around with massive cameras, the best place to see all sorts of birds, there is a small lake that attracts all sorts of birds and a few hides scattered around. They have Hyenas who are to fat to even chase the vultures away from pinching their food, never seen such fat animals. Also caged  baboons. The keeper told me most of these animals have been rescued from bad homes. I was concerned about a very skinny Baboon but I was told he was taken from a soldier who was not looking after him. They certainly do their best to look after the animals. Refreshments in the centre of the park with some seats in the shade, that was nice. I enjoyed the day, would recommend a visit

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: I expected more
reviews.text:
For such a big space i was expecting to see more animals. Our guide was great and very informative but the lack of animals was disappointing and i'm sure we walked a couple of hours. Apart from the two types of monkey that were roaming about (one type was the same as the ones that come to the hotel) the others were caged, the hyenas were just lying about because of the heat, the crocodiles were nowhere to be seen, and i saw one exotic looking bird (apart from the caged parrot)!
They said they were getting more animals in soon but it wasn't a very exciting walk unfortunately, but to be fair its not their fault that the animals were hiding, not around and tired.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Abouko......Disgraceful
reviews.text: This must be one of the most neglected parks I've ever seen,its got worse over the past 3 years . The caged animals are in a pityfull state. The baboon troop has dwindled from 40 animals to a handful,there kept in a bare cage,in another sparse cage was a vulture with a live monkey for company it was obviously the birds food! In the same cage last year was a giant tortoise and a pelcan,no sign of those and seeing the conditions they living in I fear the worse . The Hyenas were in a awful state ,one was surounded by vultures and it was obvious he was sick. Stay away if you are an animal lover or you will leave this hell hole  in tears.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Birders paradise;think again
reviews.text: This park like all the other parks we visited has been seriously neglected despite staff who sit about all day doing nothing. It is in need of signs; the lavatories need cleaning up and  like all parks geared for birdwatching it needs the provision of water so that birds can be observed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Maybe need to go early in the morning?
reviews.text: There are mixed reviews for this park. We went late morning and were disappointed: little to see, some caged hyenas, self appointed guide, aggressive monkeys (not like Bijolo). Maybe the higher ratings are for early morning when there is more bird life? We saw four birds only. It takes two hours to walk around the one forest path.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Nothing to see
reviews.text:
Well, we really did not see anything else than the caged animals (poor hyenas, one was in a really small cage, baboons and turtles).

In the beginning the quide (who invited himself with us) told that we probably aint gonna see any animals.. cause they are sleeping or eating or what ever. And we really did not see anything, not even birds. We walked an hour in the "jungle". There was a "crocodile pool" where was supposed to be 50 or something crocodiles, didnt see any, and nobody else has seen.

Welt kind of like cheated, had to pay for the quide too. Felt bad cause of the caged animals. Aint gonna visit Abuko never again.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Not big but nice!
reviews.text:
We went there and it was just a short trip from sun beach hotel just 20 min. walk trough bakau.
They have a albino crocodile there Charlie which is portriad in the watermark on the money. If you're lucky you can see him but he's in the water a lot

reviews.title: Crocodile park
reviews.text: This place you have to visit, if you go to Gambia. Crocodiles are free inside this park and you go there to they area. You can touch one of the crocodile, call Charlie and that was quite schary, but it was safety. There is "nanny"  with you and they told, that they give 250 kg fish every day to crocodiles, so they are calm. Must visit place.

reviews.title: Worth a visit - make sure you get a good guide.
reviews.text:
We had a mixed visit, in that there were no animals around (apart from one or two monkeys and some beautiful birds). However, we got lucky with our guide (sorry I can't remember his name) who was really informative and very knowledgable. He was able to talk passionately for the whole walk, which took a couple of hours. 

The animal orphanage is interesting, and you're guaranteed to see baboons, hyenas and lots and lots of vultures there - even if they are behind wire fences. 

Try to go if you're in the area - if only to support the business and the cause. Apparently early morning is the best time to see the animals.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Outstanding
reviews.text: We had a knowledgable and attentive guide for the day who found and identified scores of birds for us. The Brewer viewing hide was fantastic and the whole experience perfect.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: The Animal Orphanage needs some financial help
reviews.text: Second visit to this lovely natural place, great for birds and walking as mentioned previously - however the small animal orphanage as it is called within this place needs financial help from what I can see.  There are some Hyena's in a large cage however hidden next to the pelican is another cage with some very poorly looking Hyenas with sores etc, I'm not judging but from what I understand, this place needs some help to make sure the animals are cared for more, ie more food, medical help for animals and better quality of surroundings that they live in day after day.  The baboons could do with ropes and tyres hanging and things to amuse them and play with for example.  As its mainly tourists that visit this place, they could increase the entrance fee which could help. I have may ideas as to how this could be improved and would love to be able to help in someway.  That said, the wild monkeys are used to people and they will come and see you especially if you buy monkey nuts and will gently take them out of you hand which is a fantastic experience and one of the main reasons i viisit the place.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great if you like wildlife & walking
reviews.text: Great chance to see some of The Gambia's wildlife but be prepared for 2hrs of walking in a wood/forest  If you go without a guide there are guides hanging around the entrance and they vary from very good to rubbish Unless you know the birds it can be difficult to chose a competent one.  I've had "guides" describe birds as little brown jobs and others that not only correctly identify but give you Latin names as well now that's just showing off!  Ask for a try before you buy  agree a price and get them to walk with you for 10 mins  and let them show you the birds you'll soon know what you've got  You can go it alone as it is difficult to get lost just follow the path but the good guide will show you so much more than you'll see going it alone and are well worth the 400D fee for their services

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Rustig park, pinda's voeren aan apen.
reviews.text:
We went here after visiting the Serrekunda market and then you notice how peaceful it is
If you are there for birds you can get a guide with binoculairs. If you are not don't think they are freebies and say no.
After paying the fee and entering the park another man comes up with a donation form for maintenance on the park. They should include that in the ticket price and don't hassle on every opportunity.

We spotted some beautiful trees and we came across some monkeys. (we dont have the expert eye for birds so we didnt notice them) Also some termite hills.
Somewhere halfway there were some animals caged up. Baboons, 2 pelicans, a turtle and some hyena's.
The smaller monkeys run around and you can buy a bag of peanuts there to feed them. (about 25D for a bag) The bigger ones come pick them out of your hand and they can be quite greedy so you have to throw some around for the smaller ones to also enjoy some.

More walking ahead you come through a souvenir area.

This trip is for you if you like to walk a small hour and like to see some nature and animals.

Afterwards we also stopped at the nearby goat and sheep market.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Still as interesting as it was 40 years ago!
reviews.text: I lived in The Gambia in the 1970s, and spent every Sunday morning walking around the nature reserve, mainly birdwatching.  It is such a pleasure to return so many years later and find it almost unchanged, though sadly they need more funding to keep things going.  The highlight is watching the birds from the upstairs viewing area in the large building next to the lake, which also has crocodiles.  Take your binoculars and you will see so many different species!  Then the walk through the forest is fascinating, so many different trees, and with luck you will see plenty of monkeys, both the Callithrix and the Red Colobus monkeys.  They are easy to spot as they scamper through the trees, and trees with have fruit are often absolutely full of monkeys!  Unfortunately I didnt spot a monitor lizard on this visit, though there are many large lizards in the park, and snakes too, though the reptiles are much more active during the rainy season.  Halfway round the walk you reach the animal orphanage, which is a very sad sight with monkeys and baboons in enclosures, when they should be roaming wild.  Its all very dilapidated and makes you feel sorry for the animals.  At the end of the walk round there is a craft market, not very good I'm afraid, so it's better to hurry straight through!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text:
Until now the closest I had ever come to seeing the crocodile was through the television
I know you can see them in a zoo but it’s not the Same as seeing them for real this beats the Zoo experience

reviews.title: Crocodiles + museum = experience!
reviews.text:
Read somewhere that people had written that the museum on site wasnt according to the ”standard” they were used to. I think these people have the wrong expectations.

The museum and the park itself is small but it tells you a lots of stories about The Gambia; history, politics, people, the different tribes and their customs (clothes, instruments). I got a lot of insights during this visit, and I am thrilled to understand some of the differences and similarities between the different tribes.

Walking towards the crocodile pool we passed a -huge- tree with a hollow body that could encircle ten of us (photo session time), a lots of other trees and lianes (shadow!), and fields were the women work with the family crops (photo session time).

The crocodile pool was at first glance not that much to talk about, but suddenly they were crawling up to meet us and there were crocodiles everywhere. Cool and a bit scary :)

If you want to be close to a crocodile, go here. If you dont, stay home.
And, dont be stupid, they are still crocodiles even when they are recently fed ;)

reviews.title: Lovely nature reserve (its not a zoo!)
reviews.text:
Abuko is a wonderfully intact piece of tropical forest, amongst the otherwise heavily populated Serrekunda area. Some reviewers seem to be under the impression this a zoo, it's not! There is a small animal orphanage at one end of the reserve but its a desperately sad place and not a reason to visit.

I enjoyed wandering the narrow paths seeing birds, lizards and monkeys (you will see them if you walk slowly and quietly). The Darwin field centre is an excellent vantage point to see lots of wading birds and birds of prey as well as Nile Crocodiles.

The guides are knowledgeable and well worth taking along on an initial visit. I agree with the previous reviewer who advised taking water with you, it's quite a long way to do the full reserve circuit and the heat is sapping. The reserve doesn't get much funding so facilities are basic, but I loved it for being so quiet without lots of other people around.

I would recommend Abuko more to the serious nature lover who will get more from it than someone who expects to be entertained and see an animal every 2 minutes. For me, taking time was rewarded by getting to see amazing species like the Giant Kingfisher close up. I enjoyed it so much I actually went twice during my week in The Gambia.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: definitely worth a trip but probably just the once is enough...
reviews.text: we visited abuku in january with our 7 year old son, he loved it once we had actually found where the animals were, they keep the animals quite far from the entrance to the park, we declined the guide and walked a massive circle for nearly an hour to arrive back at the entrance having found nothing, we got our directions then took another 20 minute walk into the bush (get the guide at the entrance its worth it) we eventually came to 2 large enclosures one with lots of baboons going wild for the nuts we had purchased to feed them and another breed of monkey in the other and green monkeys all around us roaming free with the escapee (a baby baboon that refused to go back into the enclosure) i think there was around 5 different species of monkey/baboons in total as well as a monitor lizard we had passed on the way in.. after our talk from the keeper she guided us over to the final enclosure where the hyenas were having an afternoon nap, they were huge and there was also vultures in the enclosure, my boy was mesmerised,....... after a rest stop at the tuck shop for ice cold drinks we haggled ourselves a nice bargain on a wood carved ornament and headed our way to the exit... all in all was a very memorable day and so glad we went however it is not very interesting until the final moments of the park when u reach the animals.... am i glad i went? yes definitely and would recommend it too, but only once! so will i be returning? in a word,,, no.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Wonderful experience
reviews.text:
The monkeys appearing from no where and stealing nut from you.
Some of them even perched on my wife's head

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Abuko Nature Reserve
reviews.text: Saw lots of different monkey along with the hyena's - different spieces of plants on the walk around the forest, went a couple of times at different times of day, many vultures when I went around 6.pm and they were feeding the hyena's!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: The beginnings of a "gambian" "rspc to local wildlife!?!
reviews.text: The reserve offers a closer encounter with some of The Gambias more illusive wildlife,fab` for all bird watching,in the morn and evening.Adventurous bumpy sandy tracks getting there and daunting sign posting,best way is go for a sensible wander unless looking for fancier hobbies-then hire a guide,the wildlife is natural and well camoflaged.If tipping,give direct to office for animals feed etc not the guides,them got a relative salary!!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Monkeys!!
reviews.text: Don`t miss this park on your trip to The Gambia-so much fun. The monkeys are very friendly-not vicious at all. They climb up you, sit on your shoulders etc as you feed them monkey nuts. So many monkeys!  Book the trip with the RSPB men on Bakau beach (under white umbrella by Calypso Restaurant) if you want to enjoy spotting the birds as well as well as knowledge of the local monkeys. If not then go with the tour guides opposite the Ocean Bay Hotel. They charged us 20 quid which included the taxi & full mornings entertainment plus relaxing time sat under the African sun shades on the beautiful beach next to the park.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: A little dissapointing
reviews.text: We spent about an hour here but overall were rather dissapointed, a nice walk through the forest, a couple of monkeys, and some sleeping hyenas, not much else!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Fantastic
reviews.text: Such a beautiful place to spend some time. We went in the early morning and only saw one other couple for the majority of the time we were there. However, on our way back out there were huge groups arriving. I would definately recommend going independantly with your own guide rather then with a tour company in a large group. We saw a huge variety of birds and ther were certainly some very enthusiastic bird watchers there with all the high tech binoculars, telescopes, cameras etc. We also saw a couple of crocodiles and lots of monkeys. Halfway round there is an animal sanctuary where they house animals that have been removed from locals who have bought them to entertain tourists for a charge. There was a very friendly monkey that sat on my knee and played with my hair. You can buy peanuts to feed to the monkeys. We absolutely loved our time here and spent a good 3 hours wandering around spotting monkeys and birds. From what I remember it cost approx 50d (£1) each to get in.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Beautiful but only for bird lovers
reviews.text:
We arrived at Abuko having heard and read quite a lot about it. It is better to come here early in the morning, not around 11am like we did since most of the animals are sheltering from the heat and crocodiles are swimming closer to the bottom of the pond.

The few monkeys we saw were not scared of humans, this is because they are used to humans feeding them. People saying it was great to feed wild monkeys probably have not been to a safari or national park before. Infact you are encouraged to buy peanuts for the monekys. And the zoo in the middle is apparently kept there so tourists can atleast see something in the reserve if nothing else. It is expensive to run these reserves and you can see that in the health of the hyenas and monkeys. The place was grand back in the day with lion(s) and other animals, when the founder Mr.Brewster was alive but now has deteriorated a little. The president's zoo is better funded and has more animals.

Saying that, we had a lovely walk around the area and saw some birds. Since we were not bird watchers or bird lovers, we just enjoyed the different varieties without knowing what they were :-)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Give it a miss
reviews.text:
Highly overrated and a real tourist con as has been the case for a long time 
The crocodile that you are able to feel is heavily drugged.
A total waste of time.

reviews.title: Stroke a crocodile!
reviews.text:
Sacred and historic crocodile pool stocked with West African crocodiles. Crocodiles are well fed and used to being approached by humans. Informative museum.
Need a guide to find as not signposted from the road.

reviews.title: Few Crocodiles
reviews.text: Overhyped- has to travel a long way to see a few lazy crodiles. Everywhere busters inside and out hassling you to touch the crocodile etc for money. Never leaves you alone

reviews.title: NOT for faint hearted!
reviews.text:
An amazing experience that i do not think you can do anywhere else on earth and 100% NOT in Europe!!!

Get upclose and personal with one of the most deadliest animals on earth.

You literally ENTER the home of these crocs that walk around freely, just one rule DO NOT touch them by the head area if you want to come out in one piece! 

I cannot recommend this place highly enough! Also there is a museum that is really educational.

reviews.title: A great day
reviews.text: We had a lovely time in Abuko, our guide was great and we saw loads of birds and monkeys... and even a snake! The one bad point is the awful 'zoo' in the middle where they house baboons, hyenas and turtles. It absolutely stinks and the animals are totally miserable. I refused to give any money for that.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Great for the nost part...till you get to the animals in cages...
reviews.text:
Although I thought Abuko was wonderful for the most part, (we saw a crocodile, a bushbuck and several species of monkeys and birds) I was dismayed to see the hyenas in captivity, also baboons and some other animals, all in cages. I was told that the baboons are orphaned (though it was a whole family), and also some of the other animals, but that the hyenas are just an exhibit. There also used to be a lion there but it escaped. Apparently they have links with the local zoo, and some of the animals live in captivity always. There is no need for this - visitors come to see wildlife in its natural state, not kept in a prison. The hyenas were pacing up and down i.e. exhibiting stereotypical behaviour, which was not good to see at all.

Also although there are notices up saying not to feed the wildlife however friendly it is, people (and one of the guides!) were openly feeding the monkeys peanuts, thus habituating the monkeys to humans, and causing them to lose their natural skills. Abuko should actively be fining people for doing this and the guides should be sufficiently educated so as not to do this. 

For this reason I have given this reserve a 3-star rating, otherwise it would be a 4 or 5.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: The smell
reviews.text:
It is a long walk with little of interest from the main gate to the first lodge which is twinned with the University of Warwick (Birdwatching), A bit interesting as an alligator was watching a wading bird and we watched the alligator...yawn!!...  A short further walk through thicker overgrowth brings you to the heart of the reserve. Staff are always needing money to feed the animals... A very sad affair, as the main animals have allegedly been transported to the presidents old village  zoo.  You are left with the stench from 5 hyenas and 20 vultures who constantly watch the few monkeys that surround the area. 
There are a few captive monkeys to feed peanuts to if you want. Most fun was being professionally ambushed by the reserve monkeys on the way out who cleaned us of anything edible.  in conclusion..It was tired, the staff were tired, the animals looked tired...
