placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Monkey Loving!
reviews.text:
I loved Abuko, it has a little something for everyone. 

It is quite a walk, the less mobile may want to give this a miss, but when you get to the end, the tamer monkeys are there to entertain
and steal the nuts you have just bought for them! Keep the plastic bag out of slight or they will grab at it! 

It was fantastic to feed wild monekys. This made the trip well worth it. 

If you drove to the park, like I did, as a bit of advice, when you get to the cafe, go visit the hyenas and stuff, but don't go through the past with the exit sign over it. Go back the way you came, otherwise you end up a 15 minute walk down a dusty busy road from where you first started!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: Very cool!!
reviews.text: Amazing experience! Never thought I would ever touch a crocodile! They are very relaxed and don't mind people being around. Great value for money

reviews.title: Great place but full on!
reviews.text:
i loved visiting the markets, they are buzzing so it can be full on at times as everyone tries to sell you things as you are a tourist.  Don't get caught up in this, only pick up things if you are interested otherwise you may find yourself stuck there for a lot longer than you want to be!  make sure you take water as it gets hot walking around the markets during the day with the heat.  

If you aren't one for seeing animals (i.e. butchers/fishmongers) be warned you will come across stalls like this with everything out on the floor.... it's the way it is done so cover your nose and close your mouth to avoid the strong smells.  Just remember you are seeing the reality which is definately in technicolour in this place - Fab!

reviews.title: Truly amazing
reviews.text: This is a magnificent place that I have been to 3 times. There is an interesting museum documenting a lot of history. Then you go to the pool and there are over 100 crocs just basking in the sun. You can stroke them. Some people just lark about which is really pathetic as these are wild animals. Well fed on fish but still not to be messed with. Some fools think they are Crocodile Dundee and naturally the guides tell those people off. The crocs seemed happy enough to me. It is a marvellous place and I will go back many times

reviews.title: Lifted the crocodile's legs
reviews.text: Health and Safety in Europe wouldn't let you do half the things you can do here. Pose for a photo cuddling a crocodile, lift up its legs & tail - amazing.

reviews.title: Crocodile pool
reviews.text: Place, where you can see crocodiles very close. You are in the same area with the crocodiles. It is little bit scary to be in same area with crocodiles. They move very fast but Charlie is one of the croc,  which you can touch and be with him in same picture. You can touch him behind and one of the worker is very close. They give lots of fish for crocs and that's why they are full and satisfied.

reviews.title: Extraordinary place to see crocs
reviews.text: I brought 2 groups here and they were both really excited to see the crocs in and around the pool. The price has been increased dramatically and the managers are in danger of pricing tourists out of here. The museum is interesting but dated in presentation and rather dusty. Visitors who haven't seen crocs before are invariably impressed with the pool. A must see if you visit Gambia.

reviews.title: Second visit same awesome experience
reviews.text: So this was my second visit to the crocodile pool, this time i went with my 8 year old daughter, 6 year old nephew, sister and 2 year old niece. It was a 100 dalasi fee for entry for adults while the kids went in free. We started off with the tour of the mini museum then proceeded to the pool where the crocodiles are. You are allowed to touch the crocodiles and definitely pictures are allowed this is with the assistance of a tour guide. You can make voluntary donations that goes towards the feeding of the crocodiles, they are fed only fish. I will say it was yet again a beautiful experience.

reviews.title: 'Holy Crocs'
reviews.text:
We, as a couple, visited the fairly basic crocodile pool while staying at The Kairaba Hotel. One hour should easily do. We had mixed feelings, we had the feeling that the animals were sedated and moreover got a 'Lacoste' touch - say, treating wild and normally voracious animals as pets. 
Optional donations are asked for and I wish to think that at a major part is for croc food. The surroundings give a chance to see how the locals live their lifes. Tip: take a taxi driver 'green' to organise the tour for you.

reviews.title: Katchikally Crocodile Pool ,a must see in the Gambia
reviews.text: Spent a hour or so at the Croc pool today as we looked around the Gambia, well worth a visit to see such prehistoric creatures so close up ,certainly a first for me and the wife stroking a crocodile, interesting little museum attached to the pool so made for a interesting visit ,with a cost of D200 well worth a look.

reviews.title: many crocodiles, none doing very much
reviews.text: I walked over to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool, in Bakau, which is in the middle of the town and not easy to find. There is first a pleasant museum with some masks and information about Gambia in the war. The pool itself is small and has many crocodiles, none doing very much. I stroked one on the back and it didn't seem to mind.

reviews.title: Crocos wild!! :)
reviews.text: We went here with our local guide sonko (sonko1984@yahoo.com) who arranged everything. This place is cheap to go and close. Atmosphere was good, lots of crocos. And first time i had a chance to touch crocodile!! you can donate some money to this place if you want. i Recommend!

reviews.title: Up close and personal to crocodiles
reviews.text:
Crocodile pool - it's not everyday that you can get to stroke a crocodile but here you can.entrance fee is very cheap and as you walk through the museum you get a sense of history with all the artifacts and pictures on show,you then meander through the gardens hearing and seeing different birds until you come to the croc pool.a guide will go with you explaining about the origins of the pool(used for fertility rites) and take you to stroke crocodiles and will gladly take photos for you.
Excellent way to spend a couple of hours

reviews.title: Mixed Feelings!!
reviews.text:
My wife and I visited this crocodile pool while staying at the Senegambia Beach Hotel.
I have mixed feelings.
Although it was a great place to visit,
I could not help but feel that some of the animals were sedated.
It just do not seem right a load of people being able to go and touch a crocodile,
but again, having said this it was also a fantastic experience to do such a thing.
They do ask for a donation, although this is optional.
I would like to think that at least half of the donation is put towards the crocs food.
The surrounding area is a bit of an eye-opener, but do give you the chance to see close hand how the not so fortunate locals actually live.
It is worth going for the experience and close up site of these amazing creatures up close, just remain a bit open-minded by the experience.
Tip
If you are staying in or near the Senegambia Beach Hotel, get 'Del-Boy' to organise the tour for you. Well organised and worth the money. He is always down on the beach.

reviews.title: Something to do in Gambia
reviews.text:
Difficult to rate:

Before getting to the crocodile pool, there is a museum - 5 little huts: very interesting and informative. 
The crocodile pool is ok, lot of crocodile and there's a keeper that talks about the place. You can get up close to the crocodiles. You are allowed to touch the crocodile. Not sure if that is normal. The keeper said they feed them the night before so they are not hungry when tourist are around. 

The keeper will ask you to donate money to feed the crocodile. I wish I said No because you pay an entrance fee. I gave equivalent of less than $1 so that. 

The most uncomfortable part of this visit was the children at the entrance aggressively begging for money with directions/encouragement from their mothers.

reviews.title: Of two minds this is animal exploitation...
reviews.text: Conveniently placed for a quick trip from the hotel area and it is not a big attraction. Being an anti-city zoo, anti-circus type family this is NOT wild reptiles in a natural environment what ever the low price. And getting young children to bonk a maybe unhappy creature on the head is not setting a good example for future conduct with Africa wildlife.  Anyway they enjoyed the experience, pool men could be better informed and interactive in the job role.  Information centre was useful.

reviews.title: Difficult to rate
reviews.text:
Our todler had the best time at the crocodile pool. He really like petting the crocodiles. Kept talking about it all week.
But... this is not natural and in hindsight we should have never participated in this type of animal abuse. 
The adjacent museum is quite informative and we found it a pleasant surprise at this crocodile site.

reviews.title: To touch a crocodile
reviews.text: You want to get as close as you have ever been to a crocodile. This is ideal. Not sure about the health and safety side of things but worth a vist. Don't expect too much it is fairly basic.

reviews.title: Good value experience
reviews.text:
Entrance was only 100 dalasi so good value. There's a museum on site, but I personally just wanted to touch a crocodile! Wasn't disappointed, there's looots of them in a small pool, lying around everywhere, calm and lazy just lounging. 
Nice place to spend part of your day - won't take more than an hour of your time!

reviews.title: An interesting excursion, but don't expect too much!
reviews.text:
Katchikally is one of those 'must see it' excursions that are thrust upon every visitor to the Gambia and, to be fair, it is an interesting way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction - and we didn't find any toilets!
Quite simply, this is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. It is apparently used for fertility rituals and is owned by one of the wealthiest families in Gambia
Yes, you can touch the crocodiles if you feel brave. You will be surrounded by other visitors most of the time and the 'keepers' will try (insistently) to sell you handmade crocodile teeth necklaces and other overpriced craft items.
I was slightly perturbed by the keeper's insistence that we should give him a 'donation' to pay for the crocodile's fish, especially as we had just paid to get in. Was this official or just another Bumster trick? I suspect the latter!
The best bit for me was the small museum at the venue's entrance. There are some interesting examples of local drums and musical instruments with some ceremonial costumes. I was particularly fascinated by the display of old photographs. For me, this was worth the entrance fee on its own.
In short, Katchikally is a tourist trap, but a relatively gentle one. The crocodile custodians are generally pleasant and you will almost certainly enjoy your visit.

reviews.title: Great adventure
reviews.text: Amazing time, great guide to help us through the crocodile pools, keep an eye out as there is wildlife everywhere.

reviews.title: A place to visit
reviews.text:
A  nice walk through a forest/jungle with lots to see, and then there's t
lots of crocodiles in ponds and walking around. You actually not very far from them

reviews.title: Crocodile pool in a very poor neighborhood.
reviews.text: We visited the crocodile with a local guide. He did not know the location exactly so we stranded a few hundred meters from the entrance. The road are terrible and if you have to walk you realize you walking along open sewer. First thing to visit is the museum that gives a good impression of the area in the old days. When you walk along you will find the crocodiles that have been fed already so you are able to touch them. Around the pool it is relative clean but the garbage has been thrown into the behind the trees it looks like a garbage disposal area. Still touching the crocodiles is a special experience.

reviews.title: A unique experience - MUST visit place
reviews.text:
This was my second time to Gambia and I could not miss to visit this place one more time.  Last time it was summer so the pool was not full of water but this time it was raining and the experience was simply amazing.  The pool was full of water so could not see the Crocs lying on the side.
You enter the park by paying a nominal fee and if lucky find crocodiles walking along with you on the side or may be just lying next to the walking path.  They are harmless until she is a female.  Female is more into defense to protect her eggs.  You reach near the pool and find so many of them just lying over there, may be waiting for you to sit besides them and have your pictures taken.  Believe me, it is an amazing experience irrespective you like animals or not.  These Crocs are never fed meat and they eat almost 3,000 Kg of fish daily (that's what rangers told, not sure how much true it is).  Please make sure that the rangers are around and guide you which Croc to be with while taking the pictures.  Stay away from the female Crocs.  If the water level is a bit low in the pool then you can go close by and see many Crocs walking towards you from the water or the side.  There is nothing to worry about but you must need to take precautions while with animals.  There is a small shop that sells crocodile tooth and they are not expensive, may be around 150 - 200 dalasis.  They also ask for the donation and have maintained a register of donors.
They have a nicely maintained museum in the front that depicts many ancient and authentic articles including weapons, cooking vessels, musical instruments etc.  There is also a history of Gambia associated with it if you are interested into it.
It is a belief of the locals that a lady who is not able to conceive a baby can visit this place and take a dip in the pool to be an expectant mom in the future.

reviews.title: Nice and creepy
reviews.text:
A trip to Bakau is more than visiting a crocodile pool. You also see how poor this neighbourhood is. Pretty shocking. Children are happy if you give them something to eat or something small like a ball. 
Bakau pool is completely filled with crocs. You have to see it to believe it. You can touch them ( I' m not a fan). I' ve filmed it for my pupils, they found me an awesome teacher :-)

quotes: A nice little museum - but if you've time take a tour instead! The museum offers a nice introduction to Gambian life but, having just returned from a ...
Worth a visit I think it was a nice walk, although it was at the end of the dry season, and at 37"C!!! We saw several vervet monkeys, the red colobus,...
Not great, pretty run down reserve Not a great place to visit, there is a “museum” where they try and make you buy something to help with upkeep of th...

reviews.title: Good example of a fishing village
reviews.text:
I really enjoyed this visit. We went around the smoke huts where the process was explained to us, we met the ladies who were gutting/descaling the fish and got to look at where they lived and worked in some detail. The smell was awful but made the visit. We then walked down onto the beach where the fishing boats where either pulling in or were already there and the queues of people waiting for the fish to be offloaded, there were families of all ages moving around.

A walk the the market area was also an eye opener, no ice for keeping the fish cold, just buy it a get it home seems to be the motto.

The Gambians are a generally happy people and we were made to feel welcome, the women and some men are not keen on having their pictures taken so just be aware of that, ask first if unsure.

All in all well worth a visit, I would have liked to have spent more time there or gone back but time didn't allow that.

reviews.title: Average dusty local outdoor market
reviews.text:
Typical African market where the same trinkets, crafts, textiles etc are being sold, mostly very dusty. Am the above can easily be found in any same place. 

Each stall sells everything the same as their neighbours. Even having multiple stalls. 

I certainly saw, like for like, in Tanzania and Zanzibar. 

DO not accept the first price. Offer a 1/3 and meet in the middle unless you're very generous and pay their inflated price 

All good fun and they certainly won't sell at a loss 

They're great vendors, chatty, friendly and interested in where  you're from.

reviews.title: Beautyfull stuff (clothes, souveniers)
reviews.text:
There are beautyfull stuff at the market. People are very kind but sometimes its anoying they push you to buy stuff. Let people see for themselves. Pushing to buy is also pushing away. 
Because we left de market and did not buy anything. The 3rth visit i bought Some stuff. 
I bought 6 dresses and 2 Animal Crafts. Very beautyfull.

reviews.title: Not suitable for wheelchair users
reviews.text: One of us is a wheelchair user. The taxi controller knew that and he would also have known that the trip would be disastrous but still he let us go. The road surfaces are so poor that a wheelchair can’t negotiate them. As a result we saw nothing of the market. The taxi driver dropped us outside a shop having parked the taxi 200 yards away. We waited 30 minutes for him to pick us up because of the one way road system and the heavy traffic. Maybe others would enjoy the market but that was our experience.

reviews.title: Tough Shopping
reviews.text: 99% of the stalls sells the same wares. But if you have the patience to walk around and bear with the 'hassle' of the stall owners calling you....you will find something different...just like we did.

reviews.title: Good market
reviews.text: Much things to look at and much things to but. Remember that you need to discuss the Price and get it down at least 50%

reviews.title: New location, but worth a visit
reviews.text: I understand this is now a new location, just outside Brikama (rather than closer to the centre).  There are lots of traders and some lovely items, although obviously you have to be discerning.  When we were there there were not many others around so traders were desperate for a sale, and even us, as seasoned travellers and hard hagglers, probably overpayed for a couple of things (as it felt harsh to haggle too hard), but it was a nice easy to walk around atmosphere, with plenty on offer.

reviews.title: Be prepared to haggle!
reviews.text: This Craft Market at the border of the Senegambia is one of many in Gambia and displays a wide variety of hand made local products. A must do at least once whilst in the Gambia. Be prepared to haggle!

reviews.title: Good market
reviews.text:
I actually went here several years ago but remember it well.
Good market for good variety of wood carvings. I even exchanged the T - Shirt I was wearing for a carving when I ran out of Dalasi to pay for it. If you like wood carvings this is recommended.

reviews.title: Great for craft souvenirs
reviews.text:
Visited as part of a 4 in 1-day tour with The Gambia Experience. 
Lots of artisans making wooden items with some great large items to buy if only you could get them on the plane home!
Other reviews suggest the prices are generally lower than the tourist traps such as in Senegambia. 
As with everywhere in the Gambia haggle! Personally I found that starting at a third of the initial price meant you ended up somewhere just over half the initial price suggested! Whatever you pay will however be a bargain!
If you have the time, cross the main road (carefully!) and visit the livestock market.

reviews.title: Talented craft workers
reviews.text: I've visited Brikama craft market a couple of times now.  The shops each sell pretty similar things, although the style and finish may be a little different at each one.  The shop keepers are of course very keen on encouraging you to visit their shop and even though you've already seen the content in a previous one it's courteous to go in anyway.  The wooden carvings are fantastic and if you want to make a little change to something, they are very accommodating. For example, I didn't like the face on a model I picked up, so they chiselled it off for me there and then!

reviews.title: Brikama Craft Market
reviews.text:
Quite small - but great value - depending on your haggling skills !!
Around halve the price of Senegambia and a nice day out.
Good selection of wood products all hand made - and they will make to order if you want - take a picture of the object - the Gambian imagination differs from ours !!

reviews.title: Great souvenirs are worth the hassle
reviews.text:
This is my third visit to the craft market and I'm beginning to recognise and name some of the sellers now.  This is always greatly appreciated by the seller!
It is a little difficult to just browse here as all the sellers call out for you to visit their 'shop', however the atmosphere is friendly.  It can be hard to choose who to buy from as most of the 'shops' sell similar goods.  Try to haggle, I know it can be hard but it is actually good fun when you get into it for something that you really want to take home.  I'm never cut throat though.  If I would pay it at home then fair enough for me.
Enjoy chasing a bargain!

reviews.title: Eye Opening!
reviews.text: This market is both organized and chaotic. I'm sure that doesn't make too much sense but that's how I can describe it. It's like your typical market- fruits, vegetables, general goods, clothing- you name it. It's broken up in sections so all like items are within the same area. It's not for the faint of heart so you've never experienced outdoor markets from anywhere in the developing world, I suggest a guide or proceed with caution. It's safe, no one will bother you. It can be overwhelming and you may get some talkative vendors here and there. I felt very comfortable walking around with someone who was familiar with the do's and don'ts of the market, so I was very happy to have a guide. I learned a lot about the market through him as well. He even treated me to fruits, and showed me some less traveled areas in the market that I surely would not have been able to easily do had I gone solo. If you're interested, his name is Kebba and he can be contacted via WhatsApp at +220 342 1046. I even contacted him on such short notice and he was able to arrange a tour for me within just a couple of hours! He's extremely professional, reasonably priced, excellent English speaking skills, and former Gambian military, so you're in very trusted hands.

reviews.title: Great The Gambia Market For Everything
reviews.text:
We walked and shoppes through all the sections of this market that sells household goods, clothes, produce, fresh meats, spices, handicrafys and souvenirs. We could not resist fresh fruits, a souvenir shirt of The Gambia, and some good réplica of husos made into decor.  We spent time learning about various qualities, origins, and weaving componentes of colorgul fabrics.  
Vendors were generally pleasant with only a few marketing their goods with extra enthusiam. 
The market can be fun and can also have challenges.  Everyone speaks English. 
Delightful market

reviews.title: Market visit Banjul
reviews.text: It’s a tourist market mainly . Very repetitive. But some nice hand made prices . You have to haggle but stuff is junk really. You cannot take photos of locals unless you buy from them. It is not safe to go alone as you get too much hassle and pick picketers . Our taxi driver accompanied us so no hassle at all. Didn’t buy  much but  nice to see locals selling their food. You can also see junta minutes island from there.

reviews.title: Smelly but good experience
reviews.text: Smelly and dusty but good experience. We visited this market with Buba tours. It was a nice experience to see the local stalls but be prepared for bad smell, mosquitos and people trying to attract your attention. We bought some wood crafts and cookies here. Visit this market with a good guide (like Buba tours) to find your way back out and to help you bargain at the prices.

reviews.title: Good market
reviews.text: It's a good market for food, toiletries, fabric, fruits and crafts. I got some Sheabutter from the market

reviews.title: Not for the faint hearted
reviews.text:
We had a free trip and choose among others The Albert Market.
Its big,busy ,sticks of fish but not to be missed,its Gambia the tourists dont see ,you could get lost there ,every one seems to be selling fish,vegetables and spices,oh dont go to the tourist part to get ripped of .
if you get the chance go but take a quide

reviews.title: Big market
reviews.text: This Albert market is biggest market in Banjul and I think, it is biggest market in the whole Gambia. From here you can find allkind of souvenirs, shoes, clothes, fabrics, food etc. Market is under the metal roof (African style), so you can visit there also in Rain days.

reviews.title: Day trip to the craft market
reviews.text:
If you like negotiating then you need to attend this market. Almost everything is up for negotiation. 

You’ll love it just like it did.

reviews.title: Desparate
reviews.text: After visiting gambia several times i enjoyed talking to the locals in the market and they made me very welcome.  Unfortunately this time as no tourists coming in i found it the opposite . I was shouted at by one store owner as i was effecting his business i know thus is a difficult time for gambians but found it very hostile and some if them very angry and aggressive i certainly wont be visiting again

reviews.title: hassle !
reviews.text: Such a pity because I wanted to buy several things for the family, but the hassling and pushing by he vendors drove me away very quickly. If they'd just leave people to look, they'd make more sales.

reviews.title: A few tricks
reviews.text:
The trick is when dealing with the stallholders is first of all go and look at what you are wanting to buy get a feeling for the price walk away go and have a drink then take the money out of your purse or pocket and having your hand so that when you go back you tell them that this is all you have money talks louder if they can see it and you will get everything at roughly one third of the price they are wanting

Try it it works

reviews.title: What an experience
reviews.text:
Talk about busy, colourful, sights you wouldn't see in a market in the UK. Our taxi driver had his number plates removed by the police for parking in the wrong area and then had to pay a fine to get them back. 
Plenty of opportunity for a good haggle and good humoured banter. You can buy spices, chickens, fabrics, clothes, belts, shoes, pretty much anything you want.

reviews.title: All the same
reviews.text: At this market you will find the same souvenirs as on Serekunda Market or Brikama.  The only difference is that they are more expensive as this market is for tourists.

reviews.title: Very nice Market
reviews.text: A real nice market with awesome people who all want to sell u something. Best time to go is around the muslim prayer time. You will find what u will looking for here although most vendors sell the same things

reviews.title: VERY NICE CRAFT MARKET
reviews.text:
this is well stocked craft market. but if you travel to Baqau. there is a craft market there will be lot cheaper plus they sell amazing hand made wood ornaments.
senegambia as a whole is just over priced restaurants supermarkets. everything over priced for tourists. I went pharmacy for some ankle sock and creams wanted 1200 dalassi.
went to pharmacy in Baqau and kololi and was half price. same restaurants look for local restaurants. there is a kaddy kaddy gambia food jus round corner. full plate lamb and rice 50 dalassi. it's not glam though. for fruits there is stalls at traffic lights or go serekunda. everything is cheap there. there are wholesale shops for soft drinks and provisions.

reviews.title: Have a look
reviews.text: Same same really loads of different things to pick from the best part the hussle and getting the best price. You can see alot of work has gone into the crafting of the goods. Good gifts for home.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Good place to get gifts to take back home
reviews.text: The arts and craft market has a line of shops with paintings, wood and metal carvings crafts, african prints clothings shirts, dresses, wall batik paintings with various designs, fridge magnets, scarves that can be used as souvenirs. You will definitely have to haggle for prices, once they know you're a tourist they always add on 5 times the price so I'd advice if the craft man says 3000 dalasi price it down all the way to 500 till you get to a reasonable price. It is definitely a good place to buy art work but be ready to haggle!

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Sightseeing
reviews.text: Roaming about and popping in to each shop in the craft market to see  and get what I want. Very nice environment, 2 minutes walk to the Bakau beach and to the local market where you get most of the nice fruits like mango, bananas, oranges and other legumes. At the beach side you can have a stroll with friends and eat fresh fish, if you want it grilled or cooked you can get it from the sea side.its a lovely place.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Love the craft market
reviews.text: I love visiting the craft market where you can actually see the goods on sale being made. The shop keepers are keen to show you around their shops and are willing to talk to you and explain how they do things & if you buy a drum be prepared for a lesson on it  - Always very interesting.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: A quality and relaxed market
reviews.text: An enjoyable market to visit where there is no hard sell and you are able to look around each stall in relative peace. Obviously need to barter a little on the price but good fun. A little walk down the road is where the fishing boats are based. If you are confident enough it is also worth looking around here and the fishermen are most obliging in showing you their work and catch of the day for a few Dalasi tip. It is an eye opener seeing where your Butterfish and Ladyfish come from.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Nice little market, perfect for souvenirs
reviews.text: We picked up three small sand art pictures at this shop as well as another few nice little gifts at the neighbouring stalls. The choice is not huge (wood carvings, paintings, textiles) but perfect if you are just looking for a few inexpensive gifts... While all the traders were extremely friendly and eager for us to buy, none of them were aggressively pushy and all of them kept smiling even when we didn't buy from their stalls. A lovely retail experience!

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Enjoyable surprise
reviews.text:
We spent almost a whole day discovering this museum.  It looks small on the outside but is actually big.  There are inside displays of wildlife, instruments and weaving and then a guided tour of the outside displays.  We were able to touch most of the inside displays which made for an interactive experience.  We were most impressed with the mock up of a village on the outside tour.  Our 11 and 10 year old children were engaged during the whole visit.  There was an opportunity to buy souvenirs at set prices (if you don't like haggling) which were of good quality and reasonably priced in our opinion.  We bought some cloth made by the weaver there.
The cost was very reasonable at D150 for adults and D25 for children.  Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: Took a walk around this market, met some great people, my wife had her hair platted with extensions by Ramada and her daughter (stall no. 48) and it looks fantastic, whilst I waited I ended up playing a game of Wawaw and drinking green tea with one of the stall holders.  I and see Jimmy (stall 55) great guy to barter with.  Will visit again.

reviews.title: Small and quaint
reviews.text: This was a lovely little market designed to sell to tourists. Slightly more expensive than going to the city market, but we enjoyed the banter.

reviews.title: Nice relaxed market for clothes and bracelets
reviews.text: Lots of the same stuff, but nice to walk around during day time, than you see the best. Of course everybody wants you to enter their shops...

reviews.title: Difficult to say no
reviews.text: We found, of all places we visited in The Gambia, the salesmen and women at this market the most 'agressive'. There are some nice crafts on sale but every single person literally drags you into their shop. They put stuff in the hands of our todler to make us feel obligated to buy. Of course they want to make money, but this was to much for our taste.

reviews.title: Handy little craft market for Senegamia area browsers,,.
reviews.text: Situated at the top of The Strip service road next to Sara and opposite Alex. Africa brik-a brak  that you can barging for, some import not local at all. Useful that you can get some repairs done and if you know what you want some things made.  I found a contact at Alex bar that got be a good pair of sandles hand resoled and sown D250, throw away case in UK.  And a piece of silver work made up from a photo. Again reasonable but made off site from market so took a few days.

reviews.title: Shopping
reviews.text: We meet a guy in a bar one night who said he could make carvings of our pets, so I asked if I could see his work and it was spot on, we agreed a price I messaged a photos of the dogs and paid a deposit, he issued a receipt with phone number and all info, if you want anything like this go to unit 12, you will not be disappointed. Also the lady in 13 is quite aggressive and very pushy so I bought a Gambian shirt of a polite lady in 14 hassle free

reviews.title: Eye opening
reviews.text: This place was amazing. Our taxi driver took us here and showed us round. It was a really busy market selling everything but it's worth it more for the experience than to buy stuff.

reviews.title: Noise from the locals
reviews.text: The famous Albert market of Banjul is one of the oldest in the country. This market was build by the British for trade to take place  where locals can engage in all sorts of legal trade. It is a good spot if you want to enjoy real Gambian market life, with puzzling smiles and chants from sellers and buyers. It is one of the most visited place by tourist in the capital city of Banjul

reviews.title: Bustling colourful market
reviews.text:
Be prepared to haggle. Most stalls will start with a price 3 times what its worth so do haggle and you will get what you want at a price you want to pay. 
Lovely stall holders who can seem pushy but a no thank you usually does the trick.
Definetely worth a visit for the experience.

reviews.title: Typical African city market
reviews.text: This market is touted as the largest in Banjul. It’s best to go with a guide or someone that knows the place as it’s easy to get lost in the winding alleys and narrow ways. There’s lots to see and buy. It’s such a busy market with  everything under the sun, available. The sellers are quite pushy as everyone wants you to buy something from them. Thing is, all sellers start their prices very high and you must haggle for the best price. When you’re given a price, cut it below half and start haggling from there. Also be ready to walk away if you feel you’re being charged too much. It’s a bit like poker, sometimes with all the bluffing going on just to buy stuff but it’s part of the way of Albert market. Worth a visit to buy souvenirs and keepsakes.

reviews.title: Banjul market
reviews.text: Best way to get here is to get a fixed price with a guide to help you navigate the market. It is huge and the risk of getting lost is big. It is not very touristy and you have everything from leather, to carpentry, tailoring and fish. The market has everything and try to stay calm. It can be quite stressful with all of the salesmen trying to get your attention. Therefore the guide is essential, even though he leads you to his companions in the market it helps. We went in the afternoon on a Monday and were practically the only people there. It was very special, I wouldn't say you have to see it.

reviews.title: A real treat
reviews.text: Well there was everything here, all manner of smells - good and bad, people, sounds, things for sale and some astounding sights. Barter hard for a bargain

reviews.title: a long walk to a small zoo
reviews.text: Abuko costs very little to get in - less than £1. The guide didn't really talk to us so we gained little from having him. Essentially you walk a long way to see animals in cages - not what we expected. Although the animal keepers took us inside the hyena pen which was pretty amazing. Then the long walk back and pushy market sellers on the way out - you have to be firm if you don't want to buy! Much preferred bijilo park.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: One of the best
reviews.text:
I like this market because there is less hassle than some of the others in Gambia. You can see the things being made. Men with a chunk of wood between their feet hammering away and some of the things they make are amazing.
If you want to buy then be prepared to haggle for a good price. Great fun.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Best Market in the country
reviews.text: I have visited the country several times and have yet to discover another market to equal this one.  The stall holders are friendly and in most cases low pressure, just come and look.  I buy most of my souvenirs here as I am given time to look.  I have had several wood articles carved at the market for me.  If the object wasn't done correct it is either fixed or another is carved.  Special items made usually take a couple of days.  There are a couple of market holders that will sell you items (especially cloth) that may not be the correct size for the price of a proper size so you do need to beware, but over all I found this market to be an excellent place to shop.  Please remember that even though the wood is from The Gambia most items are carved by the Senegalese.  I have some amazing pieces of work at home from the market ought at reasonable prices.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Pleasant shopping
reviews.text:
I went early, about 9am as the little shops were opening. It was quiet and cool at this time. There was no pressure to buy, but encouragement to look inside each shop - not onerous. The quality of goods is reasonable. Don't expect amazing works of art, but I bought a couple of lovely wraps/sarongs to wear on the beach, which were prettier and as good quality as anything I have seen in the UK. As others have said, bargaining is expected. No idea if I got a good price for the few things I bought, but I paid no more than the things were worth to me. 

At the left of the market as you face it, is a small cafe which doesn't look anything but has a reliable and reasonably clean loo - handy if you have tummy trouble.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Low pressure market
reviews.text: After the hassle of Albert Market in Banjul - Bakau was a delight.  Friendly un-pressured stall holders meant we could browse and find things we wanted.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Worth a Quick Look
reviews.text:
Like so many markets around Africa, and the world for that matter, if you have not been to many, this will be something new and exciting even though it is small. If you have travelled extensively, you might find it boring.

I have travelled extensively but surprisingly found it a little interesting. I did not expect to see lots of new and original things I had not seen before, and I did not. It was pleasant though to get some fresh air in a small market that is less crowded and has more open space than most. I hated the fact that people wanted to bargain. I know some people enjoy that but I simply find it a waste of my time. Tell me your best price and I will buy if I like what I hear. Some of the stall owners did not heed this warning from me and lost my business. By the time I got past a few stalls, everyone knew they better just tell me what they really would charge. I ended up buying a small boat and some place mats.

Please do not buy any jewellery that supposedly is made from or has on it crocodile teeth. They sell parts of cow bone and then lie about its origins. When I confronted some of the people about this, one eventually admitted the truth. My taxi driver was also angry with them as he feels that, besides being dishonest, he could be tainted with the same brush just for bringing me to the market.

In conclusion, whether you are an experienced traveller or not, I would say go. Perhaps you see nothing new but at least you will have tried.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: good fun and good value
reviews.text:
worth a visit, be prepared to bartar.
don't be pushed to buy, make it clear you want to visit each shop, have a good look and then go back and make your offer

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Lovely..............
reviews.text:
The stalls are, almost universally, lovely;  with carvings, cloths and general souvenirs to please and enchant the pickiest tourist, you'll soon find yourself reaching for your wallet.

Don't forget to haggle!

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: unbeleivable
reviews.text: Loved this market, and can only smile about the locals wanting to charge you dalasi for a photograph.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Do all your Gambian gift shopping in one place!
reviews.text:
Senagambia Craft Market is many things: busy, fascinating, unchanging and exciting. 
I first visited in the late 90s and I'm almost convinced the same stuff was still on sale. The traders are still extremely polite but can be very pushy and the craftspeople who work in the market are still making wonderful stuff at a price that is unbeatable - but you do need to haggle. 
The woodcarvers near the entrance are a lovely bunch of lads. They work so hard to produce really well made items. I commissioned a carved elephant and collected it the very next day. It might be as well to remember that there is a weight limit on planes as that almost turned into a very expensive elephant indeed. Fortunately I got away with it...
Don't be afraid to haggle and remember that the price given for the goods on sale can be reduced if you push - just, not too much eh? Its better when both parties get a good deal.
Enjoy the market and make sure you go right to the very end where there is a stall that promises no hassle. Just don't believe a word of it! lol.
The market takes about an hour or two to look around properly. I returned several times and found something new to look at on each occasion.

reviews.title: Peter crowe
reviews.text: The craft market situated at the entrance to the strip is a must place to visit  for gifts or just to look around plenty of hand made items for sale with no set prices  "haggle away  great fun

reviews.title: Holiday
reviews.text:
Love visiting  any market in the world.  This market has many stalls lots of banter,  
Lots of bracelets for sale, everyone wants you the look in their shops on their stalls.  Love chatting with the locals here people are so friendly and poilet.  Go and take in some culture.

reviews.title: Hot and traditional craft market
reviews.text: Worth a visit, but be prepared to haggle and resist the pleas to by something/ anything from every stall!

reviews.title: Too much hassling
reviews.text: Here are so many stalls selling the same thing & nearly all stall holders are part of a “ cartel”. Beware being dragged inside to negotiate a price which is always, at least double if not more the correct price. Much of the goods are substandard. Many of the carvings are of a poor quality and they are liable to split when brought home.

reviews.title: Nive but
reviews.text:
This craft market is located at the end of the strip on the right side near the crossing.  
yes, it is a tourist trap but on the other hand you get the opportunity to learn the game of buying souvenirs in a small market. in a bigger market like the one in banjul - albert market - is the same game only 10 times bigger .

You find literally everything there, even several times. So the best thing is to go around and see what is where available. 
Your second round you can decide what you buy where.

If you want to walk around at your pace, just tell them that you are looking around . 

when you want to buy make sure to cut the price . if it is to low, they will not sell, don't worry.

reviews.title: tourist attraction.
reviews.text: Whilst i was living there this market was where i had dresses made,  sandals etc. Good place to buy your presents for home. Lovely friendly people, but shop around as prices differ!

reviews.title: trip with Habaib
reviews.text: brilliant, great experience at the market , lovely local crafts to buy . also walk along shores of Gambian river to see fishermen in action . Go with Habaib he will look after you show you things that the main trips perhaps wont

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Small nice park
reviews.text:
A small park but very nice to see. Good price, 100 dalasi for one person. Worth a visit! 
Nice to see the crocodiles. Staff was good on the security.

reviews.title: Far to intence
reviews.text: I don't know if it is that im a swede but i feelt very uncomfortable at this market. We took two steps in and instantly about 10 people started to grab us och talk and pull just to look at their shop, and I totally understand that.  Still it feels far to tourist like. Everyone sells the same things, wooden statues and batik fabriks and sure they are beautiful, but they was manufactured. So, nothing special but if your looking for souvenires, this is the place.

reviews.title: Looking for African keepsakes
reviews.text:
Visited 2 days ago
As is usual no price tags pure barter system, felt slightly pressurised to buy things we were not interested in buying. Purchased lovely peanut cookies and oranges and bananas from lady I. The photo. I am going to call her big mama but I am sure she has another name.

reviews.title: So many stalls
reviews.text:
Objectively the vast majority of the stalls had all the same stuff, but that's not a problem. Don't try to go in all the stalls! Do go with the flow and let yourself be invited in to see the wares, the stall holders try very hard. Do play a game of Gambian mankala, you do have the time, and relax about it.
Do bargain well but politely, you will get a fair price.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: Lots of wood hand crafted items, nice souvenirs, but you need to negotiate for a reasonable price. The vendors will ask sometime ridiculous prices but if you stay strong you can get a good bargain.

reviews.title: Overwhelming at first
reviews.text:
There are some beautiful items available in this market but the constant hassle from the stallholders can make it difficult to focus on what is available.  I found it very overwhelming at first but grew to love it. Once you realise that they are genuinely just trying to make money to feed their families it becomes more understandable.

Some of the wood carvings are works of art. Clothes are a bit hit and miss but perfect for holidays. Great for little gifts. Prices are higher than other Gambian markets as it is a tourist area. Be prepared to haggle, it is half of the fun. Keep your money close to you and enjoy the atmosphere. I've had great fun with some of the stallholders while waiting for things to be made for me.

reviews.title: Wander after lunch
reviews.text:
Had a wander after lunch. 
You can have a great time and fun with the sellers but you need two things.

Be able to drive a hard bargain.

Have good communication skills and they are good sellers but also lovely.
Enjoy

reviews.title: Nice things, but so much hassling
reviews.text: We didn't make it past the third stall - the sellers go hard here trying to sell all of their things. However, they did have some very nice things here. Be aware that you can easily buy everything for a third of the price that they're asking if you negotiate for a bit.

reviews.title: Easy to get to but a bit over-rated...
reviews.text: Don't really buy tourist bling and do consider a lot this is actually mass produced somewhere else. Colourful and worth a few selfie photos.  A taxi ride into Serekunda will get you to a genuine Gambian trading market, realistic prices, be prepared to haggle and ask the ladies before you take photo.

reviews.title: Better elsewhere in Gambia
reviews.text:
The Senegambia craft market is at the left when entering the Senegambia strip, the sellers were rather pushy during this low season.
Lots of things to buy, ideal for those who don't like to leave the strip.
Prices are higher than at other places. Dark during evenings.
Try the Brikama craft market, and you will be impressed

reviews.title: Market visit.
reviews.text: Nice market with a lot of shops. They all have there own handcrafted materials. You can see nice woodwork, cloth and other things. Try the  juices at the main gate.

reviews.title: Lots of little things to buy for familly and friends
reviews.text: Nice little market with jewary bags that kind of stuff just off the strip very busy so keep an eye on you bags nice people.

reviews.title: Lively market
reviews.text: Good busy and buzzy market. Very enthusiastic stall owners willing to do a deal ! Rather large too. Loads of different stalls and lovely colours abound. See the fish etc etc.

reviews.title: Good local market
reviews.text: While the Albert market does have its share of mask/souvenir shops it is also a place for locals with fish, vegetables, fruits, ancient grains and prepared foods on offer.  It is not particularly clean but it was not intimidating at all.  We were happy to be in a place that did not feel like it was only for tourists.

reviews.title: Not as full-on as serrekunda
reviews.text: And thats a good thing sometimes. Albert Market has all the usual tourist-trap shops but is a working market and caters to the locals' needs, both domestic and commercial. A must is the fishing-village part just around the corner form the market - again, a real, working place, tricky to walk around but an essential visit if you want to experience something other than hordes of tourists clicking away.

reviews.title: The real gambia
reviews.text: Instead of the serrekunda market we went with our driver to albert market. Which is in the middle of the city center. They have various little shop. Dont expect to much. You see gambian selling food, fruit and clothes. You see the normal day of life where the heart beats. Also close to the ferries.

reviews.title: Nice!
reviews.text: Well worth a visit! Don’t forget to negotiate the price when you’re there. Not very big, but a nice experience with opportunity for shopping.

reviews.title: A must-see spot
reviews.text:
This is the main market in the city and is a hive of activity. There are shops on either side of the main street, but the market itself is off to one side and is a rabbit-warren of alleyways and stalls. You'll find just about everything on sale here but it is a great place to buy souvenirs. Some really good and colourful material on offer.

There are loads of sights and sounds. You'll probably find that young (and some not so young) men will offer to guide you around. It is probably worth accepting the offer of one of them, otherwise you'll find yourself pestered constantly and you simply won't be left alone to wander at your leisure. All they expect is a few Euros or dollars at the end of your visit.

Remember that bartering is near-mandatory here. A good gauge is to pay about one third of what the seller first asks for. Be persistent. If you start to walk away, your offer will generally be accepted. Even so, things are good value and, generally, good quality.

You cannot visit Banjul without coming here.

reviews.title: It is a big market area...lots of walking around....
reviews.text: Yes...worth a visit for as short or as long as you wish.  Colourful and stimulating smeliferous.  Everything under the sun!  Much less hassle if you use a guide/escort for this part of a visit to Banjul.  Walk the fish market area and beach...including the to and fro for the local ferry boats.

reviews.title: Craft market
reviews.text: They have a lot but they became hostile when we did not buy at there shop. It is not as nice as it use to be. Maybe better when you shop with a husband with you instead of just two women...

reviews.title: Good for gifts
reviews.text: Good for gifts, but don't buy straight away , tell them what you want to pay, walk off and they will come after you.

reviews.title: Better markets close by
reviews.text: I pass through this market often.  I find the people can be a bit aggressive on some visits.  I find the prices a bit higher than if I travel a bit farther to the Baku Market where I find I am not hassled as much with a larger selection of items.

reviews.title: Waste of time
reviews.text:
Can't really agree with the positive past reviews of this small overly priced market. 

Every vendor uses the same selling phrase...
"As I'm their first customer...I'll get a special price "!!!

The inflated prices are higher than hotel and other markets. 

Of course I bartered but the price still ended up higher than other places. And no...I am very good at this. I'm world travelled and yet their prices are not really negotiatable. 

Have a quick mooch but don't go past 1800. It shuts which is a shame as during the day there's no atmosphere. 

Would I go again.....?  No

Go to Serrekunda Market instead.

reviews.title: Good experience but lots of hassel
reviews.text:
Enjoyed looking round, we did get hassled to buy everything though.  We did buy some drums which were excellent.

A nice experience just stay strong you can say no!

reviews.title: Local market
reviews.text: A large market selling food, clothing, house hold goods and live stock. It is a worth a visit to soak up the sights, sounds and smells. If you have a taxi here, your driver will probably show you around.

reviews.title: Your typical African Market
reviews.text: Just your typical African Market.  Largest in Banjul but small when compared to some of the markets in my home country. Would be of great interest to Europeans. I was able to buy some local print shirts and dresses as souvenirs.

reviews.title: Albert Market
reviews.text: A local market in downtown Banjul.it is a daily crowded noisy busy market with cramped aisles like a maze.it sells everything & anything.not for the faint hearted. The main post office is on the same street.worth a visit to see activity.

reviews.title: INTERESTING
reviews.text: Albert Market is something to see. It is quite large and is very cramped. The aisles are extremely narrow. It is one of those market that purely shows you the way of life of the Gambian people. They sale old clothes, fish (mostly covered in flies), vegetables, nuts, household bits and pieces, cotton fabric and a bit of everything in between. You can even have some clothes made for you there as you will find some very talented dressmakers. This market will be a bit of a challenge for those who suffer crowds, noise and at time bad smell. Try to go in the afternoon as it is less crowed. If you find something that attract your fancy, don't forget to bargain... cut in half or more the price offered and get to a point that you are both happy with. Happy hunting.

reviews.title: digusting, full of flies, not worth visiting
reviews.text:
1. It was like any market in the world that had all the products there. The difference was that this one was truly disgusting. Fruits were rotting, there were thousands of flies everywhere. 

2. The people can be pretty annoying too. They hiss at you and try to call you in, but in a rude matter. 

3. No real places to eat and if you want to eat a proper meal, don't ever eat here. You might even get cholera if you are not careful. 

Seriously, don't waste your time and energy visiting, unless you have nothing to do and have time to kill.

reviews.title: Handbag shopping
reviews.text: At the back of Albert market is the craft market is the craft area. We picked up a beautiful handbag and leather bracelet as well as a great piece of cloth all at the right price

reviews.title: a go to place to shop for just about anything
reviews.text: Albert Market, Banjul is indeed the go to place to buy anything, be it local art curios, local fabrics or readymade clothes, shoes and knic knacs. The advantage - you can find all of it in one place. The disadvantage - for people not comfortable with crowds, it can be a bit of an exercise. Vendors will call out, ask you what you want, show their wares. A lot of goods are cheap copies of famous brands but some shops also do keep originals if you have a keen eye. All in all a world in itself if you are unafraid to explore its winding by lanes. Happy Hunting!!

reviews.title: Lovely market with great people
reviews.text: Lovely market with fantastic people their was a lot to choose from the carvings were brilliant I did  uy a few but it was very hot when myself and my husband went the locals are very friendly the don't try and rip you of that's what I like I just name my price and this it but definitely worth a visit.

reviews.title: Real local market
reviews.text:
A peek into a real local experience of a market. Knowing that you won't be getting your groceries there, the people at the market don't hassle you but go about their way as usual. You can sit and have a drink at the end, and of course there's stalls where you can buy souvenirs.

I wouldn't venture in here alone, so coming with a guide would probably be best.

reviews.title: Market
reviews.text: Very interesting but very smelly and a lot of flies wouldn't go there on your own as quite scary don't think I would buy food, we went more for fabrics and gifts, and only pay 1/3 what they ask for.

reviews.title: Bustling African market selling everything
reviews.text: This is the oldest & largest market in Banjul.  Here you can buy everything from food to household goods, and also local crafts.  Although Gambia is fairly safe, watch your purse or wallet.  Haggling is a must.  The craft shops will be very persistent but simply ask them to give you room and time to decide.  Many people do not want their photos taken so you need to ask first or be quick.

reviews.title: Albert market
reviews.text: Awful scary place. Full of bad smells and desperate people trying to make a living 😦😱😱👃We did buy a beautiful mask and met a holy man . Not somewhere I would return unlike Gambia itself. We have returned since Albert Market and enjoy other parts of Gambia

reviews.title: Chaotic but a very interesting experience
reviews.text: The smells (mostly pleasant) and the chaos makes this market an experience I shall never forget, but would definitely recommend as you need to be there to take it all in. You walk over rough ground through narrow channels between the traders and their stalls. They all call out to you to come and look at their wares and will almost plead with you to buy something and immediately start dropping the price even if you tell them you aren't buying, only looking. You have to be firm and walk away. I found it quite annoying because I really wanted to take my time and brouse properly. I might have actually spent more if I hadn't felt quite so hassled, but it's just a totally different culture. We had a guide with us who stepped in when he could tell we'd had enough of the hard-sell. I don't think I would have liked to go it alone! Not sure I'd want to go back either, which is a shame, but it's just not for me. As I said at the beginning though, don't be put off - go experience for yourself!

reviews.title: African market with all the noise and hassle
reviews.text: A very large market where you can find just about anythings from vegetables, jewellery, shoes to chickens and fish. Its easy to get lsot so dont turn away a self-invited guide, who will tell you he doesnt want money but at the end of the "tour" will complain you dint give him enough.

reviews.title: Surprised with this market wonderful place
reviews.text: Nice to mix with the locals who are all very friendly and polite. Varied market from carvings to general shopping and not expensive. Pleasant to just walk and grouse through the stalls and not being pushed into buying. Very memorable experience a must to visit

reviews.title: Cultural experience!
reviews.text: Nice little market for proper Gambian souvenirs.  All the stalls are mainly the same and sell the same things, carvings, jewellery, fabrics and bags.  The sellers will try and get you into their shop and force you to buy their goods.  If you don't want it, just a polite 'no thank you' and move on.  There is no fixed price on anything so they will ask you for your best price.  If you ask them to give you a price, barter down until you are satisfied.  I bought a nice wooden carving there where the guy told me 850 dalasis.  I ended up paying 300!

reviews.title: More Relaxed than Serekunda
reviews.text:
A good collection of stalls selling jewellery, wood carvings, batik, accessories etc. Most of the stalls sell similar things to each other but lovely items nonetheless. The locals will hustle for business but in a milder manner than the stalls in Serekunda. It is not so hectic so you have more time to browse and consider. I wish more tourists visited the market as the locals there really need your business - many of them perhaps only selling one item a day,

My favourite stall was Roy's which is located towards the back (so make sure you don't leave him out or spend all your money too early!) He had a wonderfully carved giant crocodile that had taken him over 2 months to make. I would have loved to have purchased it but my budget would not have given him the fair price he deserved. He was also a very lovely man and advertises his stall as being 'hassle free' and that's exactly what it was.

reviews.title: A walk through the life of a Gambian Craftsman
reviews.text:
I wouldn't necessarily say that this market is any cheaper than anywhere else ,nor would I recommend it for those of you who don't like a 'hand's on approach' to business... But if you are curious, I urge you to speak to some of these traders to find out the story behind it all. 

For example, one individual, real name yusupha who calls his stall at the very back of the market 'Roye's' had carved a lifesize crocodile out of wood, it had taken him 3 months to intricately carve all the amazing detail and yet was prepared to start bartering at the equivalent of £25 for it (picture attached)

Some reviews call some of these people's products tat or knock offs from serrekunda market. Please reflect on your ignorance for one moment.

A lot of these people know anything else than the artistry of these crafts, they may be illiterate in some cases but can create amazing things. So spending an hour or so down this fascinating part of the otherwise westernised senegambia strip will truly open your eyes.

 There are some brilliant unique items to buy, which unlike the shops on the strip, go directly to the traders, who deserve it for their tireless effort. 

They will be insistent, they will beg you to buy, but they appreciate your interest in their artisan trade equally. I do warn you though, that you probably won't leave empty handed, but for a fair price for everyone.

reviews.title: Mostly for tourists
reviews.text: Good assortment of tourist souvenirs.Clean, close to restaurants and charter hotels. For the real thing,go to Serekunda market for 8 Dalasi in a white minivans and be prepared for a contrast....

reviews.title: Not bad but not great
reviews.text: Theres a lot of hassle, but thats what you can expect from anywhere here. Most of the stalls have the exact same things but there are a couple of very nice ones selling a few nicer pieces at the far end of the market. For a more authentic experience, go to the Serrekunda craft market.

reviews.title: Hustle and bustle but mostly just hassle
reviews.text:
Overall

Lots to see, a small market and somewhere you could spend everyday browsing. The merchandise is mostly wood carvings, key rings, material bags and general touristic souvenirs. 

However it is such a shame because it's just not worthwhile rooting around given the amount of hassle you get to enter the stalls and buy something.

Vendors favourite words "come inside it does not cost anything to look and then you go" fat chance! You will be harassed to go in and harassed until you buy something!

They are very friendly people, the Gambians. However they have not realised that they are likely to sell more if they back off a little and let tourists browse.

Worth a visit to see the market but we have been here for four days and still have not mustered the courage to return.

reviews.title: The Real Gambia
reviews.text:
Visited as part of a 4 in 1-day tour with The Gambia Experience. 
This daily market is a fabulously chaotic mix of colours, smells and movement with people going about their daily lives in a maze of narrow lanes. With so many traders it’s amazing that most people manage to scrape a living!
Bartering is the name of the game. Tourist can expect to end up paying what is the starting price for the locals!
A great experience and well worth a visit.
TOP TIP
Be courteous, always ask if you can take photograph of traders and their stalls. These are dignified people, not theme park extras.

reviews.title: Traditonal and colourful market
reviews.text: This is a traditional and hassle free market where you cab see how Gambia people shop, the produce available and experience the colour and bustle of real daily life in the area. There is a small craft market but the general humdrum and vibrancy of the market is the real attraction

reviews.title: Good Market!
reviews.text: We went as a group and this market was a good market! Good prices (that you barter for) good variety of stalls and the locals are all very nice! We were stuck between going to this Market and the Serekunda Market but we decided on this one! Not sure what the Serekunda Market is like but this one was great for what we needed!

reviews.title: Visit if it is the only market you have a chance to see
reviews.text: The area is alive with people, smells, and life.  I come to just walk through the area and ignore the vendors trying to sell most anything you can think of.  Having a local guide is helpful to guide you through the maize of paths.  Guides often help keep the people from hassling you.  While the meat and fish area may be smelly and upsetting for some, it is worth a visit.  This is one area in the country I had to be careful with taking photos.  The other side of the market opens to the beach area where you can see the larger boats and small boats unloading what they have brought in.  The market is Banjul at work!

reviews.title: a real eye opener
reviews.text: lots of hustle and bustle very vibrant great fun haggling for goods that you buy (please haggle because the trader love this and treat it like a game) many bargains to be had. i would advise you to miss the fish and meat market section it really stinks and swarms of fly but other then that was great fun

reviews.title: An explosion on the senses
reviews.text:
Go to the food market early in the morning (i think it opens at 8): everyone is too busy to bother with you, so for a brief time you'll be ignored and free to pass through unmolested and without being stopped by hawkers. The temperature is also much more tolerable at that time, and there are no other tourists. 
The sights and smells are not altogether pleasant, but a great taste of africa!

reviews.title: Please visit !
reviews.text: You can get all your need here ..Try  to be fair and not to beat their price down to much ! These peoples work hard all day  making there goods They need your support !

reviews.title: market day
reviews.text: i went to the market every time i went to gambia great experience but keep in mind you will get pulled in every stall and they think you should buy from everyone you have to be harsh and say no a lot and only pay half of what they ask or less and be willing to walk away go back the next day and you will get a good deal

reviews.title: Great for souvenirs
reviews.text: Great market for souvenirs! The stall owners can be pushy, but remember you don't have to buy everything they ask you too!

reviews.title: Great shopping
reviews.text: Barta everyone sells similar things.. Material heaven bangles jewellery and ornaments, a must visit for all

reviews.title: Souvenir heaven
reviews.text: It's a nice market if you want to buy some souvenirs for the people at home. Everybody wants to sell so don't be intimidated by them.  I had a jumpsuit made by hand and I love it!

reviews.title: Good for some souvenirs
reviews.text: This is a very small craft market in the strip, where you can buy some souvenirs and you don't have to suffer the terrible smell of bigger markets such as the one in Banjul. Ready yourself for sellers telling you to stop at their stall constantly and some haggling.  It opens around 10 am and opens around 8 pm.

reviews.title: Great   shopping  a  must,
reviews.text:
A  must,  great  place  a  bit  rough  under  foot  in  places but  the  people    selling  do  bother  you  a bit
but  a  polite  no  thanks  does  the  job,  I  just  love  the  atmosphere  with  the  bartering  to  get  bargins   I  will
be  back in  November  2015   and  back  to  the  market,

reviews.title: A good place to buy pressies for friends back home
reviews.text:
However, it can be a bit too pushy for you to buy something.  I wish the traders would back off and just let you have a good browse, take it in and buy what you want.  

However, not a bad place to be.

reviews.title: Go with a Local
reviews.text: When we arrived at Albert Market we were already with a friend, but another "market guide" came up and offered to show us around as well. It was helpful having others that know good prices as they helped us bargain. The craft vendors especially will try to get the best of you and are much more aggressive than the other vendors. Be firm in your prices; they may try and tell you that they're losing money if they give it to you for the price you've suggested but of course it isn't true. For a small wooden figurine or a flashy beaded necklace for example, 100 Dalasi each is sufficient. For a beach wrap, expect to pay approximately 200 Dalasi. At the end of our market excursion our market guide asked us for some money to buy a drink with, so expect to tip if you allow his services.

reviews.title: Not for the Fainthearted
reviews.text:
I had fun at this market, which is actually called Albert Market. It is not the usual kind of fun and you need to understand that it can be full of people on some days. Also understand that depending on where you go in the market, there can be strong smells of fish and meat, with flies in abundance sitting on the fish mainly. The market feels a little chaotic but if you go with someone who knows it, it is not bad. Do not expect to be wowed with amazing arts and crafts. This is a true third world market and some of the streets you might walk through are muddy with stones and holes randomly distributed. If you know where to go, you can also see a beach close to the market where boats arrive to sell their fish first to people waiting on the beach. You will also be able to see from this beach where the Atlantic Ocean and the Gambia River meet.

If you are not sure if this market is for you, ask yourself if you have seen a few third world countries and markets before. If you have, it should not phaze you. However, if this is your first experience of a third world country, it might come as a complete and overwhelming culture shock to you. Perhaps ask a taxi driver to walk with you and, if you feel you want to get out of there, you can then let the driver know. At least that way you have a quick escape.

reviews.title: Good market to visit
reviews.text: A better market than Serrecunda, not so much pressure or crowds, lovely to see all the colours and to smell all the different smells, and good to have a good barter for something.

reviews.title: Banjul Market
reviews.text: the market is an eye opener - but do not go with out a guide!!   you will just get hassled from the bumsters.   we brought some wooden carvings - but remember to haggle, do no pay the price asked.   its a very different world out there but the people are lovely

reviews.title: Nothing to see, apart from some caged Hyenas and Baboons - hassle from sellers
reviews.text: Went here on a trip out, expecting to see hundreds of varieties of birds. Saw less than 10. Paid the entrance fee, was then followed by a manager who asked for a donation for food - anything from 200 to 400D, I do not know what they spend the money on as there seems to be nothing here that they need to feed, apart from a few rescue animals (and only a few!). After a walk around, there is a visitors centre - where on entering you feel instantly pressured into buying a t-shirt or other souvenirs. About half way around there is a shop, and some people selling wood carvings. You cannot sit and have a drink here without being hassled into buying a wood carving. If you buy from one seller you then get hassled by the other seller to buy from them too as they need to money to buy food!. On exiting there are a number of wood carving stalls that you have to pass. The sellers come at you from all over - one dragged me to his stall by my arm and told me that he had not had any breakfast and asked if I would buy a simple darning for 'only 300D' so he could buy breakfast. DO NOT BUY FROM ONE OF THESE PRESSURE SELLERS OR THEY WILL ALL COME AFTER YOU FOR A SALE. On leaving the reserve, there are another two locals who will try and sell you chilled drinks for an upmarket price of D75 (they were only D20 in my hotel). Was a terrible day out, it would be a bit better if they cleared all the wood carving sellers away - or only let one or two sell - not around 10 that you have to pass on your way out, all selling the same things.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

reviews.title: SMALL CITY CENTER, FRIENDLY MARKET
reviews.text: WE TRAVELLED TO THE MARKET - TO ACTUALLY BUY AN ADAPTOR for my computer.  Whilst there we took the time to check out the market.  Alot of the artisans and tailors there are senegalese and the music yu hear blasted around you is also mainly Senegalese. Alot of second hand and chinese imports too (a growing scourge across our continent) and alot of colourful but  african outfits.  Despite the lack of tourists many items felt gearred to the tourist crowd. Not a very exciting market if you were to compare it to the kinds of fabric and tetxtile markets one sees in West Africa.

reviews.title: Banjul market
reviews.text:
Banjul market is a big traditionel Gambian market. You can find there all kind of traditionel products like dryd fish, fruits, vegetables and flavors. you can also find a small part of handicraftwork, leather, clothes, wooden mask, animals and figures.
It is a very busy market, many Gambians are comming everyday to this nice market.

reviews.title: Serrekunda market
reviews.text: Locals and ex pats have renamed this market affectionately smellykunda !!! It is an experience anyone visiting gambia must try, the array of shops and stalls is immense tip take a guide with you to help barter with the stall holders and to negotiate the market as it is large and sprawling. A must visit, throughly enjoyable.

reviews.title: Mobbed
reviews.text: We cannot tell you too much as we didn't stay long enough! You were mobbed from all sides as soon as you enter and it can be intimidating. What we did see was very run ofthe mill tourist tat tha t you get in all holiday resorts. There is no such thing as browsing in this market, I wouldn't recommend going although with very little else to do in the so called resort I guess they have a captive market.

reviews.title: Plenty to see and do
reviews.text: Very busy, great to experience African life.  Haggle and hunt for some bargains!  You can buy anything here from fish, meat and vegetables to cocoa butter moisturiser to clothes dye!  We bought some pencils to give out to local children in the villages.

reviews.title: Typical market
reviews.text: Good market with plenty to browse around, be ready to barter and you will have a great experience all tastes catered for!

reviews.title: Nothing bad, just all a bit the same as any other.
reviews.text: The stalls are all very much the same as you find else where, carvings, shells, jewellery, drums, cloths etc. Store holders, not too hasslesome like some others. Didn't buy anything as nothing that took my eye. The ladies selling fruit and nuts are nice and very friendly, would go there again to get supplies. Do drive a hard bargain though.

reviews.title: good market
reviews.text: Excellent market for material, and also for wood - best there is apart from Brikama... worth walking down on the beach towards the barra ferry as well - as this is an experience...

reviews.title: Survive This and You Can Survive Anything
reviews.text:
Yep, that's how they advertise this incredible experience & how true that is... Bustling, vibvrant, colourful and simply out of this world. Welcome to The real Gambia my friend... Here at Banjul Market one can buy almost anything from a single colour nut to chew throughout the day to a hundredweight of sun-dried lady fish...Just watch where you put your feet. Surprisingly very little hassle, so don't worry. Keep moving and enjoy. We certainly did...

All Good Things, Neville & Jill Pettitt (England UK)

reviews.title: An experience!
reviews.text: We saw a bit of the real life of the people of Gambia as, with no fridges, market day is every day. Crowded and colourful with sights and smells we are not used to in our ultra hygienic world.

reviews.title: Hectic, Crazy and fun
reviews.text: Don't mind everybody approaching you, that is a part of the experience. You see how the majority of the local Gambians make business and what they mainly sell. Always bargain.. 90% discount and you will achieve a fair price.

reviews.title: No hassle.
reviews.text: Quite an experience, loads to see and all sorts of things for sale, as usual if buying dont accept the first price, it is mainly for locals, but they are used to tourists. Perfectly safe, just use a little common sense re bags etc.

reviews.title: Just a market
