reviews.text: Good idea to go with a Gambian so you will be left alone. Most things that a tourist would want to buy can be purchased from hotel shop or other street seller and you will get the same price all you have to do his haggle

reviews.title: Be careful of the pick pockets
reviews.text: Ok market, not so big as compared to the ones in Nigeria. However, good for sight seeing, buying also and having a feel of The Gambia.

reviews.title: OK for a trip
reviews.text: The locals proudly say you can buy anything at this market.  But it looks more like a car boot sale than any market we are used to.  The crowds and stalls might look intimidating, but the locals are harmless (if overfriendly).  Personally, I was not impressed, but others might want to try the experience.

reviews.title: Look at all markets.
reviews.text:
Banjul market is great and really colourful but if you are in Kololi, Serrekunda is as good if not better. Also, have a look at the market at the top of the Senegambia strip. All prices are negotiable and don't be intimidated by the hard sell. Be in control.
Clothes can be made at very reasonable prices. Make a fair price that you feel you want to pay. If it's refused, walk away without being rude. You will get what you want .
Give it a try.

reviews.title: what an eye opener!
reviews.text: this market is nothing like uk markets,and you need a strong stomach with most of it,if you like haggling then you"ll love it, seeing how Gambian people live and work in these markets is a right eye opener and you really appreciate how clean and tidy uk markets are.

reviews.title: Great Gambian experience!
reviews.text: large African market where you can find almost everything! It is large, so if you are worried about getting lost in the maze it might be a good idea to take a guide along. It is much less hectic and overcrowded than Serrekunda market and most of the alleyways are quite wide. Large craft market that carers for tourists, but  more selection and cheaper than most others I have visited. If you like vivid-coloured abstract African paintings, ask in the craft market for Ebrima Jaiteh and other stallholders will point you to his stall where he paints while you watch..

reviews.title: You just have to go
reviews.text: The market is difficult to describe; it's more of an experience than an attraction.  I visited numerous times over a four month period between September and December while I was living in Serekunda and working in Banjul.   My experience, and the way I was treated by vendors and others, evolved over four months I was there. At the end, although I was never a native, I was no longer a complete outsider or merely a tourist.

reviews.title: Senegambia Craft Market
reviews.text: This is Africa! expect to be hassled, expect to be cajoled, expect to bargain for items. Always be smiley and pleasant, ideally the first time you visit look only, do n't touch or even ask prices. Reflect on what you want and return another day, then look and touch ! The products are cheap anyway but always barter, excellent fabric, wood carvings and jewellery.

reviews.title: What an afull place
reviews.text: Not only they pretend to make it by themselves (all is imported from abroad) they will surround you and all at the same time try to drag you to their shop (often arguing with you) that they have what you want (even though I say nothing what I am looking for). If you want a souvenir then go in there in group with something on your mind and leave quickly or you can but at shops.

reviews.title: Silly prices African craft market
reviews.text: A good selection of arts and crafts, some nice pieces and some not so nice.  The prices are ridiculous at the offset coupled with pushy overzealous sellers.  These things cost pittance to make in comparison to the retail.  Their is a premium to pay as a foreigner and this is exploited relentlessly by sellers trying to sell goods at far beyond their worth.  You can haggle but you will never be able to pay a fair price.  If you crave attention and have money is not a concern then you will like this place and they in turn will love you.

reviews.title: SENEGAMBIA CRAFT MARKET
reviews.text: Senegambia Craft Market is right on the beautiful tourist strip at Kololi.  To get there, head down the Bertil Harding Highway southbound until you get to the Senegambia Junction.  The Highway and Junction are bitumen roads straight from Banjul Airport, which really helps as many roads are not surfaced in Gambia.  The Craft Market is right on the crossroads and surrounded by Restaurants such as the excellent Gaya Art Café on the highway and popular African Queen Restaurant just around the corner near Totties Nightclub.  The Craft Market is in a thriving tourist area and there you will find many locally made souvenirs to buy and bring home while stopping off to have a drink or meal in the area on the way to or from Kololi Beach.  You can watch the wood carvers making traditional African masks and ornaments.  You may see sand painters at work, buy some art or hand-made jewellery, try some local food, buy fruit and juice, and see tailors sewing on treadle sewing machines making pretty sun dresses for women and children as well as traditional African clothing.  You can even have a tailor make you an outfit, and I have had a made-to-measure dress or two made there myself.  I can personally recommend Fatou Jagne who has a tailor’s business in the market as that is where I had my first traditional African outfit made-to-measure on a trip to Gambia.  Perhaps you will even catch some djembe players in action or just buy one of these beautifully made traditional drums to take home.  I’ve seen many wrapped up going through the departures queue at Banjul Yundum Airport.  The musicians are not there all the time, but the carvers who make the djembe drums might just show you how to play one if you want to try.  Prices there vary slightly and the traders can be haggled with but please do be polite and reasonable as they have overheads to pay, families to support and “hand-made” in any part of the world takes time.  Don’t forget that materials cost money too.  Their art and crafting is their job not a hobby and they are all very nice people keen to please.  One wood carver made me a wooden fish ornament for my brother while I watched, though fish were not his usual thing to carve.  The people working there are open to suggestions and keen to help.  The thing I like about it being situated right on Senegambia Junction is that at the side of the Craft Market there is a police checkpoint and the officers there will ensure that no tourist is hassled of harassed.  It’s one of my favourite spots in Gambia and I stay in the Kololi area frequently.

reviews.title: Market Trip
reviews.text: Go very early in the morning and there is not to much hassling, very dirty and noisy, once in a lifetime visit never to be repeated again.

reviews.title: An experience not to miss.
reviews.text: As the title says, this is a not to be missed experience.  Allow yourself plenty of time, it is a maze and you will be sharpening up your bartering skills before you know it. Don't just look at the tourist areas, have a look at the food market as well, Tesco's will never seem the same again. Remember not to show too much money or it will seriously affect your bartering power.

reviews.title: An interesting ethnic experience but not necessarily a pleasant one
reviews.text: Banjul market is a crowded rather insanitary tradilitonal African market. You will need to be firm to avoid "bumsters" trying to act as go-betweens and consequently hiking the prices for their own unseen commission while expecting a tip form you afterwards. Most of what is on sale is poor quality Chinese produce. Watch your personal belongings in the narrow alleyways and be sure to take a very tough line in bartering in the unlikely event that you see something worth buying.

reviews.title: THE REAL GAMBIA
reviews.text: Banjul market is a bustling and noisy place which some tourists are not really prepared for as they approach the experience with their own country's mindset.  If people want to see the country as it is, an open mind is needed.  Here is the real Gambia and an active one where people are putting a lot of effort into earning a living.  Gambians are hard working people.  There is no state benefits system such as that in the UK, so the people in Gambia are very resourceful and productive.  The tourists really need to support their enterprise.  Comparing it to shopping experiences in the tourists' home country is unfair and unrealistic.  Tourists know the price of goods in their home country but many are not willing to pay the price when they go there and even expect to under-pay.  They see the local traders as "husslers" though they are just trying to make a living and they put a lot of efffort into it.  I would encourage tourists to support local industry, but also to do as they do at home - shop around!  Get friendly with a local person who knows where the bargains are.  Gambian ladies are always good to know and helpful, telling people where to find the best price for something they want to buy.  Banjul market is good, but also try Senegambia Craft Market on the Bertil Harding Highway.

reviews.title: its an experience
reviews.text: There has been a lot of work done to stop this being such a nightmare for tourists from what I understand, we had our taxi driver with us but did not feel in the least bit intimidated. If it were like shopping in Asda......there would be no point!! relax and enjoy....

reviews.title: market
reviews.text: Al ways go to the market take local person with you this way you don;t get overcharged and they are very helpfull at bartering for taxi ect

reviews.title: a must see market
reviews.text: this is a very eye opening place and certainly a busy one. i didnt enjoy the fish and meat part of the market because of the smell and to many flys

reviews.title: Good place to walk around and get a good bargain.
reviews.text: Banjul Market is mainly a craft market with loads of wooden items, paintings, fabrics and similar products. I would recommend going with a guide or a local taxi driver because they can help you barter for items and lead you to the right section if you are looking for a particular item. Banjul market is better than Serekunda if you are looking for gifts however if you want fabric I would recommend going to Serekunda instead because you tend to get better deals on fabrics in Serekunda.

reviews.title: Well Worth a Visit
reviews.text:
We used a Green tourist taxi and went on our own as opposed to going via organised tour guide. We like to do our thing in our own time.

The taxi cost 700 dalassi £14, the driver stayed with us all the time and walked us around the market. Which was great because a.) he knew his way around so we did not get lost & b.) he made sure that we did not get hassled, he also explained to us the way the market runs and explained what the produce was that was on sale.
 He then walked us along the beach to the port and back via the fishing village.

A big eye opener on how they live and just how poor they really are.

reviews.title: Great place to make friends
reviews.text:
The market traders are great people to get to know. I take their photographs whenever I go there but only after asking permission.
The vital part is to give them copies of the photos on your return.
There are some very beautiful people there.
A modelling agency could fill their books.
Watch out for the wheelbarrows!

reviews.title: Market
reviews.text: The market was extremely clean considering how many stalls there were. It's a must. Lovely people, but you can't buy from them all!

reviews.title: Colourful and and Busy
reviews.text:
Very busy and colourful, and very smelly (not for the faint hearted)
The craft part at the back of the market is full of stalls selling local crafts but haggle the prices are high.

reviews.title: a busy bustling local market full of colour
reviews.text: Banjul Market is a large busy,very hot market,where you really need a guide to take you round,to avoid getting too much attention,and to help with bartering and to find your way round.Theres a lot of local colour,some of the fish/meat stalls can be a bit aromotic but this all adds to the excitement of being in an African market,thats more for locals rather than a tourist trap.This is a great stop off if you are visiting Banjul for a taste of local life with friendly smiling stall holders all trying to sell their goods to you.

reviews.title: Worth visiting
reviews.text: Good and cheap gifts.  Can barter with the locals, to get the best price. Well worth visiting the markets.

reviews.title: Beautifull market but not if you're alone!
reviews.text: Banjul has a beautifull craftmarket where you can buy lots of beautifull craft, such as, batik, woodcarvings, paintings and others. Unfortunatly we where the only ones at the market beacause it was still low season. Everybody is convincing you that they got the nicest shop. Be carefull cause the guides may close a deal with the salesmen and you pay a to high price.

reviews.title: Busy Busy Busy
reviews.text: A busy market full of noise and colour, watch out for pick pockets !!!!..... better to take a local tourist guide with you........... you have to barter for everything be prepared to get hassled to buy  but all part of the experience, it can get very hot in the center of Banjul make sure you take water with you

reviews.title: Horrible!
reviews.text: Very dirty and smelly market...not sure of the exact reason it is included as a place to visit! It was probably for people to shop but believe me, it wasnt worth the stress at all.

reviews.title: Colour and vibrant
reviews.text:
Went round the market looking for fabric.
The market is full of colour and real Banjul life, when going around the market you have some attention. However prepare to be hassled in the craft market, however it is all good fun. If you do not like meat or fish smells avoid this area

reviews.title: Nothing special really
reviews.text:
We booked a taxi driver for the day & he brought us here to look around. My mom wanted to look at designer bags (which are fake here) but he brought us to the more local-market and we felt kind of uncomfortable in those narrow alleyways between stands and everyone looked at us. It smelled bad, too. He brought us to a stand with leather bags which were nice but I don't like to bargain and to be fair, I don't want a bag in the shape of a voodoo doll when I get back to Holland. So we asked our guide to bring us back to the main street. He didn't know what we meant with designer bags en seemed a bit lost so after two shops (who were nice and airconditioned) we asked to go. 
Prior to this we bought some fabric at a stand where our guide bargained for us so we could buy the nice fabric to be tailored into dresses. We paid 800 dalasi for 2 pieces. We had it tailored at the Senegambia hotel by Aida for 1350 (not each, but in total).

reviews.title: Local flavours - good and bad!
reviews.text:
Visiting the local market/souk or whatever they are called are always a must when traveling to exotic places - and the Banjul market as such resembles what you will find across Africa. It is hectic, noisy, smelly - and so interesting!

Obviously you have to fight off the beggars once in a while, but if you go with a determined mind they are not too hard to get rid off. It is not easy to know when you can take a picture and when not - and your eyes see so many things, your camera wishes to bring back home. But mostly you will have to keep those memories in your head to not risk offending the locals. 

If however you shop non-tourist items you will not have to bargain, and the experience will be so much nicer. I brought back plastic dishes, mugs etc. at the ridiculous price of 30-40 euro cents each, and the seller did everything to make me happy finding the exact color and pattern I wanted!

It is however recommended to bring your taxi driver, as you will otherwise find yourselves with a lot of people talking to you only to later claim you own them money for guidance!

reviews.title: AN EXPERIENCE
reviews.text:
a  busy market full of noise and colour, watch your pockets.
this is where you have to barter for everything,people great, goods great.

reviews.title: Albert  fish n fly market!?!
reviews.text: Although the craft market offers some unusual locally made goods,the rest of the market on the whole,is there to serve the locals with "fresh" local produce.It can be very "aromatic" and hot,very busy with locals "on their missions",but on the outskirts are some very good trading outlets,(all round the city of Banjul),so best to wander or explore and avoid the market early morning.Once ventured never forgotten folks?

reviews.title: Busy, crowded, hot and scruffy, but worth a visit
reviews.text:
This market mixes local and touristy things to purchase, you are hassled a bit, but no where near as bad as Egypt. The title says it all really, but you do need to bargain hard, as they will just try to get as much from you as they can. We always take our friendly taxi driver with us, who gives us an idea of the price to pay, though he does this away from the vendor as they will accuse him of spoiling their business.
A far better and larger market to get a feel of real Gambia is Brikama, this is a proper local market and you will not be hassled at all, though there are few touristy things here, there is a local craft centre nearby.

reviews.title: Africa at its best!
reviews.text:
Albert Market is in Banjul on Liberation Avenue - a must for every visitor to Gambia. Very busy, very crowded and typycal African. Most parts of the market are just for the local needs and not covering the typical touristic stuff. 
I really enjoyed the atmophere, smell and sounds. However if you are not used to african Markets at least the fish and meat section may be a very different experience.
One of the few must does in Banjul!

reviews.title: Suggested Green shopping - and save a life or two!
reviews.text:
Why go to a Gambian market and not buy something? Why not buy something and avoid the hassle of carrying it home? Why not buy something that will make an excellent gift and save a life in the process?
I'm suggesting that you visit Banjul market - go by bush taxi (part of the experience) and when you arrive walk along Old Perseverance Street in Albert Market till you come to the shop of Manneh Suwareh, dealer in 'bednets' - mosquito nets, in other words. The nets are well made locally, come in various shades and styles and make superb, life-saving gifts to your favourite hotel staff, village schools, hospitals or casual strangers. Mosquitoes kill people. We take anti-malarials and tend not to visit during the rainy season. Gambian village houses are built to let hot air out, Sadly, this enables mozzies to fly in. Buy a net, give a gift, save a life. Cost? About 200D - the price of a few drinks, and a fraction of the cost you would pay back home.
Manneh is a lovely man; he won't rob you - and you'll probably get a conducted tour of the market thrown in.

quotes: Good example of a fishing village I really enjoyed this visit. We went around the smoke huts where the process was explained to us, we met the ladies ...
Average dusty local outdoor market Typical African market where the same trinkets, crafts, textiles etc are being sold, mostly very dusty. Am the abov...
Beautyfull stuff (clothes, souveniers) There are beautyfull stuff at the market. People are very kind but sometimes its anoying they push you to buy s...

reviews.title: Honeymoon visit
reviews.text: Great little market full of woodworking pieces jewellery and trinkets you will be approached a lot just remember be polite and just say only looking but enjoy the African experience

reviews.title: Must see
reviews.text: The short and outdated exhibition, but essential to understand the origins of The Gambia state. Interesting artefacts but everything is a bit dusted and crammed. Still worth visiting.

reviews.title: Craft as Craft can
reviews.text: Very well sorted craft market - mostly statues, woodcarvings, paintings, clothes and even thimbles (I bought 2 for a collector)

reviews.title: such relaxing place
reviews.text:
Baqau craft market. I go there and sit down with the people and jus relax. they are real nice people there like family. they don't get much business. so you will get very good deals on jewelry and clothes. the wooden statues hand made are amazing. but jus take your time. relax and offer reasonable offers. i was there today. an amazing bird statue quite large was 7000 dallasi. jus over 100 pound uk. a chinese man offered 700 dalassi. thats just insult. it took guy 2 weeks to make by hand. not some cheap chinese reproduction. but im sure he would taken around 5000 .. opposite is beautiful gardens to visit and behind is a Baqau community centre school you must visit and try give some donations.
there is one guy from uk has transformed that school. it was jus a dirty downtrodden shack. now look at it... it still needs glass windows that can fully open. the outside base needs cementing etc etc etc

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: A small  selection of shops selling locally made carvings and other craft wear
reviews.text:
This craft market is a small selection of approximately 25 lockup shops on the corner of Atlantic Boulevard and Old Cape Road going from the centre of Bakau to Cape Point. 

We found there is quite a selection of locally produced items for sale.  Some shops sell wood carvings where you can see the owners sitting outside making items. Others sell woven items and leather goods that are quite good quality and are reasonably priced if you willing to haggle.  Another of the shops on the corner is run by a gentleman who makes woven items and you can watch him at work on his basic weaving machine.  The items are of surprising good quality.

It is not a place to make a special journey for, but well worth looking round if you are in the local area.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: The same old things
reviews.text:
We had a quick look around the Senegambia craft market which most of the stalls were exactly the same selling wooden carvings which were dusty as been sitting about also bracelets and a few ladies sarongs but nearly all the same items.
Nothing we wanted but they were very good prices for those interested as competitive pricing due to all the stalls having the same things.
It is nice to see all the bright colours and the people were very friendly.

reviews.title: Colorful markt in the open air ,
reviews.text: Colorful markt under a cloud filled with fruits and other products, .Besides food and chemistry, you will buy hand-sewn folk costumes here  and hand-made craft .Worth a visit .It  delights and encourages you to buy unforgettable handmade souvenirs .

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text: They made me a Zebra so happy with it the quality of craft work here is of avert high standard definitely worth a visit

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Slightly out of the ordinary
reviews.text: So many African craft markets are carbon copies of each other, and the items for sale differ little. This shop is enough out of the ordinary to make the effort to visit. Very little hassle from locals.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: There are quite a few stalls which are packed in to a relatively small space. As always the Gambian people were very friendly and it was fun bartering with the stall holders.

reviews.title: Lovely day out in Banjul
reviews.text: Took my Gambian fiancé out to Banjul for the day to do a bit of shopping and R&R. taxi dropped us off next to the roundabout opposite Arch22. we had a lovely stroll around and spent some time looking at the nice green spaces. unfortunately they had scaffolding up painting Arch22, but it was still lovely to look out. TIP1. Keep you valuables' secured as my camera was stolen not from Banjul has to be said. and TIP2  make sure if entering Banjul you have ID on you especially if you are in a mixed race couple like me. But don't let that put you off please. was still a nice day out and if you go down some of the side streets in Banjul you will find bargains a lot cheaper than the tourist areas

reviews.title: Good place to shop
reviews.text: We have visited the craft market plenty of times. They have a wide selection of handy craft and gifts. If there is something you would like but you can't see they will make it for you. It has a friendly atmosphere and it gives you chance to practice your bartering skills.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: A great place for children and those into arts and crafts.
reviews.text:
You could easily walk past this little shop with its corrugated iron walls and roof! It's situated right by the roundabout a Bakau craft market and next door to Saffie j restaurant.
The shop sells sand paintings which are I believe are all crafted on site, it also sells wooden carvings and paintings.
Our daughter first visited last year during a power cut but was invited inside to sit down and have a go at sand art for herself. She spent an hour making a very small picture by torch light.
This year she took lessons during the two weeks we were there. She learned all aspects of sand art and even how to dye the Sand!
She made a lovely picture during the time she spent there and also made a friend in Sheikh who was her teacher and is the son of the owner.
We paid 150 (£3) per hour and while she was busy with the sand we spent the time she was in there watching the world go by from Saffie j next door.
The day before we came home we were each given a bag of gifts by Sheikh and a lovely card. She was also given everything she needs to practice at home (including the different coloured sand hat she had prepared with him).
Please stop and have a look if you're passing this place, the amount of work that goes into these sand paintings is amazing. Have a couple of lessons and learn for yourself how it is done, it's worth every penny.

placeInfo.name: Bakau Craft Market - Sand Art Shop

reviews.title: Good selection of crafts
reviews.text: The craft market is convenient if you are staying in the Senegambia/Kololi area.  The selection is good and the vendors willing to negotiate.  They can be aggressive, but not as pressing as other places in Gambia.

reviews.title: interesting caft market, nice place to visit
reviews.text: like all other gambian craft markets we can find a bit of all hand made jewellery, bags and colourfull clothes, people are very friendly and its well located at the center of Senegâmbia.

reviews.title: worth a visit if your in banjul
reviews.text: Don't go out of your way especially for this one - but there is a little museum and art gallery. £1 entrance fee and good views from the top

reviews.title: The 'Royal Albert' always worth a visit if in Banjul and an hour to spare.
reviews.text: Might be serious shopping for the initiated, fish, fruit and veg, fabrics or a browse around the many craft stalls at the back. Always a bargin to be had with a bit of negotiation and this time of year some real photo treats as the Gambians go about their daily routine, in colourful dress and close to Ramadam.

reviews.title: Hmm . . it all rather looked the same
reviews.text: Near the top of the strip, the craft market seems to be stocked with imported goods than locally crafted ones, and most of the stalls looked very similar.  There were some batik stalls which broke up the monopoly of the bangles, beads and baubles most of the other stalls had

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: this craft market is nice and pleasant to walk round but you do get stopped a lot with the stall holders so it takes longer to get round, all the stalls seem to be selling the same stuff

reviews.title: Do it and try it
reviews.text:
Try this craft market, nice people and they have it all, good prices with quality products.
Visit stand number 56 - ask for Rake - Quality products and good prices.

reviews.title: lots to see
reviews.text: crafts you can do or watch tie and dye being done and then have a  chance to purchase any of the goods. wood crafts are excellent and an art in there selves.

Craft as Craft can Very well sorted craft market - mostly statues, woodcarvings, paintings, clothes and even thimbles (I bought 2 for a collector)

reviews.title: Great place for children of all ages.....
reviews.text: Allegedly, this sacred pool was established in 1860's or earlier - it is small and a bit grubby but you can get really close to the crocodiles. The small museum and huge trees - you can stand in one - make the whole visit great fun.
